Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: Unknown
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Amendment Bill 1998 provides for the imposition of annual charges to recover costs incurred by the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism in monitoring telecommunications industry development plans prepared by carriers under the Telecommunications Act 1997. Part 3 of the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Charges) Act 1997 provides for the imposition of an annual charge on a carrier licence that is in force at the beginning of a financial year beginning on or after 1 July 1998. The amount of the annual charge is ascertained in accordance with a disallowable instrument determined by the Australian Communications Authority. The act provides for a limit on the total amount of this charge on carriers having regard to the amounts attributable to the ACA's and ACCC's telecommunications functions and powers for the immediately preceding financial year, the proportion of the Commonwealth's contribution to the budget of the International Telecommunication Union for the calendar year that is to be recovered from carriers and an estimate of the grants likely to be made by the minister during the financial year to fund consumer representation and research in relation to telecommunications. Currently, the licence charge payable by telecommunicatiOIls carriers does not recover costs incurred by DIST. The bill provides that, in addition to the amounts mentioned above, the total charges imposed on carrier licences in force at the beginning of a financial year may include an amount determined, by a written instrument made by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, to be the proportion of DIST' s costs for the immediately preceding financial year that is attributable to the administration of the industry development plan requirements contained in part 2 of schedule 1 to the Telecommunications Act 1997. The cost associated with the administration of part 2 of schedule 1 to the Telecommunications Act 1997 is expected to be in the order of $600,000 in the first year and is likely to grow as the number of carriers increases. The bill will enable these costs to be recovered by the Commonwealth. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill. Debate (on motion by Mr Crean) adjourned. NA Motion of Censure

Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: TECHNOLOGY AND ENGINEERING
text: Wide Bay-Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs) (9.56 a.m.)I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council Repeal Bill 1998, in part, implements the changes announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on 18 December last year to his high-level science, technology and engineering advisory arrangements. Upon coming to office, the government identified as a priority the need to examine how Australia's science and technology system might be improved. The then Minister NOES for Science and Technology commissioned the Chief Scientist, Professor John Stocker, to investigate and report on certain aspects of Australia's science and technology arrangements. In his report to the then minister, Professor Stocker identified several strengths and a number of structural weaknesses in the current science and technology advisory arrangements. Professor Stocker spoke very highly indeed of the role played by the Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council. He observed that PMSEC provides a unique forum for the Prime Minister and other senior ministers to be informed of recent developments in science and technology and their application to the national needs and opportunities. Professor Stocker noted also the difficulties which the Australian Science, Technology and NA Engineering Council faces in respect of undertaking the complex tasks of consultation, analysis of issues and in the synthesis of its findings. Professor Stocker suggested there R. L. would be an advantage in drawing ASTEC closer to PMSEC, but at the same time, allowing ASTEC to keep its independent perspective on the issues which it examined. The government has acted on Professor Stocker's recommendations in regard to the Prime Minister's high-level science, technology and engineering advisory arrangements. first In so doing, the government has sought to capitalise on the strengths, and to address the weaknesses, of the former arrangements. A new advisory body known as the Prime Minister's Science, Engineering and Innovation Council has already been established. It will supersede the former PMSEC. The new council reinforces the vital role which the government sees for science, technology and engineering in the creation of Australia's future. The name of the new council also emphasises the importance which the government places on innovation as a primary driver of industrial competitiveness. This new arrangement has created a science, technology and engineering advisory body that is able to conduct studies as ASTEC has done in the past. But, in addition, the new advisory body has the benefit of being able to draw upon the best expertise and experience available in this country, while at the same time having a mechanism that can deliver the outcomes of these studies direct to the ministry. This is a considerable enhancement over the previous arrangements in that it does maintain the conduit for independent advice, while adding a delivery mechanism that ASTEC has never had. The new council will meet in full session, generally twice in a year, to discuss major issues in science, technology and engineering and their contribution to the economic and social development of Australia. It will be chaired by the Prime Minister and will include ministerial and non-ministerial members. Ministerial members will comprise ministers for whom science, technology and engineering are particularly relevant to their portfolio responsibilities. Non-ministerial members will be drawn from key representatives of the business and scientific communities. The non-ministerial members of the new council will constitute a standing committee. This standing committee will oversee and contribute to studies and research to improve the understanding of Australia's science, technology and engineering capabilities and the effectiveness of their organisation and utilisation. As such, the standing committee will have similar functions and responsibilities time. to ASTEC. It will also have a similar capacity to ASTEC to undertake work on its own initiative, as well as work identified for it by the government. With this new and significantly enhanced advisory council established, the government is acting now to remove the largely redundant ASTEC from the statutes. In repealing the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council Act 1978, the new council will become the government's main independent source of advice on science, technology and engineering. The government is therefore concerned to see that the new council is provided with adequate resources to underpin its important advisory role. The resources which are currently allocated to ASTEC will be transferred to the new council and its secretariat once the ASTEC Act has been repealed. The government values ASTEC's current work and wishes to see it completed before the ASTEC act is repealed. I believe that adequate provision has been made in the bill to ensure that this may be the case. The government also wishes to see that provisions in the ASTEC Act to protect council members and others associated with the council, both past and present, against actions, suits or other proceedings, are maintained. Similarly, secrecy provisions c()mparable to those in the ASTEC Act must be maintained to ensure that confidences are kept in respect of information and data that might have been provided to past and present council members and others associated with the council during its existence. The bill carries forward both the protection from actions and the secrecy provisions of the ASTEC Act. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum. Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (10.03 a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. Overview of the bill The common law has long recognised the principle of set-off between an insolvent company and its creditors. Where a company is insolvent there would be an injustice if the law allowed the liquidator to insist upon receiving 100 cents in the dollar on the whole of a debt due to the company, while insisting that the creditor must be satisfied with less than 100 cents in the dollar in relation to a debt owed by the company to the creditor. To address this, the law has allowed liquidators and creditors to set-off the debts, so that the net amount becomes payable or provable, as the case may be, in the liquidation. This important principle has been taken up into section 553C of the Corporations Law. However, the common law in this area has not kept pace with technology. Improved communications technology and computers have made it possible for large institutions to enter into many transactions in the course of a day, and to be able to identify precisely the time each day each transaction was entered into. Taking advantage of this technology, the major financial institutions have many dealings each day with each other and their customers, usually for very large sums of money. Further, instead of paying each other the gross amount owing on each of these transactions, the parties have agreed to set-off the debts owed to each other at the end of each day. As there are several participants in the system, the parties commonly agree to a form of multiparty set-off, known as multilateral netting. Multilateral netting has three significant advantages for the parties. First, because only the net amounts are actually paid, it reduces their liquidity requirements. Second, an institution does not have to wait until it receives funds from one transaction before entering into another transaction. Third, th-re is a reduction in risk should one of the other parties become insolvent, because only the net amount is at risk, rather than the gross amount owed,to the insolvent party. However, because the common law has only recognised set-off between two parties, there is some doubt about the effectiveness of multilateral netting on the insolvency of one of the parties. The bill will overcome that uncertainty. In particular, the bill will provide legal certainty for multilateral netting currently undertaken in the Australia payment system overseen by the Reserve Bank. This will enhance the stability of the Australian financial system. The bill will also provide certainIntegrity ty for netting undertaken in connection with the trading of derivatives, known as close-out netting, and for netting undertaken in accordonly ance with the rules of a stock or future exchange or an associated clearing house, known as market netting. In addition, the bill will provide legal c-rtainty for transactions undertaken through the real time gross settlement system to be implemented by the Reserve Bank at around mid-1998. These measures will enhance the integrity of the Australian payment system and the international competitiveness of Australian financial institutions. They will make a significant contribution towards the government's commitment to establishing Australia as a major regional financial centre, and bring to Australia new business and employment opportunities in the financial sector. Integrity of netting in the payment system The Australian payment system currently comprises a number of separate systems for transferring funds in Australia between banks, other finanCial institutions and their customers. The multilateral netting system currently operating in the payment system produces a result reflecting a participant's overall debit or credit position vis-a-vis all the other participants. The system sums the exposures of each participant in the system and calculates a multilateral net position at the end of the day for each participant. In the present framework of banking and insolvency law some uncertainties attach to the effectiveness of these multilateral netting arrangements. These I uncertainties focus on the application of the law concerning unfair preferences in relation to multilateral netting arrangements. While insolvency law confers a statutory right of set-off in certain circumstances, there is some uncertainty about whether multilateraL netting arrangements are enforceable in an insolvency. The bill will ensury that multilateral netting arrangements in the payment system that are approved by the Reserve Bank will survive the insolvency of a participant in the arrangement. of the real time gross settlement system The Wallis report recommended that the Reserve Bank give high priority to promoting cost-effective control of domestic and international settlement risks. The Reserve Bank, the Australian Payments Clearing Association Ltd (APCA) and the major national banks have participated actively in the establishment of sound framework to support enhanced clearing and settlement systems in the payment system. As part of this process, high-value payments-which account for more than two-thirds of the value of cleared payments in Australia-are to be settled on a real time gross settlement basis. Under real time gross settlement, the processing of payments will only occur if the paying institution has funds available in its settlement account with the Reserve Bank. At the same time as the funds are debited to the paying customer's account and credited to the payee's account, the corresponding entries are passed to their institutions' accounts with central bank. In this way the transaction is completed in all its elements-including settlement-immediately and irrevocably. The Reserve Bank and Australian Payments Clearing Association Ltd are working towards implementing real time gross settlement at around mid-1998. However, because of the zero hour rule, some uncertainties attach to the effectiveness of real time gross settlement arrangements. When a court-ordered liquidation commences, any payments or transfers of property made by the company thereafter are void, subject to certain exceptions such as payments made by the liquidator. It has been suggested that a court-ordered liquidation may be taken to have commenced at the beginning of the day on which the order was made-this possibility is known as the zero hour rule. Accordingly, payments made through the real time gross settlement system could be void if the paying party enters into liquidation. This would undermine the irrevocability of those payments and create severe liquidity problems in the payment system. To prevent this possibility from arising, the bill will exempt real gross settlement payments from the possible application of the zero hour rule. Integrity of netting for close-out and market contracts In June 1997, the Netting Subcommittee of the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee recommended the enactment of legislation to clarify a number of issues a arising in netting in financial market transactions. The subcommittee was particularly concerned to ensure that the appointment of a liquidator to a party to a netting contract does not affect the validity of the contract. In its discussion paper 'Electronic Commerce', released as part of the corporate law economic reform program in December 1997, the government indicated that it would be legislating along the lines recommended by the subcommittee to provide a more certain and robust legal framework for close-out and market netting. These reforms have received strong support from the financial sector. To allow the existing legal uncertainties to the remain would leave Australia well behind international best practice in financial market reform. These uncertainties have already been addressed or are presently being addressed in a number of other jurisdictions, including the United Kingdom, France, Canada and New Zealand, and at the international level by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, to promote the legal enforceability of netting arrangements. The bill will therefore take up the subcommittee's recommendations and provide legal certainty for close-out netting in the financial markets and for netting undertaken in accordance with the rules governing stock and futures exchanges and the associated clearing houses. It will put the Australian legal system supporting financial market netting on par with that in a number of OECD countries. Enhancing the integrity of close-out and market netting will make it easier for financial institutions and their customers to obtain all the benefits of transactions which are generally regarded as an essential part of sound financial management, such as interest rate time and currency swaps and other arrangements which hedge exposures. It will also assist Australian financial institutions to join Exchange Clearing House Ltd, an international clearing house for foreign exchange transactions. Ministerial Council for - orporations The bill will alter the effect, scope or operation of the Corporations Law. Accordingly, as required by clause 510 of the Corporations Agreement between the Commonwealth, the states and the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth has notified the states and the Northern Territory of the bill. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and I commend the bill to the House. Debate (on motion by Mr MCMullan) adjourned. PRIVACY AMENDMENT BILL 1998 Second Reading Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Williams: That the bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: The Privacy Amendment Bill 1998 represents a breach of a core promise by this government. It also represents an embarrassment for the Attorney-General (Mr Williams). More importantly, it represents a failure by this government to protect the right to privacy of every single Australian. In his speech on 24 March 1997 which released the government's small business package More Time for Business, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) stated: A tangible demonstration of the Government's determination to avoid unnecessary increases in the regulatory burden on industry was our recent decision not to implement privacy legislation for the private sector at the Commonwealth level. I also raised this matter at last week's Premiers' Conference. I have asked the Premiers and Chief Ministers not to introduce such legislation at the State level. Queensland and the Northern Territory have already agreed to our request and the other States will consider the Commonwealth's request further. I will be writing to the States to set concerns. That announcement was in direct breach of the government's pre-election commitment. As the Liberal and National parties' law and justice policy stated: A Liberal and National Government will as a priority, and in consultation and development with the states and Territories, ensure the implementation of a privacy law regime in Australia comparable with best international practice. As part of achieving this goal we will: work with industry and the states to provide a co-regulatory approach to privacy in the private sector; conduct a comprehensive Parliamentary in9;uiry into the state of Australia's privacy laws. Amongst other things, the inquiry will examine and review legislative and administrative regimes for the protection of privacy, examine public interest and statutory exemptions, the extent of data-matching practices, compliance with international transfer standards, and the need for legislative protection of the right to privacy for individuals in respect of the media; review and, where appropriate, implement the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs In Confidence; The report In Confidence was tabled in this House in June 1995. It was a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Importantly, membership on that committee, of which I was proud to be chair, included the deputy chair, Mr Alan Cadman MP; a former Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Duffy; a former minister, the Hon. Wendy Fatin; the Hon. Clyde Holding, a former minister; Mark Latham MP; Christopher Pyne MP; the current Speaker, the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair MP;  a former minister; Mr Lindsay Tanner MP; and Mr Daryl Williams QC, MP, the current Attorney-General. That was a substantial committee. The report In Confidence that was presented to this parliament was a unanimous report. The current Attorney-General was a member of that committee. The current Speaker was a member of that committee. What were the conclusions at pages 172 and 173 of that committee report? I quote from page 172: out our The Committee considers that the protections provided by the Information Privacy Principles should be extended to all confidential third party information by way of a national privacy code. The Committee notes that if such a code is affected by way of extension of the Privacy Act, consequent changes to the FOI Act would be necessary. Recommendation 38: The Committee recommends that the protections provided by the Information Privacy Principles should be extended to all confidential third party information by way of a national privacy code. It goes on: As this proposal would have wide coverage in the Australian community, including application in state and territory government operations, the Committee considers it is desirable to have the proposal considered in the forum of the Council of Australian Governments. In recommendation 39 the committee: ... recommends that the proposal for a national privacy code be placed on the agenda for the earliest possible meeting of the Council of Australian Governments. That is why that recommendation found itself in the Liberal and National parties' law and justice policy. This Attorney-General, with the concurrence of this Prime Minister, put it in there, and now they walk away from it. On 12 September 1996, the Attorney-General began to implement this election commitment by releasing a discussion paper on privacy in the private sector. In his press release of that date, the Attorney-General said: ... [t]he Discussion Paper will form the basis of the development of a comprehensive policy regime comparable, if not better, than international best practice. The Discussion Paper proposes a comprehensive co-regulatory approach to privacy protection which is designed to provide maximum flexibility for the private sector. I intend to be in a position to develop legislation for introduction next year. The Attorney-General quite rightly justified this announcement by saying: Protecting privacy is no longer an issue for the public sector. With today's technology and data bases, there is unchecked potential for information to be used improperly. As a result of that discussion paper, the government received a number of submissions. Those submissions were overwhelmingly supportive of the government's proposed policy and acknowledged that there would be only minimal costs to business arising out of the legislation. As an indicator, Price Waterhouse conducted a corporate privacy survey, published in May 1997, that showed that more than 70 per cent of companies supported the introduction of privacy legislation. Mr Stephen Woolley, Price Waterhouse's privacy and information security partner, said: Business supports the introduction of national privacy legislation by the federal Government because they are confused as to what their responsibilities are on the privacy front. Mr Woolley went on: They are not sure what they can and can't do and want the Government to tell them. Price Waterhouse's report found that 75 per cent of companies would require only minor computer or administrative changes if the legislation was introduced. Yet, despite this, the first signs of a policy backflip occurred on 13 January 1997. Whilst still supporting the government's policy and still stating that any costs to business involved in implementing these laws would not be excessive, the Attorney-General conceded to the Australian Financial Review that he had no passion for this issue. He indicated that: . . . there are a variety of pressures, some quite unrelated, that have forcedI repeat 'forced'the Government to move on privacy. So much for the Attorney-General's commitment to this supposedly core commitment. Then, on 24 March 1997, the Prime Minister announced that this core commitment-a commitment that the government had already begun to act upon-would be broken. As the evidence demonstrates, this broken commitment has nothing to do with saving business from red tape. It is simply about denying Australians the protection they need of their fundamental human right to privacy. Is this another instance where the Prime Minister has rolled the Attorney-General? Unfortunately, I suspect so. The government, despite repeated requests in the Senate estimates process, has failed to come up with any credible defence of the Prime Minister's assertion that privacy red tape will choke Australian businesses. The evidence of many of our trading partners, such as New Zealand, Hong Kong and Taiwan, all of whom have introduced privacy regimes covering the private sector, is that these controls have minimum compliance costs. As the Privacy Commissioner, Moira Scollay, said in her most recent annual report: It remains my view that a legislatively based regulatory' approach would best achieve privacy protection for individuals at minimal cost to business ... Indeed, there is much evidence that improved data management procedures resulting from the introduction of improved privacy regimes have led to greater efficiency and expanded business opportunities for business. Damage will also be caused to Australia's businesses in other ways. In October 1998, the European Union will enact yet to be determined privacy standards covering the international transfer of personal information. It is expected that these standards will prevent European companies from engaging in data exchanges with overseas companies that are not subject to adequate privacy regimes. It is still unclear whether companies will be able to voluntarily comply with these standards-say, through the adoption of the privacy principles recently released by the Privacy Commissioner. May I digress for a moment and congratulate Ms Scollay on the excellent work she is doing in that area. There is also a reasonable prospect that companies, regardless of how good their individual privacy standards are, will be able to comply only if the law of their nation of origin also complies with the proposed European standards. Assuming voluntary compliance is sufficient, Australian companies wishing to engage in data exchanges with European companies or which are competing for information services work in Europe will be placed at a significant commercial disadvantage by reason of having to establish their compliance with the standards required by the European authorities. If state based compliance is required, then Australian companies will simply be unable to compete for work and important sectors such as banking and finance could be locked out of important international markets. The ramifications of such a decision would clearly be significant. But through all this we must not forget whom privacy laws are really there for-the Australian people. The Australian people will not forget this government's betrayal of them over this issue. As polling conducted by Roy Morgan Research on behalf of the Privacy 'coCommissioner shows, nearly 75 per cent of Australians rank the confidentiality of personal information as very important, ranking it second only to education and ahead of even the economy and the environment. The government ignores the will of the Australian people at its peril. The Labor Party on the other hand will not. Unlike the government, the Labor Party has a long history of commitment to protecting the privacy of ordinary Australians. Item 71 of the constitutional and legal section of the 1994 national platform stated: Labor,believes in the protection of the individual's right to privacy. The 1998 platform restated that commitment and more particularly said that Labor will: . . . legislate to extend the operation of privacy protection to cover both the public and the private sectors in accordance with international privacy principles and the best international standards. Labor also committed itself to updating those laws to meet the needs arising from emerging technologies. When we were in government, the Labor Party had acted on this commitment. On 10 December 1995, the then Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, and the then Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr, announced that the previous Labor government would extend the operation of the Privacy Act 1988 to the private sector. In keeping with those announcements, I am pleased to inform the House that the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Bolkus, has announced that Labor will continue our commitment to the privacy of ordinary Australians by amending this bill to ensure that its scope is extended to the entirety of the operations of the private sector and not just to those private businesses that have been contracted out government work. The exact form of those amendments will not be released today. Instead, we will further develop our proposals in light of the evidence to the Senate's expected inquiry into this legislation. I do, however, indicate that Labor will, as we proposed to do in 1995, draw upon the international experience of privacy protection as evidenced by the highly successful adoption of similar laws in New Zealand. Although this bill is an improvement on the current regulatory environment, there is no doubt that it falls well short of what is required. Nor does the government have any genuine commitment to this legislation. Once again it has been forced to act on the issue of privacy through its own incompetence. It w-s only under increasing Labor Party and community concern about the government's outsourcing of its information technology functions and employment services that the government has produced this bill. In May 1997, the Privacy Commissioner, Moira Scollay, submitted to the Senate inquiry into the contracting out of government services that the Privacy Act did not cover contracts for government services performed by private sector agencies, nor did the penalties that apply to the misuse of private information by public servants under the Crimes Act or the Privacy Act similarly apply to those contractors and their employees. Yet the government did not originally propose to adopt such legislation. Rather, when the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) announced the government's decision to outsource its information technology services in the middle of last year, he initially stated that only contractual protections would be put in place. However, after an embarrassing story in the Sydney Morning Herald, he said that cabinet haq. now decided to amend the Privacy Act 1988 to require independent contractors to comply with the privacy principles. The government's initial failure to act in this regard is demonstrated by the fact that it has since come to light that the Minister for Finance and Administration ordered his department to enter into negotiations with IBM-ISSC to outsource the department's information technology, services from July last year, well before he knew that any amendments to the Privacy Act were being considered. This bill is another example of this government making policy on the run and the bill shows many of the hallmarks of that approach. Schedule 3 of the bill excludes 2Y2 pages of government funded services from the operation of this bill. These include a vast array of government services such as medical and health care services, services provided by a volunteer or community based organisation for the Department of Human Services and Health and the like. No reason has been provided by the government for many of these exclusions. We are particularly concerned about the exclusion of medical records from this list. We currently have the anomalous situation where, in many cases, patients are either entitled or not entitled to access their medical reports depending upon whether the doctor in question is employed in a public or private sector medical clinic or hospital. This is clearly ludicrous and nationally consistent legislation should be introduced to protect ,the rights of patients in this regard. Enforcement regimes under the bill also seem to be highly deficient. No consideration appears to have been given to the extension of criminal penalties for the misuse of personal information. Even the conciliation regime appears to breach the requirements of the Brandy decision by purporting to give the Privacy Commissioner the power to make binding determinations, including the power to award compensation against errant contractors. 'c As the government well knows, as a result of [he Brandy decision, these sorts of orders are only enforceable when made by a court vested with power under chapter III of the constitution. What the government is seeking to introduce in this bill is an enforcement regime similar to that which currently applies to other human rights legislation but in relation to which there is universal agreement that changes need to be made as are currently proposed in the Human Rights Legislation Amendment Bill. On the face of it, this is a very sloppy piece of legislation. The Labor Party looks forward to the opportunity that will be afforded by the Senate committee's consideration of both this bill and the wider issue of privacy protection and the private sector to examine this legislation in greater detail. Accordingly, I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not refusing to give this Bill a second reading, the House: (1) notes the Government's failure to keep its election promise to extend the Privacy Act 1988 to the private sector; and (2) in particular, notes that this breach of a core commitment will: (a) leave Australians open to continued violations of heir basic human right to privacy; and (b) damage the trading prospects of many Australian information technology and information management companies, particularly in respect of trading opportunities with the European Union, resulting in the loss of Australian jobs in these vital ging sectors of the economy". I indicate that the Labor Party will be dividing on this second reading amendment.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: Mr Jenkins)Is the amendment seconded? Mr Lee-I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: I am pleased to join the debate on the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998 and to support the bill and to oppose the amendment moved by the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) and seconded by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). Interestingly enough, the honourable member for Banks represents the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Bolkus, in this place. On every item of legislation, he comes in here and delivers a speech which has no doubt been written for him by Senator Bolkus. He does, however, sound like a broken record on very many occasions. Every time he comes into the parliament to talk about bills, he claims that the Attorney General (Mr Williams) has been rolled by the cabinet or by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). He does not take into account the fact that we have an excellent Attorney-General, someone who is well and truly in control of this portfolio. I think it is demeaning of one of the best Attorneys-General we have had in this country to have the honourable member for Banks come into the House of Representatives bill after bill after bill and claim that he is not really putting forward his own point of view and that he has been overruled by others in the government. The member for Banks was also hypocritical when he claimed that this is a core promise which is being broken as a result of this bill.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: This was a non-core promise, was it?

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: The honourable member ought not to interject. He has made his contribution, and a very poor contribution it was. He has clearly forgotten the fact that the Labor Party was in office for many years and that it was responsible for a litany of broken promises. Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, you were also here. You would also be aware of emer- the l-a-w tax cuts which disappeared and the 1993 no new tax promise made by the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would also know of the promise made by the Labor government not to increase the Medicare levy, the broken promises in relation to pensions, company tax and so on. The honourable member for Banks and indeed his colleagues in the opposition should very much be the last people to refer to any promise which has been broken. The Labor Party in government brought dishonesty to a very high level. The Labor Party in government shredded promises like confetti. They were prepared to do anything or say anything prior to elections and then, having secured the votes and the treasury bench yet again, the promises passed their use-by date and they were discarded time and time again. What the honourable member for Banks does not do is give adequate emphasis to the privacy principles announced by the Privacy Commissioner and the Attorney-General's response to those principles in a press release dated 20 February. For the benefit of the honourable member for Banks and everyone else listening, I want to point out that in that media release the Attorney-General said on behalf of the government: The Government welcomes the release today of privacy principles which provide a basis for businesses to develop practices to ensure that the privacy of individuals is protected. He went on to say: The Government believes that the imposition of a heavy-handed regulatory approach to addressing privacy is not necessary and accordingly the principles are not intended to be legalistic rules. Rather they are intended to provide practical assistance to business-the principles will allow business to develop protections that meet privacy concerns. So, far from walking away from proposals for privacy, we have achieved the same end by another means, one which does not impose more red tape and extra compliance costs on the business community. The Labor Party clearly are not at all concerned about red tape and compliance costs. In fact, during their 13 years of government they burdened business to an incredible degree and they had absolutely no regard to the fact that it was very costly for business, particularly small business, to observe the multiplicity of requirements by governments at all levels. Whenever small business turned around it found that yet again it was being entangled in more and more Labor red tape. The record of the Labor Party over the 13 years of office is nothing short of disgraceful. I have a very voluminous document here setting out details of the red tape brought in by the Labor Party and the compliance costs imposed on business, particularly small business. Mr Hatton interjecting

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: The Labor Party ought to apologise for what they did to small business. I hope that the honourable member who just interjected, the honourable member for Blaxland, will indeed do so. This government will not apologise for the fact that we are supporting a regime for privacy which is balanced, fair and reasonable. We seek to achieve through the privacy principles announced by the Privacy Commissioner a regime where the protections in the private sector are extended to people but in a way which does not impose extra burdens, stresses and difficulties on business. What does the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998 seek to achieve? Obviously it seeks to amend the principal act, the Privacy Act 1988. That act came into being on 1 January 1989 and it requires government agencies with information about individuals to deal with it in a way that protects their privacy. This is appropriate because the public, in dealing with government, clearly have rights to privacy. As the honourable member for Banks himself conceded, the bill currently before the chamber actually extends the coverage of the Privacy Act 1988 to personal information held by contractors including subcontractors under or for the purpose of a contract with the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency to provide services. In the pursuit of increased efficiency this government believes, and its predecessor to a certain extent concurred, in outsourcing. We believe that people in the private sector can often carry out services which have hitherto been provided by government in a more efficient and cost-effective manner. It would be perverse if that outsourcing meant that there was a diminution in privacy to members of the public. That is why this government has not hesitated to bring in the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998 to extend that privacy to people dealing with contractors on behalf of the government. The honourable member for Banks suggested the government has been dragged kicking and screaming to introduce this legislation into the chamber. Nothing is further from the truth. The Liberal Party and the National Party in coalition have a commitment, a real commitment, to privacy. We believe in a civilised society, particularly with technology galloping along, where people do have a right to privacy. That is why we support the principles of the Privacy Act 1988 and that is why we have brought in the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998. It is interesting to note that the former government did not actually proceed with this particular bill. The honourable member for Banks also spoke about a majority report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I was a member of that committee, as he pointed out, in the last parliament. He claimed that it was a unanimous report and because it was a unanimous report the government ought to seek to implement the report of that committee. The honourable member for Banks himself was chairman of that committee and he ought to recognise that he has come into the parliament on recent legislation that has been debated and opposed the majority report of the committee which he chaired in government. So what governments must do is to look at the reports of standing committees and consider them in accordance with the circumstances of the day and formulate an appropriate response. So the honourable member for Banks on yet another count is being hypocritical in so far as he is saying that we were part of that majority, therefore we should be supporting everything that was in that report. The fact of the matter is that Labor members like the honourable member for Banks chaired and controlled those committees, made reports, yet we have found that they have come into the chamber and done a somersault. The response contained in this bill is reasonable, it is appropriate and it is balanced. must be taken into account when one considers the privacy principles which have been released by the Privacy Commissioner. Of course the privacy principles were referred to as the National Principles for Fair Handling of Personal Information. The government is prepared to have privacy in all areas of the economy, but what we want is not a heavyhanded and bureaucratic approach but a regulatory regime included in the Privacy Act 1988, as amended by this bill, which extends the cov-rage of the act to contractors who are in fact carrying out services on behalf of the Commonwealth. Equally, we support the principles outlined by Ms Scollay in her report. We believe that when one looks at the bill referring to, on the one hand, government departments and the extension of those requirements contained in this_ bill and, on the other hand, the privacy principles announced by the Privacy Commissioner we do have a situation which is appropriate in all the circumstances. It ought to be noted that the act does not apply to what is referred to as 'excluded funded services', which include those traditionally delivered by the private sector or by volunteer and community groups. The excluded funded services are listed in the new schedule 3. Complaints about breaches, quite appropriately, can and should be made to the Privacy Commissioner. The Privacy Commissioner can conciliate and, if necessary, make a determination. So, far from this government running away from privacy, we are putting in place a regime which I believe we ought to have. The legislation will also extend the role of the Privacy Commissioner to the provision of education assistance ,and guidance to contractors. Therefore, if contractors doing outsourced work on behalf of the government are uncertain as to what the law is, or as to how they ought to approach a situation, then it will be available for them to approach the Privacy Commissioner to receive assistance and guidance. Individuals will continue to have the right to know why personal information is being collected about them and they can be confident that that information is It secure and is not being disclosed inappropriately. Some people say, 'Now that we are extending the regulatory requirements through this bill, what extra costs will be borne by the government?' Bearing in mind that we inherited a $10.3 billion deficit from the former government, clearly we have to be very aware of the costs of any amendments to legislation. I am happy to advise that the compliance costs ought not be great, as many of those have already been met by contractors under contractual requirements in accordance with current government competitive tendering and contracting policy. Government agencies will be required to prOVide assistance and support to prospective contractors regarding their obligations. So there ought not be any substantial extra burden on the taxpayer. What is the Labor Party going to do finally in relation to this? Do they want to give the government yet another double dissolution trigger? Who knows. What we do know, however, is that at this stage the honourable member for Banks has moved a second reading amendment, which the government will reject, the honourable member for Banks has foreshadowed further amendments which will be moved in the other place and the opposition have said that this bill does not go far enough. The opposition have failed in their approach to date to take into account the extra costs and burdens that their approach would impose on small business. It was Keating who said that small business basically should get out of the field because 'this is as good as it gets'. This government is making no apology at all for its policies assisting small business because we know that, if we can continue to create the environment where small business can grow and invest, we create extra jobs. It is not too late for the opposition to support what the government is doing and to remove the amendments, which are simply seeking to frustrate what this government is attempting to achieve. r am very pleased to support the bill before the chamber. It is an approach that r believe will receive the backing not only of business but also of the general community. Once this bill becomes law, people dealing with government departments and government agencies will have their privacy protected, and those people who are dealing with outsourcirtg contractors will be protected as well. That is eminently reasonable and r believe very desirable. We have the privacy principles announced by the Privacy Commissioner which will deal with the protection of the individual when dealing with the private sector. The government has said, in the Attorney-General's media release: Consultation will continue in assisting business implement the principles, and the Privacy Commissioner has stated that she intends to review the principles in six to twelve months to ensure any issues which arise in practice are taken into account. The honourable member for Banks believes that the government has not taken this matter far enough. The honourable member for Banks comes into the parliament and criticises the government whenever we seek to make amendments in the Attorney-General and Justice portfolios. The honourable member for Banks is suggesting that the government has left private individuals dealing with the private sector unprotected and unshielded by all of the protections which apply to those dealing with government contractors and government departments. r would commend to him a perusal of the Attorney-General's media release and statements made by the Attorney-General. The government has said that we will continue to assist small business to implement the principles. The Attorney General himself has supported the privacy principles, and the Attorney-General has noted that the Privacy Commissioner herself: . .. has stated that she intends to review the principles in six to twelve months to ensure any issues which arise in practice are taken into account. If in six to 12 months the Privacy Commissioner believes that the private sector has not embraced the privacy principles, given the fierce independence of the Privacy Commissioner, there is absolutely no doubt that she will make a further statement as to what she believes is necessary in all the circumstances. r suggest to the honourable member for Blaxland, the honoura,.ble member for Dobell and the honourable member for Banks, and colleagues opposite, that they should go out and take a cold shower. They ought not come in here and huff and puff and claim that this legislation is disastrous, inadequate and a very poor response. Mr Lee-You're the one huffing and puffing.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: No, you are. What they ought to do is to come into the parliament and say this is a fair and balanced approach. They ought to say that they are prepared to to await the further review of the Privacy Commissioner in six to 12 months and then express an opinion. The Attorney-General has brought this legislation in. This legislation is a firm indication of the coalition's very strong support for the principles of privacy. It is sad that the Labor Party, having broken just about every worthwhile promise that they made in government, are seeking to criticise us for implementing our promise in another way. The Attorney-General believes very strongly in the importance of privacy and this bill before the chamber is an appropriate response. The opposition ought not play politics. People have had a gutful of Labor Party politicians in opposition strutting across the national stage. What about being a constructive opposition? What about getting behind this bill? What about not moving your amendments? And what about giving this government credit for extending the privacy regime to make sure that more people are protected? I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: Blaxland) (10.53 a.m.)What a dopey government we have got. If this bill before us today, the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998, was just an April Fools' Day joke, we could walk out of the place thinking that they had tried another one on, that they were going to bung this through, that they were going to play an April Fools' Day joke before the whole Australian communityMr Lee-Before midday.

Speaker: Mr HATTON
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: Before midday, as the member for Dobell said, and before all of the private companies in this community. The member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) made great play of the costs and burdens to small business that would have been occasioned if the government had legislated for privacy legislation to cover all of the Australian community. I am going to go to that key question of costs-not just compliance costs and burdens-and relate that to the question of why we are in the situation today where we have this amendment legislation in which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has broken yet another promise and broken it a couple of times. The reason, we have heard, is that compliance costs would be too great on small business. But it is rumoured there is another agenda in relation to this as well-that is, that a number of very large companies had the ear of the government in relation to this and that those companies are ones that presently gather for themselves a lot of information about people's private lives and then on-sell it. Privacy legislation covering the whole of the Australian community and every private company in Australia would prohibit those private organisations on-selling that information about people's private lives. So I have to wonder whether that was the key reason for the government moving not to fulfil its pre-election promise. We know that the Prime Minister has a thing for non-core promises and core promises. This turned out to be a non-core promise-one that you could flick away-but it was an absolute pre-election commitment. He committed himself and his government to extend privacy regulation to the private sector, and the Attorney General (Mr Williams) announced in September 1996 that the government would be legislating to extend the Privacy Act to the private sector. It is not surprising that there were quite enthusiastic responses Australia wide to the fact that privacy would be guaranteed-not just within government departments and agencies and not just, as with this amendment bill, to those who are undertaking contracted out services but to every organisation within Australia. So it was promised prior to the 1996 election. In September 1996 the Attorney-General confirmed that promise, indicating they would be legislating and that that coverage would be there. What interposed between the promise and that confirmation by the Attorney-Generalthat they would be fully legislating on a federal basis one set of laws for privacy to cover all of the Australian states, every private company within Australia, all government instrumentalities and all companies that you could outsource government business to-and March 1997,just one year after they had been elected, when the Prime Minister said that it was not going to be legislated? He said that the government was not going to extend the Privacy Act to the private sector. At the very time he did it-linked as the member for Banks (Mr Melham) said to the introduction of their small business package and an argument that they did not want to burden small business with great compliance costs-what else did the Prime Minister do which shows the very ideological nature of this coalition government and the fact that they are still stuck in 1947, not 1998? They are still stuck with a vision of federalism which says that the states should have their rights and duties and, basically, the states should do just about everything and the federal government should get out of the game. But here is a twist. In March 1997 the Prime Minister said that he had made efforts to dissuade state and territory governments from introducing privacy legislation that would impact on the private sector, citing concern for the implications in compliance costs. This is from the background paper prepared by the Parliamentary Library. Not only had he broken a pre-election commitment and promise, which was added to and reinforced by the Attorney-General in September 1996, and said that the federal government would not be taking action; he had attempted to twist the arms of every Premier of every state and every Chief Minister of every territory in this land to stop them bringing in privacy legislation. So what did he choose to do instead? He chose to seek a soft option-a soft option which would appeal to his constituency in small business and which would appeal to all of those people who thought the government should stay out of the business of governing, the government should not be regulating this area at all and the government should leave it to private industry and to voluntary codes. Those voluntary codes were a matter for the Privacy Commissioner to try to put together. The Privacy Commissioner undertook to look at this area and suggested that she had quite a number of problems in dealing with these matters, because there were fears within the community concerning just how broad the coverage might be and how effective that might be. I will quote here from the February 1998 paper from the Office of the Privacy Commissioner entitled 'National Principles for the Fair Handling of Personal Information'. Just one month ago, the Attorney-General in conjunction with the Privacy Commissioner came down with these national principles. The Privacy Commissioner gave some background as to why she had to do this job, and the paper states: In March 1997 the Prime Minister offered my services to help Australian businesses to develop voluntary codes of conduct to meet privacy standards. I subsequently held informal consultations with business and consumers and in August 1997 I issued a consultation paper that addressed options for the content and implementation of a national scheme for fair information practices in the private sector. The scheme presented in this paper attempted to provide a viable self-regulatory option but was designed to be compatible with existing Commonwealth privacy laws and any further legislation which might be considered necessary in partiCUlar sectors, States or Territories. She did the job that she was asked to do. The Commonwealth government, through the mouth of the Prime Minister, said that they would not take action and have one law for one country. The Privacy Commissioner was given the task of trying to complement what was happening at the federal and state level. When she undertook those consultations, this is what she found: In the broad consultations that followed, it quickly became clear that the major issue is the need for national consistency in privacy standards. Everyone wants to avoid a patchwork of different standards applying across industries, technologies and State and Territory boundaries. The message to the Prime Minister and Attorney-General is to amend this legislation to introduce privacy legislation in the private sector for the entire continent of Australia. What came out of the consultations the Privacy Commissioner had? People do not want a patchwork. They do not want to be in a situation where they do not know what the dimensions of their coverage are; they do not want six different states having their own individual regulations and statutes; they do not want a pre-Federation horse and buggy approach to this problem; they do not want a patchwork of voluntary codes across different industries with different levels of compliance. Being in federal government means governing. Being in federal government means that when you approach a situation which is as significant as the privacy laws of this country you do act and you do legislate; and that will be supported by the community at largeexcept for the ideological crazies. What was the commissioner forced to do when she came up with these principles? She was forced to put a set of principles together which she hoped would be relevant and flexible and which would cover those standards. She states: Overseas developments, especially in Europe, make it important that these principles meet international best practice. Pressure for a national approach is building and it is critical that we take this opportunity now to work together to get it right. Just one month ago, in February 1998, the Privacy Commis-ioner is saying, 'I have done the job.' The first section is to put down the basic privacy principles. The second is to go to the much harder job of attempting to implement them. But there are significant problems and the key problem in this area relates directly to what is happening in the European Union. Over the last 20 years in the European Union, national governments have acted. Acting nationally, they have put in strong privacy regulations and they have done it in such a way that every company in Germany is covered by their privacy regulation. Every company in Germany and every country covered by the European Unionbecause they have strong privacy laws-is in a position where they can trade information amongst themselves, in the full knowledge that the privacy rights of their individual citizens are protected. There have been indications that Australia was not going down that track; one year ago the Prime Minister broke his promise and backtracked. The European Union has indicated that there could be severe problems not just for any country but for any sector of an economy that does not have strong and strict privacy regulation because they simply may not deal with them. That is why the second part of our amendment states: . . . this breach of a core commitment will: (b) damage the trading prospects of many Australian information technology and information management companies, particularly in respect of trading opportunities with the European Union, resulting in the loss of Australian in these vital emerging sectors of the economy". The reality is that over the past 20 years members of the European Union have moved towards absolutely protecting the rights of their individual citizens. The European Union will not allow a situation where information about their individual citizens goes to another country or another sector where that information could be traded freely without protection from strong privacy legislation. There are two articles that deal with this. Information sheet No.3, the European data protection directive, put out by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission states: The European Commission has reportedly confirmed that Article 25 can, in principle, be applied either to a whole country or to a sector. What does article 25 say? It sets out the principle that data should not be transferred to a non-EU country unless that country ensures an adequate level of protection. It is specific-'should not be transferred'. There is a get-out clause in article 26. This government will be hoping the get-out clause would be there so that, if companies voluntarily sign up to a particular code, they will be covered by article 26. Article 26 allows for transfers of data to non-EU countries that do not have an adequate level of protection but where other specified conditions are in place. The member for Fisher and other members on the government side have noted the Prime Minister's deep concern about compliance costs to small business. This is a key reason that he broke his pre-election promise in relation to this privacy legislation being federal and covering all of the private sector. The problem here is with the European Union. Company by company, sector by sector, and possibly on the basis of the country as a whole, the compliance cost for companies attempting to do business with the European Union could be enormous. If the companies want to sell smart cards into the European Union or they want to sell other advanced products into the European Union and the European Union are not satisfied that the privacy of their own citizens is protected, jobs they will make them line up, one by one, and the companies will have to go through the rigours of the European Union process in order to get a guernsey to trade with European Union countries. That is why this is a dopey amendment bill. A promise was made before the 1996 election that the bill would cover the entire private sector. But, because the biII pulls back and looks for voluntary codes, the potential compliance cost and the potential loss of business is enormous. This is dumb stuff. The federal government can regulate this area once and for all, end of the section. Once the legislation covering the entire private sector is through, none of our companies will have any problem with matters covered by this privacy bill. I will not implore the government to stop now and to do it; I will ask them, just for once, to be entirely sensible about this. The information economy that the 21st century will be built upon is here now and it is growing. The information economy is an enormously significant part of our gross domestic product. If the government want to really damage it, if they want to cripple it, they want to increase the compliance costs and the worries and the concerns of small and medium enterprises in Australia, they should go ahead and put through this dopey amendment bill which covers only the outsourced companies that are doing work for the federal government; they should back off and leave it to every individual company in Australia to decide whether or not they will sign up to a voluntary set of principles. What do you think the European Union will say about that? They will say, 'What a bunch of dopes. How dumb are they? Why didn't they just do the job in one go?' The Australian states of Queensland and Victoria-not Labor states, I might add-are so concerned about this matter that they have indicated they will put in their own privacy legislation unless the Commonwealth government puts in a system that works. The principles provided by the Privacy Commissioner are fair and reasonable, but effectively it is has been left to individual Australian businesses to make their determinations. Some of those businesses do not want to enter into those undertakings. They do not want to make the changes because the compliance costs that would be involved will cost them money. Also, the businesses do not want to enter into those arrangements because they already sell and onsell information that they have gathered. A bank might gather information about its clients and onsell that information to an insurance company or to a health company when the individual has not been asked whether or not they can do that. They make money out of the present. situation. They do not want to do away with these profits by being roped into a federal act which says, 'You cannot do this. You have to respect the individual rights of all Australian citizens.' So the money and the profit could be swept away. The compliance cost issue is not the only issue here. The national businesses that do not do as much business with the European Union or with other countries that are signing up to the European Union approach have a vested interest in not signing up to this voluntary code; they have a vested interest in slipping if out of it or only partially signing up to it. This is the core reason, the rumoured reason, why this change was made and the fact that the government did not line up and put in a national bill. Companies in Australia stand to lose an enormous amount because this government did not have the sense, the courage and the straight sensible balance to act in the national interest by providing federal legislation. Not only that; the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) pressured the states and said, 'Let's put a new flip on federalism. You stay out of this area altogether. This will be the great and shining example of what the Howard coalition government is doing in relation to privacy in Australia. We'll cut the cost to private companies. We'll look at their compliance costs. We'll make sure they haven't got red tape.' They might also not have the business-not only locally but also overseas. If there is one area in which Australia-a rich, natural, talented, clever country-can expand its earnings in Europe and the rest of the world it is in the information sector. This bill should deal with that issue. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TONY SMITH
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: The previous speaker, the member for Blaxland (Mr Hatton), touched on concerns he has with certain aspects of the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998.The government is, of course, mindful of concerns that the contracting out of services, particularly information technology services, could, if not properly controlled, lead to personal information being transferred offshore. An individual whose privacy is breached overseas may, it is recognised, have great difficulty in obtaining a remedy from a contracted service provider who is not present in Australia. The government does not consider it appropriate for personal information to be processed overseas and has included provisions in its outsourcing contracts under the IT infrastructure initiative to require contractors to provide services under the contract in Australia. However, the government also recognises the importance of ensuring that legislative privacy protection continues should any personal information be handled overseas by a contracted service provider. Privacy protection is ensured by the bill deeming anything done outside Australia by a contracted service provider in relation to personal information to have been done in Australia. The bill also goes on to protect individuals extent. if a contracted service provider is not resident in Australia-for example, if the service provider closes down an Australian operation-when it breaches an individual's privacy rights. In that case, any breach by the service provider will be attributed to the contracted service provider resident in Australia, or the Commonwealth agency, responsible for the information. An affected individual will, in such a case, b- able to seek compensation or other remedies under the act. Additionally, where the contracted service provider ceases to exist or goes into liquidation or becomes bankrupt or is wound up, the bill does allow the relevant Commonwealth agency to be substituted for that service provider and to be required to pay comp.ensation. So a number of saving and protective provisions have been introduced to ensure that the privacy rights in the circumstances to which I have referred are protected. As. is envisaged, circumstances may well exist where those sorts of matters may come up, and to have the adequate protection within the bill itself to deal with those exigencies may indeed provide a remedy. There will never be a complete answer to this issue, of course, because circumstances change from time to time. Since 1989 when the act was promulgated, government agencies that hold information about individuals are required to deal with that information in a manner that protects individual privacy. Privacy is a right, in my view, in the real sense of the word. We hear a lot of things bandied about about rights. But legislative protection for privacy has never kept pace with the advances of technology which promote the invasion of that privacyand that can be clearly seen in this technological age in which we live. Obviously, there are state and federal aspects to be considered. In Queensland, for example, there is the Invasion of Privacy Act, and there are other acts which deal with this area which complement parts of the federal legislation. But at the same time, dealing as it does with federal issues within the realms of the constitutional power, it is limited to an As I said before, it is a right, a right not to be interfered with by the state, except in particular circumstances. It is a right not to have corporations peer into your private life. It is a right not to have the media peering into and exploring people's private lives. In the 10 years since the federal act was promulgated, there seem to have been many experiences of invasion of privacy in one way or the other. There have been, of course, the checks and balances that I have indicated, but it seems to me that situations arise from time to time where these checks and balances have an effect that is not intended-and I will refer to that shortly in some of my remarks. Generally speaking, there has been a plethora of royal commissions and inquiries that have gone beyond mere inquiries into particular circumstances and have developed a life of their own. The Fitzgerald inquiry was an example of that. Quite rightly, it weeded out and exposed a systematic and orchestrated web of corruption but, as in all crusades, there was a certain spiritual oil spill that flowed from the sometimes evangelical zeal with which this crusade, amongst others, was processed. People got carried away with their own rhetoric. Instead of trying to detect a dereliction of virtue, these things developed into virtue testing. The agent provocateur process used in drug undercover work has become the norm across a whole spread of industries trying to uncover corruption. The Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland did, unfortunately, get very carried away with this process in recent times. Following the Fitzgerald inquiry, the Office of the Special Prosecutor adopted at times a prosecutorial zeal that led to mistakes and to aborted investigations. In tum, privacy invasion considerations were frequently turned on their head. No more clearly was this seen recently than in the case of Mr Matthew Heery in Queensland. Heery was working in North Queensland in an election campaign for a particular seat. He was working for a political party. During the campaign, certain allegations were made about promises and other matters involving the persons who were keen to ensure that the election was won. As a result of that, the CJC commissioned an inquiry. And during the inquiry the CJC made an application to a judge in chambers and obtained pennission to bug Mr Heery's house. The commission operatives recorded hours and hours of private conversation within that house. They invaded Mr Heery's life and that of his family. This app,uatus was permitted by the state legislation. This is why I say we have to be careful with this sort of legislation. Frequently what it is designed to do can effect great mischief. That example is an outrageous one. As a result of those bugs and the hours and hours of very private conversations that were recorded and noted, Mr Heery was eventually tried for an offence in the district court in Townsville, I think. The jury threw the case out in record short time. It is great to know that 12 common sense people in the community will not tolerate this sort of state invasion of people's lives. It is a salutary warning to state authorities that the comn;mnity does not tolerate the excesses that can occur as a result of a zeal in trying to use an invasion of privacy act for a purpose that-while it may have started out quite innocent-just blew out out of all proportion and caused great harm. I would argue that, in Mr Heery's case-I have never met Mr Heery; I have never spoken to him-he and his family deserve significant compensation for what happened to him as a result of that matter. One would hope that his legal costs would be picked up as well as an amount for his pain and suffering as a consequence of that over-the-top behaviour by the tJC. We are seeing another example of this overseas-the Kenneth Starr investigation into President Clinton. What started as a Whitewater inquiry into property dealings has now gone right to the heart of the presidency of the United States in terms of virtue testing. People's virtues are being tested and then, if the virtue does not line up, the consequences can be a prosecutorial inquiry of a nature which we have not experienced. President Clinton's politics and mine probably do not have terribly much in common, but he does not forfeit the right, because of his office, to the same protections as everybody else in society. I will defend that right while I have breath in me. No matter what politics or extremes of politics may be involved, every person has a right to be protected from that sort of state invasion of their lives. It behoves all of us in this House to remember that and to ensure that, when we deal with these sorts of matters, we bear in mind the rights of that individual to privacy and the rights of all individuals to privacy. Privacy legislation is important. I do not for one moment suggest that the particular ways of detecting crime, the particular methods that government agencies use in order to ensure that people are not ripping off the system, should not be available to government agencies. However, we must use great caution in this area and we must provide very strong checks and balances. I believe the bill does that, but we must be ever vigilant to ensure that it continues to do so. I refer very briefly to the experiences I have had in my electorate of parents trying to track down children who have left home. The children have told a pack of lies as to why they have left home and have come back and admitted to their mothers and fathers that they told all those lies just to get the homeless youth allowance. Parents are being worried out of their minds and are trying to go through government agencies, such as the former Department of Social Security offices, now Centrelink, to find out where their children are, but they are being told by bureaucrats that the privacy provlSlons are protecting the children from being 'harassed' by their parents. I have not met any parents who want to harass their children. I have met parents in this situation through Tough Love, a group in my electorate who desperately love their children, who are terribly worried about their children living on the street and are extremely annoyed and irritated about the agencies that are stopping them from trying to find out how their children are. I do not think that is a proper use of the system. Recently, a mother who does not live in my electorate came to see me. She had been everywhere and had written to everybody. I was sotouched by the letter I received that I invited her to come and see me. We discussed what we could do in relation to getting her daughter off the street, trying to find out where she was and getting her to come home. She was 14 and she was running around with a 20-year-old male who was getting into all sorts of criminal and drug related behaviour. The system frustrated this lady at every tu:m, but we are certainly still pursuing avenues to try to assist her. I can refer to other areas. There are children of age who have disabilities. There are children with anorexia nervosa. One lady came to see me about a child with that disease aged 21 and the attempts she has made to try to break down the barriers in order to have an input into that child's life, fragile as it was because of the disease. She was frustrated by the bureaucracy on privacy grounds. We really have to get that bureaucracy broken down. We have to help parents in this situation. Surely, there must be a dividing line when it comes to somebody with a disability, be it an intellectual disability or a physical disability who, in a sense, unwittingly is being used by the system to keep the parents' input out of it. Let the parent have input, but please bear in mind the heartache and pain that parents feel in these sorts of matters. The system of priva-y that is in place can inflict even more pain on them for no real, logical social purpose. At the end of the day, this is an area that must be constantly reviewed. I refer - o the mass of information that is collected in regard to the computer age-the ability of computers to effectively plot people's movements and lifestyles. All of these things need direction.
