The legislation needs to be ever vigilant in protecting the privacy of individuals. At the same time, the government recognises the need to provide for better government to ensure that public resources are used effectively and efficiently and to ensure that the best possible use of those resources is manifested by effective service delivery methods which are continually improved. That has led to the introduction of this legislation. I support the legislation, but again warn of the dangers of privacy rights being affected by over-the-top actions of governments and others.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: I am pleased to join this debate to assist in reinforcing the concerns which are being expressed by my colleagues in the opposition about the inadequacies of the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998 and, as well, to express our concern that there is - absent from this legislation provisions which quite clearly and firmly had been part of undertakings given by the present government, particularly by the present Prime Minister (Mr Howard), prior to the last election. The Privacy Act, which this legislation proposes to amend, was enacted in 1988, which of course means that it was a Labor initiative. The act at present provides privacy provisions which relate only to Commonwealth government agencies and agencies of the Australian Capital Territory. In addition to those which are the primary purpose of the act, the privacy provisions also relate to or extend into a number of other areas, including for example tax file number information, consumer credit information and more recently it was amended to apply to contracted case managers for the long-term unemployed. This amending legislation is designed to ensure that the privacy provisions also extend to contractors who enter into arrangements with Commonwealth agencies, but our chief concern is that it does not honour an undertaking that was given by the Prime Minister to extend the provisions of the Privacy Act, modified and amended as they may need to be, to deal with questions of privacy within the private sector itself. An interesting thing about this is that the government's own explanatory memorandum provides in large part the case for an extension to the private sector. The explanatory memorandum refers to three possible options in dealing with the circumstances to which this amending legislation relates. Option 2 suggests that the circumstances of contracting arrangements with Commonwealth government agencies could be dealt with by self-regulatory measures. We need to keep in mind the fact that the intention of the government is to leave private sector privacy considerations to precisely selfregulatory measures, but in this legislation the government, in its explanatory memorandum, says what some of the costs of this approach will be. It says that, for business, there will be compliance costs. If these contractors to whom this amending legislation relates were left to self-regulate privacy requirements, it says those compliance costs would be involved in 'designing and implementing systems and procedures'. That is precisely the problem which will be experienced by the private sector because the private sector is not part of these provisions. It says what some of the costs will be for the community and says that 'there may be inconsistencies between standards'. By excluding the private sector and leaving the private sector to self-regulate, there will be inconsistencies between standards. It also says, 'The Privacy Commissioner would have no jurisdiction over the acts or practices.' That is precisely the situation in which the private sector will continue to find itself. Option 3 applies the Privacy Act to contractors supplying services to the government, that is, applying this act which we are now in the process of amending. The government says in relation to that, as among the benefits, to do that 'would achieve certainty and consistency'. We say yes, it would. Extend it then to the private sector in order to achieve certainty and consistency. It says that it would apply 'the same standards'. We say yes, indeed it would, so apply it to the private sector. It says it would involve 'the same consequences' . Yes, it would, so apply it to the private sector. It says, 'Any administrative costs . . . would be certain and quantifiable . . . ' Yes, they would, so apply it to the private sector. Do not exclude the private sector. In relation to businesses themselves, it says, 'Contractors would have clear consistent standards ... ' Yes, they would, so apply it to the private sector. In addition, it says those standards 'would be known to be acceptable to government' . Yes, they would. In the face of the fact that the government promised to apply the provisions of the Privacy Act to the private sector, and the fact that it here provides arguments in support of that approach, why then does it repudiate it? I will make some suggestions further on about why I feel it has repudiated it. As far as the community is concerned, it says as well that option 3 is to apply the Privacy Act to contractors and for the community the benefit would be that 'The Privacy Commissioner would have jurisdiction'. Yes it will. If it were applied to the private sector generally, then the Privacy Commissioner would have jurisdiction there. So as I say, in the government's own publication, the explanatory memorandum, the government makes out a case in favour of it acting where it promised to act but has failed to act. I said that the legislation, as it was enacted in 1988, was a Labor initiative. The provisions within the act are based on the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development guidelines of 1980 on the question of protecting privacy, and Australia is a signatory to those principles. I said that the government had repudiated its own pre-election position. After that pre-election commitment to extend the privacy regulation to the private sector, the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) then announced in September 1996-a few months after the government came to officethat the government would be legislating to extend the Privacy Act to the private sector as it had undertaken to do in opposition. Then, in March 1997, the Prime Minister announced that the government would not legislate to extend the Privacy Act to the private sector. Presumably, that was another non-core promise. What happened between the time when the Prime Minister, speaking on behalf of the coalition, which was then in opposition, and March 1997 to cause the government to suddenly decide that there was no need for any government intervention in the private sector to ensure that Australian citizens would have their privacy protected? Was it to advantage 18 million Australians who could have had their privacy protected? I think not. Who may have been advantaged by that reversal, that repudiation of a firmly adopted former position? If it is not 18 million Australian citizens, who are the other parties to that? Private business? Why then did private business prefer that no protection be imposed by the government in terms of the types of provisions which exist within the existing Privacy Act? Why did they decide that they would be better off being excluded from those requirements? In what way was' pressure brought to bear on the government to repudiate its former position? Of course there are going to be suspicions surrounding that issue-and, by the way, I am not suggesting for a moment that it implies any corruption, but obviously there would have been pressure, discussions, negotiations, understandings reached between prominent organisations and operatives within the private sector and the government to bring about that change. Our concerns are contained in the second reading amendment that was moved by the member for Banks (Mr Melham), who represents the shadow Attorney-General in this House. I referred to the government's failure to keep its election promise; that is the first item to which we have drawn attention in our second reading amendment. The second item includes a reference to possible damage to the trading prospects of many Australian firms, particularly those trading with the European Union, unless suitable types of private sector privacy provisions are put in place. The business sector itself needs to be perfectly aware of this fact and of this danger. They are the ones whose position can be prejudiced as a result of inadequate provision being made within privacy legislation for the private sector. There is a threat by the European Union that it will not trade with countries that do not. have strong privacy laws. On Thursday, 17 April 1997, the AM program dealt with the concern about Privacy International, which is a private sector organisation concerned about privacy matters. Privacy International threatened to push for the European Union to impos- economic sanctions on Australia after Europe's privacy laws came into effect in October last year. So Australia needs to give serious consideration to the circumstances and the possible dangers to which it leaves itself open as a result of a failure to move in this area. In Lateline, on 17 April last year, reporters Bronwen Reid and Maxine MCKew made a number of comments. In her introductory comments, after referring to some of the excesses of privacy invasion of individuals, Maxine MCKew said: Now, this trend so alarmed the Federal Coalition that in the lead-up to the 1996 election it promised a major extension of privacy legislation. _Twelve months on that promise has been broken. After furious lobbying from some sections of business, the Government agreed that any extension to the current legislation would be costly and unnecessary. It was a smack in the eye for Attorney-General, Daryl Williams, who'd supported change, and it outraged privacy campaigners. Now they've found a major ally in the European Union. The EU has issued an ultimatum to all countries, including Australia, that it will not trade with them if they do not have strong privacy laws. For many of our major companies, this could effectively become a trade embargo. In the same program, Bronwen Reid said: Companies wanting to trade in Europe's common market first have to show they can protect personal data. They must demonstrate that they can be trusted with the vast rivers of information on citizens so routinely collected, stored and traded. It sounds abstract, but the Europeans recognised that in the course of daily life citizens impart enormous amounts of personal information. That was spelt out then. Now, in this month of this year this legislation is coming here, legislation which leaves Australia and Australia's overseas trading and business interests seriously exposed. I have already referred to Privacy International. Simon Davies is head of that watchdog group. During that Lateline program, he said: This isn't a national issue at all. The market is a global market. What affects another country. So if, for example, my data is accumulated in, say, France, it and will find its way to the United States Australia. So this is an issue which affects citizens globally, and what we've sought for many years, and almost achieved, is a harmonious global set of rules. And all we're doing is calling on said: Australia to agree to that harmony. If we fail to do so, we need to know the about reasons for that. We need to know what the benefits motivation is behind it. I also refer to an knowledge', ... article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday, 17 December 1997. This was joint article by Tony Vinson, who is Emeritus Professor of Social Work at the University New South Wales and Director of Research at the Uniya Jesuit Social Justice Centre, Karl Langheinrich, who is a social work student. When they were dealing with quesis tions of surveillance standards, privacy and on as part of that article, they said: The onus should not be placed on individuals whose rights are infringed to defend them. Rather, it should be placed on those who violate the right to privacy to defend their actions. That is where governments have a responsibility, particularly national governments with their national responsibilities. They went further to say: . . . there must be sanctions for the breach standards and a confirmed regulator in the form a Privacy Commissioner to ensure the application of the standards. Because, obviously, without having such a responsibility with such a commissioner, there is no guarantee that those types of obligations on the part of the private sector would honoured. I know that one of my colleagues referred to Moira Scollay, the federal Privacy Comjust missioner. Ms Scollay addressed the National Medico-Legal Conference in Sydney February this year. I know that some of her claims were disputed, but I leave it to others to judge whether or not they are plausible. She told the conference: ... once current research mapping all 100,000 human genes is completed, there will be 'enonnous financial pressure'financial pressure; business pressureon the life insurance industry to discriminate on the information basis of people's genetic make-up. affects one country She said: can find its way They already do, .. or You see there is a difference between the all premiums charged for males and females based on their expected longevity. She also Genetic testing would raise issues within families who should be tested and who should be told the results, 'particularly if there are then financial or disincentives accruing as a result of that a There are matters of extreme importance, extreme community, cultural, social and of personal importance in the whole question of the explosion of modern technology which and make possible serious intrusion into the privacy considerations of individuals. There an urgent and growing requirement, an so absolute necessity, for governments, which are the only authorities with national responsibilities of the kind that should be brought to bear on questions like this, to respond to them. To just say that this is an area where self-regula,tion is sufficient, is simply not adequate. (Time expired)  on honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is a wise man and has been here for of the many years, so I do not wish to go through of his entire speech and talk about many of the subjects that he raised. But I make the point ' that it is awe-inspiring the number of times the Labor party has stood up in the last two years and said how the government is doing outrageous things too late or that the governbe ment is doing things that should have been done a long time ago, when for 13 years they had the opportunity to introduce legislation like this or, if the opinion of the member for Charlton can be believed, go much further in in introducing privacy legislation. It is just one of the litany of issues that were left to the Liberal and National parties to do in government that were ignored by the Labor Party for 13 years. Ones that leap to mind are the fact that we have increased pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings-a promise made by the Labor Party for 13 years and never achieved. We are the government that created the Natural Heritage Fund for fixing up the environmentsomething the Labor Party, supposedly the great environmental party, could not do in 13 years. We are the party that is doing major infrastructure projects like the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. I notice the opposition claiming to up the ante with respect to the Alice Springs to Darwin railway by saying they would spend $300 million on that instead of the $100 million that the federal government has promised. But, for 13 years, Bob Hawke and Paul Keating promised the railway, which was never achieved. We are the government that is cracking down on the trafficking in trust losses. We are the governavail ment that is amending the Copyright Act to try to ensure that we can achieve cheaper CD prices. Yet we have speeches such as that today, delivered in such a wise and clever fashion by the member for Chru:lton. However, it missed the fundamental point: if the Labor Party regarded these issues as so important, why did they spend 13 years doing absolutely nothing about them? Among the crystal clear messages delivered by the electorate in March 1996 was the public'S expectation of greater efficiency by government. The former Labor government demonstrated an unenviable ability to pour billions of dollars into programs which yielded minimal or negligible results. When these programs failed, Labor responded by inventing more hidden taxes, increasing public expenditure or putting the nation further into debt. On the other hand, the coalition government remains committed to ensuring that public resources are used efficiently and cost effectively. In achieving the public's expectations of accountability, the government has acknowledged that funding alone is not the sole criteria for better government. This government has heard the concerns of the public and recognised that, to ensure optimum utilisation of public resources, service delivery methods must be continually improved without compromising the expectations of the public. A feature of this performance evolution is the introduction of market discipline into the delivery of various Commonwealth services through competitive tendering and, where appropriate, the contracting of services. In achieving these higher standards and greater efficiency, the government recognises that it is essential that performance improvement be delivered without compromising the privacy of individuals. The protection of individual privacy is paramount. The coalition government recognises this and the Privacy Amendment Bill, which we are debating today, demonstrates that recognition. It is universally accepted that we are living in a more intrusive world. It is the voluntary price that we as individuals pay when we ourselves of the technology that is now available to us, which the member for Charlton touched on. The convenience of using automatic teller machines is to a certain extent tempered by the knowledge that all the details of the transaction-just to use one example-the time, the location, the withdrawal amount and the account balance, have become a matter of record. The passive sounding term 'browsing the web' belies the privacy intrusions that a web browser is potentially exposed to. Again, with the convenience of the Internet come inevitable intrusions on our daily lives. Ever since the 1950s when the United States government began entering individuals' data on to enormous mainframe computers there has been a public suspicion of the collection of personal information. There exists a substantial body of anecdotal evidence to suggest that these fears are not without foundation. In the United States, a Maryland banker abused his position on the state health commission by accessing a database of cancer patients which was then cross-referenced with his bank's database of loan customers. In cases where there was a positive match, the banker revoked the loans. In the United States, technology has clearly outpaced protective legislation. In Australia, striking a sensible balance between the social benefits of technological advancement and an individual's right to privacy has been the challenge of successive governments. It is a challenge that this government has accepted. The Privacy Act provides that government agencies in possession of personal information about individuals are legally required to protect that individual's privacy. This fundamental expectation is legally extended by this amending bill to include services delivered under a government contract. This bill also regulates privacy standards for the practice of subcontracting such services. The information privacy principles embodied in the Privacy Act require personal information to be collected solely for lawful purposes which are related to the functions and activities of the information collector. Under the act, a duty exists on the information collector to ensure the person providing the information is aware of the nature of the purposes for which the information is collected. This principle includes both the compulsory disclosure of iri.formation and information voluntarily disclosed. Subject to certain exceptions, such as law enforcement and the preservation of life, information collected under the scope of the Privacy Act may not be used for a purpose other than that for which it has been collected. Disclosure to another person, except with the consent of the individual concerned, is also protected under the provisions of this act. There are several important functions of the Privacy Act. Perhaps the key function is the requirement that agencies store personal information records securely from theft, loss or misuse, and the requirement that agencies are to provide details about the type of personal information they hold. Further, subject to the exemptions provided for by the Freedom of Information Act 1982, agencies are required to provide an individual with access to his or her personal information records and to make appropriate corrections for accuracy, relevance and completeness. This amending bill requires that these same fundamental rights are applied to the practices of contracttions ed service providers. One such effect is the role of the Privacy Commissioner in the monitoring and auditing compliance of the information privacy principles to contracted service providers. This monitoring and auditing role has cultivated a self-regulating role in publiosector agencies as to the obligations and requirements of the Privacy Act, effectively educating the public sector and the public alike as to rights under the act. The coalition government expects that this bill will have the same effect on contracted service providers. By applying the legislative principles of the Privacy Act directly to contracted service providers, this bill will encourage greater consumer confidence. Similarly, service providers will be in no doubt as to what is expected of them by both government and their clients. This bill provides that an individual consumer of these services has the right to lodge a complaint to the Privacy Commissioner regarding suspected breaches of the principles of the Privacy Act by a contracted service provider. Accordingly, the Privacy Commissioner has the legal capacity to investigate such complaints and assist in the conciliation process to reach a settlement where it has been established that a breach has occurred. In the event that a satisfactory conciliation or settlement cannot be reached, the Privacy Commissioner has the legislative capacity to make a binding determination. Options that are legislatively available to the Privacy Commissioner include the requirement of a formal apology by the contracted service provider to the consumer, a change in administrative and/or management practices, or payment of appropriate compensation for any damage that has resulted from the breach of privacy. This bill also makes the qualification that there are some services for which it is inappropriate to apply these amendments. It has become the practice of successive Commonwealth governments to fund community and volunteer organisations which provide their services to local communities. Although many of these funding programs are described as grants, there has been a trend for organisain receipt of such funding to enter into service delivery contracts. These service delivery contracts are to ensure that program expectations are clear and that proper financial and service accountability exists. Funding is also provided for the delivery of some services that have traditionally been delivered by the private, rather than the public, sector. This bill does not place additional obligations on organisations delivering services traditionally delivered by the private sector. Rather, this bill assures the continuare ation of existing protective measures. Contractors who provide excluded funded services under schedule 3 of the act do not come within the scope of this bill. Due to the continually evolving nature of these social programs and the time frames under which they operate, this bill allows for regulations to ensure that services are not inappropriately excluded by references in the schedule. addition to their binding contractual responsiprivacy bility, including their administration and conduct, this bill also provides service providers and their Commonwealth agencies remain accountable for the contracts they enter into. The government has ensured that outcies sourcing agencies will be informed of any complaints against their contractors and Privacy Commissioner will have the discretion to be able to recommend changes in contractthe ing practices in appropriate circumstances. Consequently, Commonwealth agencies will, as an essential aspect of entering into tracts for the delivery of services, need to ensure that prospective contracted service providers are aware of and able to obligations of the act. Existing contractors should be operating in accordance with accepted privacy principles. The extension the act should therefore require them to make few, if any, changes to current administrative practices. In the drafting of this legislation, the government also recognises that Commonbill wealth agencies are expected to provide assistance and support to contracted service providers in the development of appropriate systems and practices for the services under contract. In addition, the Office of the Privacy Commissioner will be able to provide service, advice and assistance to contracted service providers to facilitate that meeting of community expectations under the Privacy Act. Broadening the Privacy Act to make it applicable to contract service providers will not have any financial impact on the taxpayer. The contracting agency will responsibility for the acts and practices of the contracted service provider. However, these costs which the government would otherwise have borne if that function had not been contracted out. Similarly, any costs for contractors associated with the compliance of the privacy obligations of this bill may be taken into account when negotiating the contract price of the provision of the contracted service. Indeed, many of these costs may already be taken into account in current In contractual arrangements which include requirements in accordance with current government competitive tendering and that contracted contracting policy. This government remains committed to the principle that individuals are entitled to have access to personal information held by agenabout them and to have that information amended if it is established to be inaccurate. the . The existing mechanisms for implementing these fundamental principles are contained in Freedom of Information Act 1982. Accordingly, the government will complement this bill by introducing a bill to amend the conFreedom of Information Act to extend it to apply to requests by individuals for access to personal information under the control of meet their contracted service providers. The fundamental principles of this amending bill are complemented by several safety of net provisions. This bill takes into account that the contracting out of services, particularly information technology services, could, if not adequately controlled, lead to personal information being transferred offshore. This also recognises that an individual whose privacy is breached overseas may be left without a legal remedy from a contracted service provider who is beyond Australia's delivery of legal jurisdiction. Privacy protection is ensured by provisions of this bill which provides that any act performed outside Australia's legal jurisdiction by a contracted service provider in relation to personal information is deemed to have been committed in Australia for legal purposes. In extension of this principle, this bill also provides protection for affected individuals if a contracted service provider is not a resident retain a degree of of Australia. This bill also recognises situations where the service provider ceases its Australian based operations and breaches an individual's privacy rights. The breach by the service provider will be attributed to the contracted service provider resident in Australia or the appropriate Commonwealth agency responsible for the information. In such circumstances, an affected individual will have the legal right to receive compensation or other appropriate remedies under the Privacy Act. Individuals whose privacy has been compromised by a contractor in circumstances where the contracted service provider ceases to exist, becomes bankrupt, insolvent or has wound up are also protected under the Privacy Amendment Bill. In such instances, an affected individual has the right to complain to the Privacy Commissioner and to receive a remedy if appropriate. If a remedy, financial or otherwise, is appropriate, this bill provides that the relevant Commonwealth agency is to be substituted for the contracted service provider and is required to pay any compensation owing. This bill not only demonstrates this government's commitment to protecting individual privacy but also acknowledges that privacy legislation must continue its evolutionary cycle if it is to keep pace with technology. It is a challenge for government the expectation of the public. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr MARTYN EVANS
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: We are here this morning to note the passing of another Howard government promise from the core pile to the non-core pile. We are here to note the breaking, in eiJect, of some very clear election promises which the coalition put to the electorate prior to the last election in" which they indicated their strong support for privacy principles and in which they indicated their intention to ensure that privacy was regulated in the private sector in Australia. They were going to to ensure that Australia was very much a part of the international community in respect of privacy principles, privacy law and privacy obligations for the private sector. But, of course, as we see from the actions of the government following the election, and as we see from the very words of this bill itself, the government has chosen to move that promise from core to non-core. That promise, in the words of another infamous government in the " United States 20 or 30 years ago, is now inoperative and we have other policies which will be substituted in their place. Mr Deputy Speaker, this has become so commonplace that you may wonder why we have raised it specifically in respect of this bill. It is because privacy is very important. Privacy is so important that many of the governments around the world and international bodies who are responsible for views on these matters have taken particular steps to ensure that we are aware of their importance. Article 12 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights states: No one shall be subjected to arbitrary interference with his privacy, family, home or correspondence, nor to attacks upon his honour and reputation. Everyone has the right to the protection of the law against such interference or attacks. The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights includes a provision for privacy protection similar to the article in the universal declaration. The OECD has published substantial primary documents andguidelines for international privacy protection. They were set out as far back as 1981 and they talk principally about stored data but are relevant across the board. The Council of Europe has a convention on privacy protection which also dates back to the early 1980s and is binding on all the signatory countries. The EC has issued a privacy directive which will take effect in October this year. That is the one to which my remarks will be further directed and in which Australia now has significant interest. If that directive is enforced, Australia's trading practices will be at risk. We will run the risk of Australia being a non-conforming country with that directive, with significant consequences for companies here. The threats to privacy have changed dramatically in the last 10 or 20 years. Privacy has always been an issue in Australia and has always been an issue on an international basis. Several hundred years ago, the United States saw fit to enact the Fourth Amendment to its constitution, which guarantees the right of people to be secure in their property and in their person. That threat to privacy was very much in the minds of the framers of the American constitution when they enacted the Fourth Amendment and ensured that people were secure in their property and in their private lives. But that, of course, is not something which this government has chosen to take heed of. Privacy in the digital age is very much another matter. Digital technology, computer technology, not only allows us to find the proverbial needle in a hay stack; it allows us to find particular specified needles, and that is the part which is so very fundamentally different and which the government's response to privacy fails to address. To give an example: we all know how easy it is to find a phone number in a phone book if you happen to know the name of the person concerned. If you take the substantial phone directories of Sydney, published in several very thick volumes, it is very easy, given the name of a subscriber to the telephone system, to find their phone number because all of those names are listed alphabetically in the directory. However, if you wish to find the name of a person given only their phone number, it is almost impossible on a manual basis to go through the phone directories and seek out that name. That was an almost impossible task until very recently and it ensured that people's privacy was protectedif not by law, then certainly by the sheer physical impracticality of breaching their privacy because of the vast amounts of data involved. However, it is now possible on the Internet to simply enter a phone number on an Internet site and have the name and address of the subscriber instantly reported to you. That can take place even in the United States, where the number of subscribers is vastly higher. The power of reverse searching, given computerisation of data records, is enormous. It allows you to breach the privacy of the telephone subscriber almost instantaneously. Not only that, it will also show you the address of their house on a map which brought up on the screen and it will then give you street by street directions to find that house from wherever you might be located. So information technology has put into the hands of every citizen the power to breach the privacy of almost every other citizen. There are commercial advantages in this as well. The company Lexis-Nexis, which is a very substantial databa-e provider, has recentOnce ly started offering a database known as PTRAK. This provides for some 300 million residents in the United States not only a person's name, address and telephone number but also their social security number, birth date and the names and birth dates of other people living at the same address. This data can be incorporated to include real estate records with data on neighbouring properties, approximate household income, plane and boat ownership, motor vehicle records, voter registration records, any law suits in which they have been involved, any liens or judgments which are outstanding against their name, any past criminal records and any relevant credit information. All of that is available by simply entering the name of a person that you have chosen into the Lexis-Nexis P-TRAK database and out will come some or all of that information. That represents a massive breach of privacy made possible by technology and by the commercial interests which that technology responds to, and it is a situation which we must as a parliament address. It is a situation which Europe and the United States are struggling with at the moment. Europe has a very substantial legal response to that. The United States is still working through that legislation, as we are here, but when this government promises to address those issues and then withdraws that promise, I think we have a sufficiently different situation which warrants people being very concerned about the trend of this government's interests. Although I have highlighted the activities of the Lexis-Nexis P-TRAK database, there are many hundreds of other similar databases in use throughout the world, particularly in the United States, which provide that kind of information. Government itself often has very will be substantial databases of information which it now firids profitable to sell to the private sector so that data matching can take place. Sometimes that information is made available as a result of freedom of information requests-which are perfectly reasonable-but when that is combined with the opportunity for data matching with private sector records, we have an issue of very serious concern. that starts to extend to unauthorised access to government records, the situation becomes even far worse because governments then have access on databases to criminal information, electronic medical records, Medicare records, pharmacy records, a whole range of information on employees, life insurance data and marketing returns. All of that is available in digital form and, increasingly, it will be converted for profit to accessible form to those who are prepared and able to pay. If we look at the scale of this digital traffic in data, it becomes quite an incredible amount of information flowing now in digital form. Because this is often hidden, it is useful to aggregate the effect so that we can understand the enormity of its impact. For example, in 1994 there were some 776 billion e-mail messages in the United States alone-not data; simply e-mail, which is the equivalent of private telephone conversations or letters. By 1997, that had risen to 2.6 trillion e-mail messages, and by the year 2000 it is expected to be some 6.6 trillion messages in the DS alone. On a world scale it would be substantially greater. So the privacy issues raised by that are very substantial. We must address them or people will find that their privacy is at risk, even without their knowledge. The issue of the Internet raises a whole new spectre for people, because increasingly information is transmitted over the Internet. There is even the opportunity for children who are interested in Internet surfing, which is often the case, to divulge information which their parents would not wish divulged, such as telephone numbers, addresses and data about the family. All of that needs to be contained in a legal way or we will find that family privacy is significantly more at risk than we would tolerate as a society. One of the principal things which is before us at the moment in a commercial sense is the ED directive, which comes into effect in October 1998. The government, having originally promised to address the issue of the legal protection of private sector databases and private sector information, having reneged on that promise, has left Australia exposed in relation to the ED directive. This is a very powerful privacy directive. In a very serious way, it addresses the kinds of risks which we face as a society in the digital age. It requires a number of privacy principles to be observed by countries and by private sector organisations within ED countries. One of the most powerful principles is that the subject of a data record must give informed consent about the way in which that record is to be used. The ED directive ensures that individuals are aware of the impact of the use of their data records, they are aware of what will be done with them, and they are aware of the purpose for which they are being collected and manipulated. The ED protections are quite substantial. They address the kinds of issues which I have raised in this debate. In the absence of any effective regulation in this country, our businesses will find themselves not, as the government would have you believe, relieved of a burdensome obligation of red tape; rather, they will be SUbjected to lost business opportunities, because the ED will not deal with countries which do not have adequate privacy standards in place. Australia probably would have met those standards if the government had implemented its election promise. Because it has not, Australian business is at risk because of this government's failure to act in this very important area. New Zealand have acted. New Zealand have appropriate legal standards in place for the private sector, and they will be able to participate in ED trade. But Australia will find itself at risk of being out in the cold in a privacy sense if we do not have adequate legal standards to address these issues. Not only do we need a privacy regime in place in a legal context; we also have to make use of some of the technology which is appropriate to address privacy concerns. Although it is technology which in many ways has fundamentally undermined our ability to keep information private about ourselves, it also delivers a number of potential solutions to the privacy question. In an era where information technology and electronic commerce are very much in the public eye, the government has followed the opposition's role in having a spokesman on information technology. Senator Alston is the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. At a time when the information economy is before us and privacy is so critically important, the government must provide the lead to business and private citizens in using technology to ensure that privacy is maintained. I speak here particularly about cryptography, which, although it is an esoteric subject, has within its ambit the technological ability to not only deliver some very substantial protections for citizens' privacy but also underpin the whole information economy. Cryptography delivers-it keeps information secret as it passes from computer to computer or as it resides on computer databases and also has the potential to ensure that that information is checked for integrity, that the author can be validated, that the author can ensure that the recipient of that information has received it and that only the recipient has the ability to decode it. It also very clearly has the power to keep that information confidential, no matter who ends up having access to the computer system or to the computer records. Cryptography is a technology for the digital age, although it has been around for thousands of years. Our ability and our need to use cryptography have come together in the 1990s to form the foundation of an information economy, an information society, which not only allows electronic commerce to flourish but also ensures that the reasonable rights to privacy of its citizens are respected. The potential for electronic commerce to open up vast areas of fraud is also negated by the widespread use of encryption technology. There has been substantial debate in the United States about cryptography policy. Like the American administration, this government-and some previous governments of my own persuasion-has not understood-the value of cryptography in ensuring that electronic commerce, which we see growing around us in leaps and bounds, is protected in a very stable way. We have seen governments attempt to use the digital era and the way in which it allows governments to maintain electronic surveillance, but we have not seen governments quite so enthusiastic to embrace those aspects of information technology which will protect the privacy of its citizens and security of electronic commerce. To give an example, we recently approved in this parliament a bill to ensure that law enforcement agencies are able to make use of telephone tapping technology in a digital age. That is not objectionable in itself. We all know that law enforcement will sometimes require access to telephone conversations, and that this has become very difficult in the digital age. But the reality is-and figures from the United States bear this up-that, in 1996,2.2 million US telephone conversations were tapped by the government-that is legal tapping I assume; I do not know what took place on an illegal basis. Of those 2.2 million conversations, 1.7 million were deemed to be innocent by the law enforcement agencies involved. Digital telephone tapping has now made it very convenient, very easy, for governments to tap telephones and to mount electronic surveillance operations in ways that were very expensive and very inconvenient on a practical level for governments previously. This is becoming all too easy and all too possible for government. I understand why government is reticent about the options which cryptography offers, but it is because of these reasons that the public should demand that the government adopt and promote in society a reasonable policy, a strong policy, in relation to cryptography. At the moment, the United States and Australia both prohibit the export of strong encryption products. People can gain a licence, but it is not easy to do. These cryptography products are regulated by government in much the same way that munitions might be, because in some ways governments fear secrecy, fear privacy, almost as much as they fear munitions. Law enforcement has some very reasonable basis for" its requests for access, but we should not allow these to overshadow the vital importance of cryptography-and strong cryptography, at that-for citizens who are participating in the information age. If electronic commerce is to underpin Australia's economy in the next century, we have to ensure that private individuals and government are able to adopt strong cryptographic techniques or we will find that many more the criminal opportunities are opened up than law enforcement is able to attack through its access to electronic communication. Many of the crimes of the next century will be electronic crimes. We will find ourselves in a situation where banks are under threat from virtual robberis rather than physical armed robberies. It will become much easier to steal from financial institutions and from those who put credit card information and other financial data through the electronic format than it will be to steal from them in a physical way. Strong cryptography will protect us from some of these potential hazards. The situation is that our national security could well be more threatened by our failure to adopt strong cryptography than by our insistence on suppressing that technology. Terrorists might well find it more practical to undermine the telephone system of a nation, to undermine the electricity distribution system of a nation, to undermine the ability of a nation to respond to attacks to national security, by undermining the very technological basis of that society itself. Unless government agencies, utility companies and substantial private sector corporations are encouraged and allowed to adopt strong cryptography, they may well find themselves under threat from those who would break the law, from those who would undermine democratic societies through terrorists acts-not the other way around. I suspect that our attitudes will have to change very substantially. This is an issue for government. We are now in a digital era and government must act accordingly. I support the second reading amendment because it addresses the very real failure of this government to ensure the privacy and security of its citizens in the information age.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: PAYMENT SYSTEMS AND NETTING
text: I propose to close the debate on the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998 and, in doing so, I would like to thank those members who contributed to it: the member for Banks (Mr Melham), the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), the member for Blaxland (Mr Hatton), the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne), the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) and, lastly, the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans). To some extent it has been an interesting debate, and it is obvious that members of this House have a keen interest, as does the community, in the subject of privacy protection. But to a large degree the debate has been irrelevant to the bill. The reason it is irrelevant to the bill is that most of the speakers, particularly from the opposition, have been addressing the second reading amendment moved by the member for Banks which does not address the bill but addresses what the bill does not do. This is, as I said, interesting, but it is not particularly helpful in sidering the bill. In fact, I think only about two issues were raised in relation to the subject matter of the bill itself. Let me sayar once that the government oppose the amending motion of the member for Banks and we propose to vote against it. I also want to comment again on the manner in which the opposition deals with bills in this House, and in particular bills in my portfolio. We have, yet again, the member for Banks coming in, unprepared to move amendments to the bill but prepared to foreshadow that the shadow minister in the Senate will move amendments. This is a continuing and constant insult to the House of Repre--nta tives. The member for Banks must accept responsibility for it, although the ultimate responsibility rests with the shadow AttomeyGeneral, Senator Bolkus. Senator Bolkus must be just about the laziest shadow minister that there ever has been. He i" never prepared to state what the opposition position is on a bill. He is never prepared to allow amendments to be considered in this House. We do not even know until the very last minute what amendments Senator Bolkus proposes to portfolio bills in the Senate. I think the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) really ought to take a long hard look at the position of his shadow Attorney-General and just ask, 'Is he doing anything?' He is certainly not assisting the member for Banks, as his representative, to do his proper job in this House. I repeat: it is a continuing insult to the House of Representatives that it is treated in this way by the opposition. The government is acting on privacy protection in the private sector as a whole. On 20 February, the Privacy Commissioner and I launched national principles for the fair handling of personal information. These principles were developed by the Privacy Commissioner through a process of intensive consultation with business, privacy, consumer and government representatives. The Privacy Commissioner will now continue her consultations to assist business to implement the principles and to work out means by which they may be enforced. In this way, the government believes that privacy protection con- in the private sector can be ensured without imposing heavy-handed regulation on business. I can add in this context that the privacy principles received the support of some 14 peak body organisations at the time of their release. Those bodies were largely involved in the consultations resulting in their developprinciples ment and they will be involved in the consultations relating to the development of implementation mechanisms. The government took the approach of seeking a self-regulatory regime for privacy protection in the private sector following extensive consultations'with the private sector. The member for Banks has mentioned the release of the discussion paper in September. This resulted in a significant number of formal submissions, formal representations, and the submissions revealed concern about the cost implications for business of a heavyhanded regulatory approach. The government was committed in its election policy and continues to be committed to reducing the regulatory burden on business and particularly on small business. The government firmly believes that privacy protection can in fact be achieved in the private sector without imposing unnecessary legislative burdens on business. A number of speakers have referred to the European Union directive and have raised a spectre of alleged adverse trading consequences for business in Australia if that directi ve is not complied with. The government has had a number of discussions with European Commission officials about the directive. Although the directive refers to limitations on transfers of personal information to countries that do not have 'adequate levels of policy protection', it is unclear what the precise, practical impact of the directive will be. The commission is at this stage still developing an approach to assessing adequacy. It should be noted that the EU directive contains a number of exceptions which will allow transfers of data to non-EU countries in certain circumstances, even if they are not considered to have adequate levels of privacy protection. In addition, an EUmember country may authorise a transfer or set of transfers of personal information to a non-EU country that does not have an adequate level of privacy protection where there are adequate privacy safeguards in place under appropriate contractual clauses. The government believes that the national on fair handling of personal information which were released by the Privacy Commissioner on 20 February provide a good basis for Australian businesses which handle personal information to develop practices to ensure that the privacy of individuals is protected. The government is discussing the Privacy Commissioner's principles with EU officials in the course of its discussions about the EU directive. The government will of course continue to monitor the directive both domestically and internationally. It has been suggested by the member for Banks that the bill sets up a regime inconsistent with the principles laid down by the High Court in its decision in the Brandy case. This is incorrect and, regrettably, demonstrates a lack of understanding on the part of the member for Banks of the Brandy decision and of the mechanisms which would apply under this bill. The impact of the Brandy decision has been taken into account in the construction of the determination and enforcement regime. The opposition has also suggested that the privacy of unemployed persons is not respected by the government. I draw it to the attention of the opposition-and in particular the member for Batman-that this bill will apply to providers contracted by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs under the new employment services market. The member for Banks may in fact recall that it was a committee of which he was the chairman and I was a member when the ESRA scheme was introduced which saw that privacy principles were respected and the legislation was improved by the committee's determination. Unlike the then government, this government has already taken those principles into account. Since 1 January 1989 when it came into operation, the Privacy Act has required government agencies that hold information about individuals to deal with that information in accordance with a specific set of private standards. It has also provided a specific regime for dealing with breaches of those standards and monitoring compliance generally. The government is committed to ensuring that where its agencies contract for the delivery of services those same specific standards and that same compliance regime continue to apply. That is the purpose of the amendments proposed in the bill: to preserve the same protection that the personal information had when the government performed the service. The act will apply only to those organisations who choose to contract with government to provide services to government. This is very different from imposing privacy legislation on the private sector as a whole. The question of privacy laws for the private sector generally is a separate issue which should not be used by the opposition to delay passage of the Pri vacy Amendment Bill. The government knows that individual Australians want the parliament to deal with this legislation expeditiously, and the government expects the opposition to stop playing obstructive games with this important legislation. One matter I do want to mention specifically is the one raised at the end of his speech by the member for Bonython-the subject of encryption, or cryptography. The government is aware of and is acting in relation to cryptography. There has been established for some time a committee of the OECD in which Australia participates. In fact, a senior officer MCDougall, G. R. of my department chairs the committee. It has developed some principles which ensure the meeting of different objectives while using encryption. The member for Bonython expressly mentioned law enforcement. You could add to that security and intelligence. One of the principles expressly deals with that subject. The government has adopted as broad policy objectives the achievement of the principles determined by the OECD as a result of the work of the committee. on which the deputy secretary of my department participates. So the member for Bonython can rest assured that the government is well aware of the issue and is acting on it. I repeat that the government will oppose the second reading amendment moved by the member for Banks and supports the bill as is.
