Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I move: That this House censures the Prime Minister: (1) for breaching Ministerial standards in relation to (a) his own Guidelines on Ministerial Conduct and (b) the House of Representatives Register of Members' Interests in that: (i) he failed to disclose his directorship of the Menzies Research Centre Limited, which he held for the first seven months of his Prime Ministership; and (ii) he placed himself in a position of conflict of interest between his public duty and his directorship of that company; (2) for presiding over a Cabinet meeting which agreed to $400,000 worth of grants to Menzies Research Centre Limited, as well as agreeing to tax deductibility for donations to the company, whilst he was a director of the company in a clear conflict of public duty and private interest; (3) for his weak and secretive attempt to avoid both public scrutiny of his directorship and the need to reveal his breach to former Ministerial colleagues he had forced to resign for similar breaches of his Guidelines on Ministerial Conduct; and (4) for his latest contortions and re-definition of the meaning of his own guidelines to suit his political needs, again doing so in a manner which has no regard to the standing of tl:ose guidelines, or to their consistent application, credibility or transparency. We have here the guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility. This document has about the same amount of relevance now to Australian political debate as do the Dead Sea scrolls. This is a useful piece of archaeology; it is a useful piece of archaeology which lends us an understanding of what time was once like in this country when governments exercised some degree of restraint in relation to themselves and some level of public accountability. Like the Dead Sea scrolls, it is a document full of spirit which will enable archaeologists and historians to discern the attitudes of various sects at the time and to speculate interestedly on whether or not they have any relevance to a discussion of the head of state of the land or are in any way responsible for the politics of the time. Like the Dead Sea scrolls, these things have become things of the spirit rather than things of actuality and of practical relevance to the considerations of the parliament today-that is, to everybody except those on this side of the House. For us this is a living document. For us this is a set of standards which our ministers adhered to. For us this is a set of standards against which we tested ourselves. For us this is basically what is expected of a standard of honour in this place for members of governments and members of parliaments. Without it, the very substantial reputation for honesty that federal politics in this nation exercises around the globe for an almost unique honesty and integrity goes down the tube. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has set an exercise in rendering black white when it comes to dealing with these standards of ministerial conduct, both in relation to Senator Parer and in relation to himself. As he redefines and finds himself trapped, he redefines again; he finds himself trapped, and redefines himself again. For example, he has said in the course of his remarks here today that, because he exercised no pecuniary interest in this, it actually has no meaning as far as he is concerned. I will get on to how much he obviously actually believes that, by his practical actions, a little later. . Suffice to say at this point, as I took that statement of Senator Hill and as I indicated in my question, this is a statement of registrable interests. Registrable interests have, for the Prime Minister, included everything from biros to membership of Rotary clubs. He has understood thoroughly, he has firmly fixed in his own mind, that the standard requires registrable interests, not just simply a pecuniin ary interest. He was asking of us last week, 'Ignore everything in my guidelines in relation to Senator Parer. What you in the Labor Party have to do is to demonstrate that he did that action in connection with this interest and as a result produced a conflict of interest.' So low is the moral sensibility now on that side of the House that they think that in those circumstances what you are actually discussing-particularly when it comes to a matter in which you are actually earning something from it-is a conflict of interest. In actual legal terms what you are discussing there is not a conflict of interest-perceived, real or actual. You are discussing corruption. So conflict of interest propositions went right the window as far as the Prime Minister was concerned. But, having established that test last week, that test was run across him on this matter here today. And on this matter we can identify two clear-cut breaches: first, a requirement for declaration was breached-that is a declaration to all of us-and, second, a requirement for declaration to the cabinet and for absenting yourself from a discussion that is directly relevant to matters of interest that you entertain was also breached. So we have had those two breaches even under his own redefined standards. What do we find today? We find it finally reduced to the point: 'Unless you can prove that I put a bit of dough in my back kick, nothing matters, absolutely nothing else matters.' You can bring this very lengthy guideline down to one sentence: 'Ministers may not make decisions that put dough in their back kicks.' End of story. That is the end of it. Mr Crean-But they worry about it only when they're caught.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: And then, as the honourable member for Hotham says, only when they're caught. Mr Crean-And that's corruption.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The honourable member for Hotham will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The Prime Minister said his little episode in question time that what the opposition should be concerned about in question time is a whole range of issues that he says are of relevance to the Australian people. And so they are. And, if you ask me to evaluate this thing in the great scheme of life as to what is relevant to the average Australian, what puts bread on the table is more relevant in the daily life of the average Australian than the enforcement of ministerial codes of conduct. What is relevant to the average Australian is the question of the removal-as was pointed out by us in question time yesterday-of a whole range of entitlements, in clear breach of election promises by the Prime Minister. That is of far more relevance to the elderly out Australian than questions of breaches of the code of conduct. The destruction of educational opportunity for a range of young people in relation to university is far more relevant to them than a ministerial code of conduct. The proposition of the privatisation of Telstra and the consequent likely disbenefits that are going to flow to a whole range of Australians, particularly those in the bush, is far more relevant than the ministerial code of conduct. If the Prime Minister wants us to make a statement about that fact, we will. We are cheerful to own up to the fact that in our judgment-and no doubt in the judgment of the people of Australia-those things are far more relevant to them. And we have therefore been providing you with an opportunity to answer for yourselves on all those matters in question times and in MPls over the last couple of weeks. But there is one task that is uniquely performed in this chamber that cannot be performed by the average Australian, cannot be performed by somebody whose devotion of their daily attention is to their struggle for survival, the needs of their families and the jobs that they do. They are not in this place. They elect us to this place. They expect us to establish a set of standards that are broadly publicly acceptable, they expect us to adhere to them and they expect us at the end of the day to hold governments and each other accountable as far as those standards are concerned. Indeed, when the Prime Minister was gallivanting around the Old Parliament House, as I do well recollect, at the time when he discovered that the then minister for education I think he was, Mr Dawkins, had in fact failed to declare that his mother was a shareholder in BHP, what did we get from the Prime Minister? Did he ask for the establishment of the fact of the minister of the day reaching into the pockets of BHP and putting into his own pocket as the standard? Did he want us down at that bottom line? No, he was prepared to go on with arguments about the appearance of that situation. He had very high standards then he did. He had very high standards which he was pleased to announce to the rest of the Australian people would be the standards that he would apply when he came into this place. And what havewe seen from this Prime Minister since then? Just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to the elderly of this nation as far as dental health is concerned, just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to the people of this nation as far as their access to nursing homes is concerned, just as he had weaseled out as far as the access of the unemployed people of this nation to decent support when it comes to labour market programs is concerned, just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to the young people of this country in relation to HECS, university places and a whole range of other activities, just as he has weaseled out on his promises on tax-as we see his massive increases in superannuation tax arrangements proceeding though here-just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to maintain spending as far as the environment is concerned, just as he has weaseled out of just about everything that Australians do regard as relevant to them in their daily lives, so he has weaseled out of this set of commitments. And there is only one place where he can be held accountable as far as that is concerned. I have here a question that the Prime Minister asked in relation to former Senator Richardson. He dragged Senator Richardson's political wraith around him in his defence of himself on the Channel 9 show the other night. I never thought I would live to see the day when Richo was called to defend the reputation of a member of the government when I think of the hard things the Prime Minister had to say about Richo from time to time in this place and in other places. I want people to reflect upon this question that he asked the Prime Minister of the day: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's claim that it was common knowledge that Senator Richardson was a director of 2HD . . . I repeat: 'common knowledge that Senator Richardson was a director of 2HD.' What was the first answer to a question he gave here in this place? 'Oh, it was common knowledge, Mr Speaker. I was leader of the Liberal Party. As far as everybody in this country was concerned, of course that would find them immediately identifying the fact that I was a director of the Menzies Foundation.' That was a marvellous defence as far as he was concerned. His question continued: . . . when he participated in broadcasting discussions and decisions of the Cabinet. Was this statement by the Prime Minister not just an expression of personal opinion, or has the Prime Minister been personally assured by all Ministers present at the Cabinet discussions that they knew of Senator Richardson's directorship? Well, Prime Minister, were you assured by all your ministers at the time that they knew about your directorship of your particular company on this occasion, and a declaration of it? He went on: Is it not, therefore, the case that unless the ment is satisfactorily assured that Senator Richardson either disclosed his interest as a director radio station whenever he participated in Cabinet discussions or decisions on broadcasting mattersand not jut those relating to licence fees, but all broadcasting matters--or, alternatively, absented himself from those discussions, he must, in accordance with accepted Cabinet practice, resign from the Ministry and in default you ought to remove him? That was the standard of the Prime Minister at the time. What is the difference between the Prime Minister's situation and Senator Richardson's? Senator Richardson sat in that cabinet for six days as a director of 2HD. The Prime Minister sat in it for six months. There is no evidence in that six days that there was any broadcasting matter before cabinet. There is every evidence, and the Prime Minister has effectively fessed up to it, that there was a matter precisely concerning the Menzies Foundation put before the cabinet during the Prime Minister's consideration of those concerns. Furthermore, not only was there evidence of that but there is the evidence that the way in which he conducted himself around it was a representation of a pattern of deliberate deceit, and I will get on to that in a minute. Let me finish with the Graham Richardson example, because there was a conclusion to the Graham Richardson example. It did not simply conclude with Graham Richardson-or me, as Leader of the House, or the then Prime Minister-standing up and defending himself and just flicking it off by saying, 'These are trivial matters; it doesn't matter. I didn't get any pecuniary interest. I didn't benefit this particular company from any decision I took. It wasn't a public company.' You never got that as a conclusion from Senator Richardson. You got that as a conclusion from the current Prime Minister. What did you get from Senator Richardson? He stood up in the Senate and made a substantial and clear-cut apology to the parliament for having, in his mind, inadvertently misled them. There was an apology to the parliament and an apology to the Prime Minister. What we get from this Prime Minister, who can never admit he is wrong Parliaand will destroy every standard that governs parliamentary activities, every rule that govof the erns parliamentary activities, is that he can breach them; the rule is wrong, he is not wrong. He alone, uniquely, exercises the authority to redefine the rules every time he stands on his feet. Today, in question time, we had those rules redefined, I would suggest, at least four or five times as he retreated from or failed to answer every question that was put to him. Let me turn to another aspect of this matter, in case people think it is a matter of some trivia or of no importance for us to consider. Consider what he was doing at the time. The Prime Minister, of course, had the lowered eyebrows, the sadness on his face, as he punted one minister after another during that period of time, as he clothed himself in the rock-ribbed armour of self-righteousness and the significance of these rules that he put down that he is prepared to uniquely claim. He got up and speculated for the people as to how he had so frequently had cause to remark to his ministers that they must observe these laws to the letter, even if it was just a bit inadvertent, even if it was trivial. Remember that he punted poor old Senator Short, one of his flatmates, for trivia. What a lousy cook he must have been and what a terrific one Senator Parer must be! An indication of a career afterlife when he has finally dealt with it. What did the Prime Minister say about them during that period of time? Well, they had to go. But what was he doing at that point in time? Remember, he has had the cabinet meet on his Menzies Foundation and make a determination. That does not provoke anything from him at all. He has rung me. He has said, 'Look, I intend to give a hundred grand to the Menzies Foundation and 1'm going to give to_ you a hundred grand for the Evatt Foundation.' This was supposed to be one of his defences here-the fact that he rang me. I can tell you this, Prime Minister: I was perfectly cheerful to see resources given to the Menzies Foundation, I was perfectly cheerful to see them given to the Evatt Foundation, but you never told me you were a director of it. And you are going to be taking that to the cabinet-well, really! First, he attempted to clothe himself in the wraith of Senator Richardson and then he attempted to clothe himself in my all-too-real presence. On both occasions, he did not manage to drag down what he desperately hoped for himself-that body over himself in the trenches so that none of the flak may hit him. We have both jumped up and moved away as far as that is concerned. How must his colleagues feel? How must those colleagues who were humiliated by him feel? Those colleagues who obviously did not fully comprehend all the aspects of detail as far as these considerations were concernedhow must they feel about it? How must they feel about a Prime Minister who clearly understands the full range of things which he must declare and then, above all, how do they feel about a Prime Minister who is dragged kicking and screaming into this place to explain these matters because of exposure, because, even if inadvertently, he had not actually seen what was expected of him or remembered what was expected of him? He certainly did recognise it ultimately. One would have thought that what would have flowed from that was a correction when that revelation came to him, but there was none. And why? Obviously because he knew that, if he put this into the register of interests the time when we were considering these other matters, we would have pointed it out and he would have suffered a massive degree of embarrassment. What sort of Prime Minister is that? I would say it is a Prime Minister who is weak and sneaky. That is how I would describe a Prime Minister of that demeanour: weak and sneaky. He now seeks to defend himself-and I notice the bloke who is going to speak next, the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), also seeks to do that-saying that somehow or other you do not actually have to declare any of these things in business dealings related to your job if you happen to be leader. I am afraid that you do have to make those declarations. That is part of your job and your duty. The fact that you happen to be leader and that that automatically puts you onto a public company or a company of any description has to be declared. That has to be in here. That has to be there so that it can be seen because decisions are taken by governments that benefit those particular companies from time to time. If I were a director of the Evatt Foundation, I would have to declare it and you would expect that I would have to declare it. If I were a director of anything, there would be an expectation that it would be declared in this place because the rules-this piece of archaeology that is left for us to use--demand it of you. This Prime Minister is deserving of censure. This Prime Minister has scuttled out from this, but he will not scuttle out from the judgment of the people of this country on this matter. (Time expired) Mr Crean-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak, Mr Speaker.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: This motion deserves to be thrown out and to be dismissed for the triviality that it is. It says a lot about the opposition that they would even have the hide, the impertinence, the gall to move such a motion today. It just shows you what muckrakers they are. You can pat him on the back as many times as you like, Simon. But the read-out in the Australian at community will be that, when there is a major waterfront dispute going on and when you have major problems within your own side because one of your own front benchers is about to launch a book attacking his own leader, people will understand that this is just an old tactic. How many times have you seen a political party that has its own internal problems struggle to find an attack on the government, their opponents, as a political distraction. It is telling indeed: here we are in the second or third burst of industrial strike action by the wharfies, yet the Labor Party is unable to ask one question on an issue which really is important and of substance. I have seen many weak, pathetic, irrelevant performances in my time, but that one certainly takes the cake. To hear the Labor Party talking to us about standards: what ajoke! It is April Fools' Day and the fools are out in full strength. It was 14 years ago that Mal Colston was fiddling the books and who were the ministers in charge of covering up Mal Colston? None other than Kim Beazley, now Leader of the Opposition, then minister in the Hawke government. Who was the other part of the Mal Colston defence team? It was none other than the deputy leader, Gareth Evans, the then Attorney-General. What did these great upholders of standards do? They were advised to send the Colston matter to the police; they buried it and kept paying him for years and years. And you have the impertinence to move a motion in this House today about standards. No-one has done more to maintain standards in this parliament than the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). No-one has been prepared, more often, more regularly, more courageously to stand up and talk about standards and to maintain and enforce standards. You blokes would not know a standard if you fell over one. No-one has done more to enforce standards and to apply a common sense approach to the whole issue of standards. A common sense approach is something which you would have a lot of trouble understanding. This motion today is just a distraction. It a triviality in the extreme coming from an opposition that basically have absolutely nothing to say about the significant issues. They have just drummed this one up as a political distraction. The incredible impertinence and gall of these people! The Prime Minister today revealed that a decision was made to provide some dollars-less money than most wharfies earn, or a lot of them earn. It is not exactly big money we are talking about here-$100,OOO. I can show you wharfies earning more than that on the Australian waterfront, thanks to the Labor Party. This is all about the fact that when you become the leader of the Liberal Party you also become a director, a member of the Menzies Foundation. Mr Crean-Read the articles.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I have the articles. I will read some of the articles to you. Mr Crean-Well, read that one.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The honourable member for Hotham will remain silent if he wishes to make his contribution in this place.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: There are two think-tanks, policy groups associated with the two major political parties. The Labor Party have the Evatt Foundation. They have named theirs after one of their greats, old Doc Evatt, and we have named ours after the greatest parliamentarian Australia has known, Robert Menzies-the Menzies Foundation. Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: For many years, when Labor was in government, the Labor Party looked after the Evatt Foundation. The Labor Party also looked after the unions-talk about conflict of interest. Thank you for reminding me about that. For many years, the Labor Party looked after the Evatt Foundation. When the Liberal Party came in, the Prime Minister said that there ought to be fair and equal treatment between the two parties and that each of them ought to have $100,OOO-which was a cutback for the Evatt Foundation, which was fair enough-and that there should be tax deductibility. When the Prime Minister became leader of the Liberal Party, he automatiis cally took on the role of being involved in the Menzies Foundation. As the leader of a political party, you get involved in lots of aspects of your organisation. You get involved in the think-tanks, the advisory committees, the executive of the party, and you get involved because you are the leader and you are expected to be involved in each and every part of the organisation. Part and parcel of being a senior member of a political party in this country is that you are involved in your party. Like it or not, we have a party system. Mr Dondas-A strong party system.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: And on our side we have a very strong party system, arid it is part of the success of our side of politics that we work the party system and we make sure that we have a strong and viable party system. The accusation against the Prime Minister essentially is that he is a member of the Liberal Party. That is their real complaint. What was revealed today was that when we got in we said that we wanted f-ir treatment for both sides. Before or at the tIme that the cabinet made the decision, the Prime .Minister rang up the Leader of the Oppositi?n and said, 'Kim, your side has been creammg off the top very nicely over the years. Now that we have a change in government and we are controlling things, we will treat both sides equally and fairly. What do you say about that?' What was his answer? His answer came back, 'That is a good idea. Thank you very much.' Now Mr Beazley says, 'That's no answer because you didn't tell me that you were a director.' So what! The accusation is that the Prime Minister is not associated with that Liberal Party when he rings up to have a discussion about funding for the Evatt Foundation and the Menzies Foundation. What a ridiculous, stupid, juvenile, pathetic claim. to make. It is like saying, 'Oh, I spoke to Kim Beazley about whether or not there should be funding for the Evatt Foundation, but of course I assumed that this was a matter beyond his interest because, as leader of the Labor Party, his interest in the Evatt Foundation was totally irrelevant.' It makes no sense. Kim Beazley's interest in the Evatt Foundation is exactly the same as the interest in the Menzies Foundation that is held by the Prime Minister. As leader of the Labor Party, Mr Beazley is interested in what happens in the Evatt Foundation; Mr Howard as leader of the Liberal Party is interested in the circumstances and the arrangements for the Menzies Foundation. Quite frankly, that is all there is to it. I think I should just put my papers down and go and have a cup of tea and leave you lot to carry on. Mr Crean-Do it.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I warn the honourable member for Hotham!

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Look at the Menzies Foundation-look at the things that it is not. Members of the Labor Party say that it is a public company like BHP or Coles Myer-they are trying to suggest that this is a breach of the rules which refer to public companies. This is not a public company as everybody else understands a public company. Why? Because with a public company like Telstra you can buy and sell shares. Can you buy and sell shares in the Menzies Foundation? No, you cannot, because it is not a for-profit or trading corporation. It is a think-tank, for heaven's sake! It is not BHP. He is not trading in BHP shares here, Simon. This is a think-tank. This is a policy group that has nothing to do with any commercial operation. The first thing to say about the Menzies Foundation is that it is not a public company. That is the end of your case, Your case just disappeared. You do not have a case. There is no case. It is not a public company. It is not a for-profit company. There are no shares traded. What was the Prime Minister's involvement in it? Quite frankly, he didn't have much of an involvement in it. He never went to a meeting, unlike Richo-Senator Richardson, the former minister for communications-who attended at least a couple of the six meetings of his company. He was actively involved in the commercial trading operations of a radio station. That is a very different proposition to the circumstances of a policy think-tank. Is there any conflict of interest? Of course there is not. How could there be any conflict of interest? Firstly, it is not a trading organisation but, even more comprehensively, the fact is that the PM did not have any interest in it anyway. Is this a matter of great importance? Is this a matter which should displace the matter of public importance? Is this a matter which is a hanging offence? Of course it is not. This is ridiculous. Even Richo, the great Sydney radio commentator-and Labor Party ex-minister-says: Now, I'll disagree with the Labo- Party here. I.do not believe you should have to resign for breaching your own Code of Conduct. The breach is a minor one. And as far as I'm concerned, the Labor Party is wrong to suggest that you should resign. Simon, your mate, your mentor, your great numbers man is telling you that it is a joke to be moving this. This is pathetic. Even Richo, a paid-up, fully operational member of the Labor Party is telling you that it is ridiculous that you should even raise the issue. Have we had these issues raised before? As a matter of fact, we have. For example, in October 1983 there was some issue about ministers not dotting their i' s and crossing their t's-and this was nine out of 27 ministers. What did Bob Hawke say about that? He said: . These mistakes were obviously made in good faith. I regret that they were made, but they were made in good faith. It will be clear from the amendments that they do not include anything that could lead to a potential conflict of interest. . In the present we have Richo, a voice from - he p-st, telling us today that there is nothing m thIS; and 15 years ago Bob Hawke was telling us that this whole thing is trivial in the extreme. What is the Prime Minister's crime? His crime is that he is the leader of the Liberal Party. They are moving a censure motion against the Prime Minister because he happens to be the bloke who runs the Liberal Party. You think it is a matter of censure. We might as well censure the Labor Party because Kim Beazley is the leader of the Labor Party. We. - ay as well have a debate about party POhtICS. We may as well have a debate to reveal it entirely. This is trivial in the extreme, so what is it really all about? The fact is, it is all about the Labor Party's problems. That is what it is about. This is about the failure of the Labor Party to start developing real policies. . A very interesting story which has been building up in the last few days is the story of the writings of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). He is the Young Turk- I know about this because-sadly, I have to say-I was there for the whole time our side was in opposition. I know what happens-it takes a while for you to realise that you have lost the election and then, when you lose the second election, you realise that you have to change your approach. These are the words of the member for Werriwa: History tells us that wheneve- federal Labor has lo-t heavi-y at the polls it has had to fundamentally remvent Itself to regain office . . . the cause of Labor is never weaker than when the party has nothing more progressive to offer the electorate than a revival of ideas long past. Dinosaurs they are, Mr Speaker. How relevant it would have been if he had said, 'When the party turns to muckraking as an alternative to policy development, then as a party, we, the Labor Party, are going nowhere.' Paul Kelly, in. his piece this morning in the Australian, Said: Mark Latham, a Gough Whitlam protege, has just smashed the myth of contemporary Labor politics. In a 390-page book that could be called a heavy read, Latham dares the ALP to forget the politics of nostalgia and follow Bill ClintonI do not know whether that is such a good ideaand Tony Blair to invent a new position. Mr Speaker, they do not have a new position. What they have are fractures within their own side which are opening up, so a weak leader who has got no case comes into mount a case of triviality in the extreme-the most trivial I have ever heard. It reflects on you, Leader of the Opposition. Yo- .are a weak leader; you have no policy posltlOn; you cannot put the member for Werriwa back in his box; you are unable to provide any leadership; and you cannot address the issues like the waterfront because the waterfront unions have got you tied hand and foot to their policy position. Ultimately, this is a reflection of a weak Labor Party, unable to find a position to adopt and unable to develop policies. In the end, we have the muckraker-the member for Hothambasically running the Labor Party, being attacked by the member for Werriwa and with a failing Leader of the Opposition unable to give any direction to their side. We reject it, and I look forward to the contribution from the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The code of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is rotten to the core, and now it has engulfed him. The Prime Minister has now breached his own code of conduct. He has been deceitful with the Australian public in failing to disclose the directorship not only as his code requires but as the members' register of interests in this parliament requires. He, like Senator Parer, has been deceitful with the Australian public in trying to hide what they knew should have been declared. In Senator Parer's case, it is a significant breach because he failed to disclose that, as coal minister, had $2 million worth of shares in a coal mine. The Prime Minister was director of a company that he presided over and that benefited, in a cabinet meeting of which he was chair, to the tune of not $100,000 but now $400,000-benefited to the extent to which it has been extended tax deductIbility for tax donations to it. But was there any declaration of that by the Prime Minister? Was there any declaration in the cabinet? The Prime Minister has been asked that question time and time again today, and he has refused to answer it. He was specifically asked: did he declare his interest; did he absent himself from the meeting? The fact that he will not answer that question 'Yes and yes' means, I am afraid, that he did not. That is where the opposition is saying the conflict of interest has occurred. be seen. He has failed to declare in the parliament his interest, according to his own code. There has been a direct benefit to the company of which he was still a director. And what have we got? We have now got him invoking Richo as his defence-the man that he maligned because he said, 'Do whatever it takes.' Now the Prime Minister is doing whatever it takes to save his motley hide. John Winston Howard-Winston the weasel; that is what he isis a person incapable of coming into this place and fessing up; a person who was given the opportunity this morning to come into the parliament and squibbed it; a person who sat down at every question he was asked, bar one, today, after he went to some lengthy answer that had been prepared for him by his lawyers. But let us go to that question of the company. The Leader of the House (Mr Reith) has made great play of this-that it was not a company that traded in shares. It does not matter. In the case of Commonwealth Bank of Australia v. Friedrich, tnis is what the court said: There is nothing in company law to suggest the standard expected of a part-time non-executive director of a company not for profit is different from the standard expected of any other director of a profit-making company. In other words, the court said that the Prime he Minister has not got a defence, and that is what the Leader of the House spent five minutes defending him on today. He is ruled out by the court. Don't come in here and quote the Macquarie Dictionary when you have the Federal Court of Australia against you. This is how stupid the Prime Minister is, Mr Speaker. He thinks he can weasel his way out of what he has got himself into by relying on the dictionary definition, when he has his code against him, he has the declaration of registrable interests against him, and he has the Federal Court of Australia against him. Yet he says, 'I didn't know nothing.' This is the Prime Minister of Australia-dumb struck when confronted with irrefutable evidence. He says, 'I didn't know nothing.' What a brave man this wimp of a Prime Minister is. Where is he today? Defending himself? He is nowhere to John Winston Howard, the Prime Minister of this country, was appointed a director to the Menzies Foundation on 29 September 1995. He was appointed a director five months before he became Prime Minister. He signed the articles of association. His signature is here. On page 23 of the articles, John Winston Howard signed the articles of association of the company. No wonder the Leader of the House did not go to the articles of the association-I interjected to him that he said he would. What do the articles of association say? They do not automatically put the Prime Minister as a director of the Menzies Foundation. The Leader of the Liberal Party has the clear opportunity to appoint a nominee. So let us have none of this argument about automaticity. Let us hav- the argument about the state of knowledge and knowledge in the signing of the articles of association, but failure to declare to the public and to the parliament. We know the Prime Minister knows his guilt. Why else would he go and resign in secret? Because he was guilty of failure to disclose. That is why he resigned in secret. If the penny has not dropped, we will keep repeating it for you. Members should understand the time sequence of this because it is very important. On 15 October John Winston Howard secretly resigned from the Menzies Foundation. Two days before he had lost two ministers-Jim Short and Brian Gibson. The minister for industry was embroiled in a real controversy associated with the mess with his family companies and his share trading. He was on the rack too. So foremost in the Prime Minister's mind would have been the fundamental significance of complying with his code. That is two days before. He resigned secretly on 15 October 1996 and did his press conference the next day where he made those famous admonitions to his front-bench. He went bravely before the Australian public saying, 'I'm Honest John. l'm enforcing my code. I have had lots of talks with a lot of my colleagues in recent days and I very forcibly reminded them of their obligations.' That is John Winston Howard, Winston the weasel. That is what he said. But at the same time as he was reminding them of their obligations, what was the weasel up to? He slipped in the back door, divested himself of his directorship and did not declare it. Mr Ross Cameron-On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the member for Hotham continues to refer to honourable members with derisive epithets that are both inaccurate and unparliamentary. I ask that he be required to refer to honourable members by their correct titles.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: This is a censure of the Prime Minister, but I think the honourable member for Hotham needs to bear in mind the admonition of the honourable member for Parramatta.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: I remember when the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) got up and objected to me being referred to as a grub and you said that was fair play. Perhaps you can give usa list of the animals that are in and those that are out.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The honourable member for Hotham will resume his remarks.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: And I would be enlightened.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: If the honourable member wishes to persist in that remark, I will order him to sit down. Continue your response to the censure.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Here we have the Prime Minister of Australia reminding his ministers and colleagues of their obligations yet he sneaked in the back door, tendered his resignation and did not tell anyone about it. On this question of the so-called trivia, the Leader of the House says $100,000 is not worth anything. I suppose when you have got a front-bench over there that is into family trusts and 16 shares that are worth $2 million, then I suppose $100,000 is just petty cash, it is just what you might draw out on the weekend to look after yourself and your family. One hundred thousand dollars is not much money? What sort of an April fool is that Leader of the House to come in and make that assertion? But it is not just $100,000; it is $400,000. That is what they have benefited from. The Prime Minister says it was trivial that he was director of a company when he sat in a cabinet meeting, chaired it and gave them what is now worth $400,000, plus all the benefits of the tax deductibility. He might think that is trivia; we do not. Let us understand the Prime Minister's version of trivia. In his declaration of interests, the one where the directorship of the Menzies company does not appear, what does he declare? This is what he says-these are his own words: I am writing to advise you that I have accepted honorary membership of the International Fellowship of Cricket Loving Rotarians. I would have thought that that is absolute trivia, but he chose to declare it. How can he choose to declare that and not the fact that he is a director of a company that benefits to the tune of $400,000? It beggars belief. What have we also got?

Speaker: Unknown
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Yes, a couple of bottles of Grange Hermitage. Then in his declaration he mentioned the Gladesville RSL Club, the Lords Taverners Australia Cricketers Association, City Tattersalls, Sydney Cricket Ground, Ravenswood Fathers Association, Shore Parents Association, Earlwood District Rugby Union Club, Balmain District Cricket Club, but not director of the Menzies company. Talk about trivia. Just to get again this point of the state of mind of the Prime Minister in what he knew he had to declare in the declaration of interests, he wrote: It will be obvious that some of the above organisations are ones to which I have belonged for some time. They were not included in earlier returns as I had not appreciated that membership of charitable/community organisations were ones that should be disclosed. However, it is apparent from a strict reading of the explanatory guidelines that they might need to be. Who said that? John Winston Howard when he declared everything else except his directorship of the Menzies company. It is a sham to come in here and say that he did not have to declare. He was required to declare in accordance with his code and in accordance with the parliamentary register and he did not do so. He sought to cover it up and as consequence not only have we identified the conflict but he has also misled this parliament because he told this parliament in putting that declaration before them that he was not a director of any company. He misled the parliament. He is guilty on three counts. . Let us go to the exercise of his defence last night. He did not come into the parliament today to give his defence. He had the opportunity at 9.30 a.m. today and any time thereafter-after question time today. He has not added to an answer. He still has not answered the question as to why he did not disclose and why he did not absent himself from the meeting. This is what he said. Apart from the cover-up, apart from the nondisclosure, apart from the misleading of the House, these are his own words: . ... unless the Parliament is . .. assured that Senator Richardson either disclosed his interest as a director of the radio station whenever he particior pated in Cabinet ... decisionsnot the specific conflict but any discussion about communications; this is the John Howard test thenon broadcasting matters '" or . " absented himself from those discussions, he must, in ance with accepted Cabinet practice, resign from the Ministry ... We are asking no more today of John Howard, the Prime Minister of this country, than that he applies the standards he himself was laying down for other people. Why should the standards change just because he is caught out? In these circurnstances-a code of conduct rotten to the core, tatters flapping in the breeze, corpses all over the place-the Prime Minister of Australia says, 'Oh, there's nothing different.' We had thought the reason he was sticking by Senator Parer was not that his wife could cook a decent meal; it would cause a domino effect with Max Moore-Wilton, the departmental head who cleared them. The reason John Winston Howard, the Prime Minister of this country, has been sticking by Senator Parer is that he knows he has been caught. The Prime Minister has been caught. The Prime Minister cannot continue to lay down standards which he himself has breached and not cop the consequences of that. That is what we have today. It is the next dimension in the argument. The dominoes will fall-Senator Parer, Max Moore-Wilton; they lead right to the oval office in this case. The code of conduct is rotten to the core, the Prime Minister of the country engulfed in it. No wonder he is sticking by Senator Parer, but the longer he does the more his standing will diminish. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: As I have a good recollection of the history of the Labor Party in this place, let me commence by reading a quote from page 3973 of Hansard on 28 November 1986. It was stated: At no point has the Treasurer indicated other than that this was a mistake and one which he regrets. There is all the difference in the world between a Minister, in this case the Treasurer, making a mistake of this kind, readily admitting it and immediately rectifying it and some suggestion that a question of propriety is involved. By any standard criterion one would wish to apply to this matter there is no question of ministerial propriety involved. There is no question of a pecuniary or any other gain involved. They are the words of Pri-e Minister Hawke defending his Treasurer, Paul Keating. On accord- what charge? Failing to lodge two tax returns-not one but two. The then Treasurer of the country failed to even respond to the very polite correspondence that he was receiving from the Commissioner of Taxation'Treasurer, do you think you could send your tax returns in?' At that time it was a scandal throughout Australia that there were half a million unclaimed group certificates in the tax office, primarily the property of moonlighters. What did the then Prime Minister say? 'It's not really a problem. There was no act of impropriety. There was no conflict of interest that the poor old Commissioner of Taxation had to put his job at risk.' Yet we know how brutal that Treasurer could be with other people's employment if he crossed their path. The reality is that they were pleading with him to put in a tax return. It was a massive conflict of interest. What was the response of the Labor Party? There were questions asked. And that was the then Prime Minister's answer. But there also a censure motion in which the then Prime Minister said: What I said was a factual statement of the position, that is, that for an ordinary pay as you earn er this would not be a matter of immense quence. He is excusing his Treasurer on the grounds that maybe the tax commissioner would not punish an ordinary taxpayer for failing to in a tax return-not much, but what a dement, fence! What happened at the end of all this? is traditional, we had a vote. There are still few people sitting in the House-not many from the Labor Party side. I am sure I can find Bob Brown's name on that list. I can certainly find the name of the now Leader of the Opposition-Beazley KC. I can certainly find the name of someone who had a shot at me as I stood up--MCLeay, Leo. There is also Martin S.P.; Morris, Allan; Morris, Peter; O'Keefe, Neil; Hawke, R.J.L., the Prime Minister at the time; and Theophanous, A.C - you would remember him, Mr Speaker, he keeps taking points of order on you. All of those people and all of the Labor Party came in here and voted to support the then TreasurI er after it had been said that there was no personal conflict of interest, that it was nothing than some ordinary PAYE taxpayer. What does that come down to? Gross hypocrisy. There were no standards in the Labor Party. We had the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) pontificating today. The way he rewrites history has to be the most outstanding effort in the world. 'We were perfect,' he said, and of course the list is legion. I remind the House of Mick Young and the Ivanov affair-a situation where state secrets were leaked in a car park. The then Prime Minister even misled us. He said that Keating offered up honestly. That is a fact. After Jim Carlton wrote him a letter asking if a copy of a letter he had from the tax commissioner saying, 'Treasurer, please lodge your tax returns' was true, he came in here at half past 10 one night with Mick Young standing behind him and said 'Yes, it's true,' and Mick Young closed the parliament. Yes, tell me about it. I remember the was history in this place and so do you, Mr Speaker. The realities are that on another occasion I raised a question of pecuniary interest. The whole nation was afire because taxpayan entrepreneur called Holmes a Court, the consemajor shareholder in Bell Group and Bell Resources, had a takeover offer that was just about imminent over Australia's biggest company, BHP. It is not surprising that the put government of the day, the Labor governput together a secret cabinet subcommittee to consider the government's position. What were the rules of that subcommittee? As Whatever they considered, whatever informaa tion they had, would never come out. But the caucus was going to be told what to do by that committee. It was a massive situation. There was a group of people there, including the Prime Minister. There. was a fellow there called Senator Button. Of course, Senator Button had done the right thing, as we were told by the Leader of the Opposition, 'in keeping with their high standards'. On 12 September 1983 he wrote to the Prime Minister saying: I confirm that I have resigned any directorships in public companies, cease to engage in professional practice or in the daily work of any business, that accept no retainers and derive no income from exertion other than arising from my duties worse as a minister and a member of parliament. That is pretty clear. But what do we find on 11 April 1986, just three years later? An admission in the parliament that Senator Button is a director. Of what? A company, of course, that he did not think was a public company. But today we have been told the Menzies Trust is a public company. He is a director of a public company that just happened to have 58,000 shares in BHP. They were worth at that time some $371,000 and, if the takeover offer had been accepted, their value was going to jump to $452,000 and the $80,000 profit was tax free. He was sitting on this cabinet subcommittee making decisions about whether or not there would be a takeover of BHP and he was a representative of this company. I should find the name of the company because it is of great importance to us. I will come back to that in a minute. I thought we should also have a look at who the shareholders in that company werethe beneficiaries of his actions. The beneficiaries are the Transport Workers Union of Australia, the Australia Post and Telecommunications Union, the Federated Gas Employees and Industrial Union, and the Australian Labor Party. Everyone in that cabinet subcommittee was a member of the Australian Labor Party. We had our Prime Minister today accused of having an association with one of these things. They were all shareholders in BHP. They were sitting there in judgment. But the irony gets better, because there was another fellow there. His name was John Dawkins. I had-and it is all on the record-the pleasure of drawing to the parliament's attention how, through the operations of a company called Coomel, Mr Dawkins and his brother had practised every tax minimisation device available. By the way, what was the process they used? They were trusts. At a time when probate death duties were still around, to make sure they were going to pay none of that, they went so far as, on the day their father died, to liquidate the company, pulling it all out. They went further. They sold a major property. In fact what had they done? They had actually capitalised the interest. They sold the property on terms but there was no interest mentioned. The fellow made them an offer of X. The actual purchase price three years later was X plus a large amount of money, which worked out at 11 per cent, or whatever the current interest rate was at the time, but that was in the price. Of course in those days there was no capital gains tax. Dawkins was the liquidator of the family company. In all the distributions and for other reasons his mum just happened to have 250,000 shares in Bell Group. Please remember what the takeover was. It was Bell Group or Bell Resources-it was one or the other-taking over BHP. So we have this secret cabinet subcommittee. The Labor Party is a beneficiary of 58,616 shares worth $371,000. They are all sitting there and in comes Dawkins. Of course he had been a great scourge on tax avoiders. He was the one who demanded of us in government under Fraser that we bring in retrospective legislation. He was going to fix up everything. Of course, every weekend he went home and worked out through Coomel how to protect his family from anything that was happening. He was also a great moralist. So he walked into this cabinet subcommittee and said, 'I hope everybody here has declared a pecuniary interest.' What did they say? 'We haven't got any.' Button did not have one. He was a director. He was a trustee of this fund. Of course, what was the situation with Dawkins? We are told in the Hansard when we had another censure and Mick Young got up to defend him that the realities were that you could not possibly expect Dawkins to know everything his mum had. Well, we expect Senator Parer to know everything his kids have got, and we blame him for every bit of it! Mr Bevis-That's because he is running the trust, you dill.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: And Dawkins was running the trust, too, you bigger dill-and you hypocrite.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will direct his remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The reality is that you and your mob condoned all these things. You condoned a Treasurer who did not put his tax returns in and you voted in this place to say that he was honest and right and did not have a conflict of interest. Mr Bevis-Calm down!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: The honourable member for O'Connor will direct his remarks through the chair.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PRIME MINISTER
text: You carryon and you tell us what the Prime Minister should have done, but you had a cabinet subcommittee-nothing bigger. The joke of it was, and I reminded the government at the time, that a tame caucus took their recommendation. They all had a pecuniary interest through their membership of the Labor Party. Senator Button was a director of the company three years after he had told his Prime Minister he had resigned all those directorships. Any suggestion that Dawkins did not know that mum had shares in Bell because they originated from the old Albany Woollen Mills, of which his uncle, Sir Ernest Lee-Steere, was of course the chairman of directors, defies reality. That was your argument at that time, but of course you are too big a mob of hypocrites today. You come in here and you have redefined yourselves. Is it not amazing that it was the Leader of the Opposition that accused us of redefining the issues? You never sacked anyone for a pecuniary interest. Of course, you did not sack too many anyhow; you came in and you defended them. Ros Kelly: what an outrageous arrangement-and you defended her for six months until public opinion demanded she had to go. In all of these cases the defence was by the Albanese, A. Prime Minister, and you all came in here and you voted to back him. I will read you the names again. When Dawkins was censured in this place, Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, was in here in fact defending that outrageous situation. You cannot get much closer to a pecuniary interest than to own shares in a company or have your mother, whom you' are very close to and whose business affairs you were conducting, owning shares. You go in and you say, 'Has anyone got apecuniary interest?' and they all say no. The reality was that you were up to your eyebrows in it. You just make fools of yourselves by coming in here and trying to rewrite history. It is all in the Hansard; go away and read it. But do not come in here and tell me there is any difference between the Prime Minister's almost arms-length involvement in a research trust when in fact your people sat with hard dollars on behalf of the Australian Labor Party and went on and took secret cabinet subcommittee rulings. And you are stiII doing it-you are all members of your unions. You are all in here arguing industrial relations legislation. When have any of you put your hand up? (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: I move: That the Carrier Licence Conditions (V odafone Pty Limited) Declaration 1997 (Amendment No.1 of 1997), made under subsection 63(5) of the Telecommunications Act 1997, be disallowed. The purpose of this disallowance motion is to stop the federal government giving a huge financial bonus to a foreign owned company which is standing in the way. of the analog mobile phone service being maintained for the people of rural and regional Australia. In 1992 the then Labor government made an agreement with Vodafone which allowed the British owned company to enter the Australian telecommunications market as the country's third mobile carrier providing an exclusively digital service. That privilege cost Vodafone a mere $140 million. Under that deal, the government agreed to phase out analog mobile phones by the year 2000, while in return Vodafone agreed it would take on majority Australian ownership by 2003. When the Labor government made the decision in 1992 to phase out analog phones, it was not to know that the digital system would be so disastrously ineffective. It was a naive decision-how could any reasonable person predict technology and its impact eight to 10 years out? But now this government says that it cannot reverse the decision because it would have to pay compensation to Vodafone. At the same time, it is letting Vodafone back out of its side of the deal, meaning that it will no longer have to take on Australian ownership. What is this deal worth? Some who know more about this than I estimate that it could be worth as much as half a billion dollars. Vodafone does not have to shed half its value onto a glutted Australian telephony market, but is left free to sell to AT&T or British Telecom or whomever else down the track. How much compensation would the government be liable to pay Vodafone if it moved to break its side of the deal and maintain analog? Again, it is guesswork-but some say it could be worth between $100 million and $200 million. Even allowing for a certain amount of misestimate, there is a big difference between the two figures: the off-thehook bonus for Vodafone and a payment, which I believe could be defended in the High Court if necessary, in the interests of community services. The government wants to give Vodafone a half billion dollar concession, but says it cannot ask the company for anything in return, because it might have to pay a couple of hundred million dollars compensation. The analog system is worth $3 billion alone; that is what Vodafone wants us to throwaway. I put it to you that the government is deliberately misleading the Australian people on this issue. Members are going around the bush saying, 'It was the Labor government that agreed to phase out analog, the government is now stuck with the decision, but because we'-that is, the government- 'understand, we have now made a decision which will allow analog to be retained in areas where there is no "reasonably equivalent" digital coverage.' However, the analog will only continue in these particular rural areas if Telstra, Optus and Vodafone agree to it. This undertaking is the biggest con job and the most hollow promise ever made to people in regional Australia. Let us take a look at electorate. I seek to table these maps prepared by independent consultants which show the difference between analog and digital coverage from Mount Canobolas in the centre of my electorate. They are prepared by Tele Resources and used, in fact, by the Australian Communications Authority. I should point out that they give a much more accurate picture of the digital coverage compared to the highly exaggerated coverage maps put out by the phone companies themselves. These publicly available coverage maps from Telstra are a joke-you just have to compare the digital map with the public ones. If you look at the map which I have sought to be tabled you will see the analog has a range of about 100 kilometres and more, reaching almost out to towns as far away as Bathurst, Wellington, Crookwell and Cowra from Mount Canobolas. Importantly, it covers little places like Hill End, Canowindra, Carcoar, Barry, Garland, Mullion Creek-all of which cannot be reached with digital. If you look at the digital map, you will note that the range is only about 30 kilometres-and there is nothing at Molong, where I live: I vouch for that. There is nothing several kilometres east of Orange. I can also vouch for that, having tried, any day of the week, contact my office and other constituents only a kilometre or two out of Orange. The digital transmitters on Mount Canobolas do not even provide effective coverage to parts of the of Orange itself, let alone along the highway to Bathurst-despite what these pamphlets say. Let us just take a look at the scenario is certain to unfold in the next 12 months when the Australian Communications Authority starts negotiating to maintain sections of the analog network. It contacts Vodafone, which-remember-is the only carrier without analog and therefore the company with most to lose. It writes to Vodafone and says, 'Do you mind if we keep the analog transmitter in operation up on Mount Canobolas?' By this time Vodafone has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars installing digital transmitters on Mount Canobolas, as well as putting others in a number of nearby towns, including my Orange, because of course the one on Mount Canobolas really only provides effective coverage to the orchards and farms around the base of the mountain. I might add at this point that Vodafone has outraged residents of Bathurst because, after installing a transmitter on Mount Panorama, it has found the coverage to be so inadequate that it has had to put another one on top of the post office dead in the centre of town, and it is right next door to a pre-school. Despite a big campaign by concerned residents to have the tower moved away from the preschool, Vodafone has completely ignored the requests of the residents and the Bathurst City Council. So much for the community service obligations from telephone companies. And here we have a government prepared to do this company favours, to give them a huge financial windfall and say, 'We'll leave it up to you to decide which areas of regional Australia can continue to have analog phones.' What an absolute farce of a telecommunications policy! Of course Vodafone is going to say that the analog service on Mount Canobolas has to go, can because it has what it would no doubt call a 'reasonably equivalent' digital service there. Likewise, the analog service at Mount Panorato ma should also go. Vodafone would have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on its digital network throughout the electorate. But as I've already pointed out, it doesn't even city provide adequate coverage in the major regional centres. Mr Deputy Speaker, take another look at those coverage maps-I invite all members to that do so-and see how far the analog service does, in fact, go. The story is the same in every rural electorate and many metropolitan electorates right across the country. Some like to describe analog as inferior technology to digital. But what good is the better technology if you can't get a signal? We will probably see the same sort of disaster as we introduce digital television, because it is going to need a crowd of transmitters. It is going to cost an arm and a leg-far beyond the sort of money that the regional television stations are quoting at the moment. They have not even begun to work it out. Analog phones have become an essential business tool to hundreds of farmers and rural business people in my electorate. We all know that farmers cannot afford to hire employees to help them these days. They are increasingly having to work on their own, doing business from the tractor seat, using mobile analog phones. Farming is one of the most dangerous and lonely occupations. Here is one tool that has made that job a little safer and more viable, and a Liberal-National Party government wants to take that technology away. Andrew Prior, who runs a fertiliser spreading business based in Bathurst, is typical of those in my electorate who are alarmed by the way the government has handled this issue. He carries a mobile-an analog mobile-not so much to conduct business, but more as an emergency tool. He says his job has become increasingly isolated as farmers take on larger property holdings, while many also take on jobs in town during the day. He says: If the analogue system is closed and a single efficient system is not introduced to replace it, then the safety of myself and many others is placed at greater risk. On occasions, I am 8 paddocks from the nearest public road. In the event of an emergency I rely on my mobile phone to obtain personal assistance. I am often 20 minutes drive from the nearest occupied house, say 40 minutes walk, assuming I am capable of walking. He notes he uses his phones in rural areas like Paling Yards, Fosters Valley and Trunkey. None of those areas have any hope, I would say, of getting a digital signal. They are too far away from the major regional population centres and the highways, and there are not enough regular mobile users in the areas to warrant the expense of installing more <Jigital based stations to provide the same coverage. Telstra is likely to deliver cable to these sorts of people and say, 'Do it yourself,' for a normal phone service. That has happened in my electorate. That is why this decision to phase out analog has to be reversed. Unless technology is developed to improve the signal strength of digital, it will never be an adequate replacement for analog. We have a ratio of at least four to one in digital to analog transmission points. That could rise to 10 to one in certain circumstances. Certainly it was Labor that made the decision. The coalition has the power to change it, but I wonder if it has the will. Rather, it has opted for a con job that will do absolutely nothing to help the farmers and agricultural workers like Andrew Prior in my electorate. I am sure there are others in other rural and regional electorates. Another part of this deception is this weird promise that new satellite phones will soon be here and that they can be used anywhere. This is another deception because anyone with a passing knowledge of mobile phones can tell you this technology has not even been fully developed. Even when it is, the handsets will cost several thousands of dollars. The Iridium system, which is one of those being talked about, has handsets costing $US3,OOO. I do not believe that is a cost-effective replacement, even given reasonable take-up of this technology down the track. It is still moons away for the sort of people who can afford and rely on analog. It might be okay for big mining companies and the like, but not for a struggling farmer, his wife drivipg a lonely rural road alone with the kids or the bush fire brigade captains who use analog throughout Calare. Forget about digital; they cannot even rely on the inadequate radio communication system for their fire control, but they can rely on analog, to a large degree. Why do we have to wait for a system that is untried and expensive when we already have a system in place that is cheap and effective? It is because of this ridiculous promise made to Vodafone back in 1992 that this government says cannot be broken. I urge members not to fall for this con job by Vodafone. Vote with me to disallow this giveaway to Vodafone so we can force this company to come to the negotiating table for the benefit of the people of rural and regional Australia. Recently, we were visited by the very successful technological wizard, Bill Gates, who reminded us that we were only at the very start of the communications age. It is all very well for the majority of Australians, who live in capital cities and who have fibre optic cable laid to their front door, to pat themselves on the back and say; 'Wow! We're leading the world. We're right up at the coalface. We're at the edge of technology. We're right in amongst it.' Compare this situation to that of many farmers in my electorate, given Telstra's dreadful service record of late-which I was accused as late as this morning of exaggerating. In his report to the parliament yesterday, the minister at the table, the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith), who represents the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) in this chamber, detailed some of those shortcomings. I have had a litany of complaints, not necessarily from within my electorate; some have been from outside my electorate. Compare this to Telstra's dreadful service record of only using copper wire. They believe that that is enough; that that is an adequate service. To many of these people out in the remote areas, having a fax or a computer or a transmission via modem seems little more than a pipedream. Now they are being told they will lose their mobile analog service. From day one in this country the people of rural Australia have had to fight for equal access to communications. As we enter the communications age, there is a very real risk with the imminent sale of Telstra looming in the background that these people will be left behind unless the federal government makes the right decisions in this crucial policy area. These people are opposed to the further sale of Telstra because they know that, if it is purely left up to market forces to deliver services in the bush, there will not be an adequate service. I urge the government members to consider, as we prepare to head into the next century, what sort of message they are sending to the people of rural and regional Australia when they start switching off what has become a crucial means of communication to satisfy a foreign owned company, a British company, which could never have any understanding of the distances, the isolation and the unique needs of the Australian bush, such as the scattering of people across vast distances. The make-up of our geographical spread of population and our particular needs .do not bear any resemblance to any country in the world that I can think of. I commend this motion to the House.
