Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Yes, more of the sameTweedledum and Tweedledee. My electorate is a case in point. Moore is a metropolitan electorate in Perth's northern suburbs; it is not even a country electorate. About one-third of my electorate has no digital mobile telephone service. The service providers presumably do not cover the whole electorate because they do not consider it economical. This is at the crux of the flaws in this government's approach. Most of my constituents have an analog alternative at present, but of course under the current arrangements-these plans-that will not continue for much longer. Amongst other things, government exists in our tradition to provide essential services to the community. Communications are an essential service. During the years that digital mobile telephone communications have been available in Australia governments have allowed a commercial rationale to dictate who gets coverage. It has not ensured that the community service obligations related to mobile telephony coverage are raised and enforced to benefit all Australians. This obligation on government to ensure that a service is provided fairly, equally and as best as possible to all members of our community is at the base of this particular problem. That is their No.1 objective and their No.1 duty. The digital mobile service providers have not been without blame in this area. Telstra, the potentially private corporation this government seeks to control through legislation, unfortunately has a poor record in service provision. Telstra's honesty in advertising has been less than good. It claims to cover 90 per cent of Australia with its digital service and implies in its hard-sell telemarketing that anyone switching from analog to a digital service will be getting better coverage. What it fails to say, and what it should be made to say clearly, is that it covers 90 per cent of the static telephone numbers in Australia. The vast majority of those are in close proximity to the central business districts of the capitals and major cities of Australia. It does not he cover even outer metropolitan areas like my electorate, and it certainly does not cover most of regional Australia. The problem is that if you are not standing in one of those areas serviced when you try to make a call, you might as well be on the moon. Telstra is displaying the concept that terra nullius is not dead. It wants us to believe that Australia is an empty, cavernous entity once you leave the central business districts of major cities, and it has been allowed to get away with pushing this view commercially. How can this government claim to be able to control a privati sed Telstra when it clearly cannot restrain Telstra while it still owns a majority interest in it? I want to talk about a specific example in my electorate. I have a number of constituents in the northern suburbs of my electorate, that is, in the northern suburbs of Perth, who are cray fisherman. They have a requirement to be able to communicate with each other at sea. Previously they used the analog system and used it successfully-it gave them good coverage. But the only drawback it had in the case of cray fisherman was when they were ringing each other to describe where the crayfish were. Obviously their competitors monitored their phones and they would start converging where most of the crayfish were located. Telemarketing by Telstra, and in this instance aggressive telemarketing, assured them that they could change to digital, get the security they needed and have coverage at least as good as the analog network. My constituents identified that they needed coverage out to sea, which is presently available through the analog network. They were reassured by the Telstra marketers, and the Telstra agent fitted the high-powered, expensive digital telephones to their cray boats. After spending many thousands of dollars between them, they now find that there is no reliable coverage. Often the phones do not work more than 200 metres offshore and, when they do, the calls drop in and out without warning. As Professor Julius Sumner Miller would ask: why is this so? It is becaliSe the transponders in Western Australia do not face out to sea. Telstra then say, quite clearly once they have sold the equipment to these people, 'Oh, but our maps show that it doesn't in fact provide a service out to sea.' Of course, with their heavily stylised maps, it is very hard to understand where their particular service boundaries are. If you look very carefully .at them and their relationship to the maps and the stylisation of those maps, you will see that it is very difficult to identify where those boundaries occur. Telstra is very happy to keep the analog network. Perhaps the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) does not know this, but it is. In fact it has such a huge capital investment that it would see such a decision as preventing a huge capital waste. It is also a question of competition. By allowing Vodafone to operate exclusively within the digital environment, the government is actually reducing competition in the mobile phone sector. True competition would see both digital and analog systems operating side by side. They are different. Each has different strengths and weaknesses. They each bring different things to customers, and if this _government were true to its own philosophy it would keep the analog network operating on the basis that competition between the networks is good for customers. I thought that was one of the principles U;lOn which this government based its policies until, of course, I saw it introduce its digital television decision, which I have to say has reinforced a somewhat jaundiced view about this government's commitment to true competition. It will drive technological advancement; it will provide better service; and it will drive prices down. This is the whole point of having the two networks side by side. I might also point out that in the United States, at one of the cutting edges of the telecommunications markets, analog and digital services will exist side by side. In fact American consumers will be able to choose. They will be able to use a system that allows for the merging or the interrelationship between the analog and the digital networks. The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, was quizzed on this on a radio program. He was asked precisely about this particular facet of digital versus analog networks in the United States, and he made what was in fact a totally inaccurate comment that there was going to be a phone that could be used in both analog and digital networks within Australia. No such telephone exists. Mr Neville-It does exist.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: No. You have to carry two phones. I am sorry, you produce one for me; I would like to see it. That was a problem with another recent piece of legislation, the child care amendment legislation-which the minister is familiar with-where the technology was not quite available to be able to deliver the promised legislative change. He agrees with that and he knows that that was one of my criticisms then. As part of my contribution to this debate, all I am asking is for the government to think again. I do not think that is a particularly difficult thing for them to do, surely. All we are asking them to do is to review a decision made by the Labor government. It was a decision that was wrongly based; it was a decision that was not in the best interests of customers; and it was a decision not in the best interests of service delivery and fundamentally, and the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) might want to be aware of this, it was a decision that was inconsistent with the coalition government's own philosophical commitment to competition and market forces because it restricts competition. In the last few minutes of my contribution in this debate, I will deal with a couple of issues that were raised by potential customers, clients, when talking to one of the experts from the ACA's analog closure education program, Mr Warren Duncan, who appeared on 8 January 1998 on 3AW in Melbourne. He made some observations in response to questions, one of which was when the interviewer said that a knowledgeable caller suggested that the digital coverage would never cover the whole of Australia, that it was impossible. Mr Duncan conceded: That could very well be the case. He is the expert. Ask the expert. He says: That could very well be the case, but the difference really is that . . . it's because of the nature of the technology, Doug. Analog can stretch out over quite considerable distances whereas, dependent upon where the base station is, digital may not cover the same extent, but that's why the government has gone for digital because in the future, in the areas even where there isn't analog at the moment, satellites will be covering these areas in a much more cost-efficient way than analog even is now because y'know we will be able to have dual handset ... dual mode handsets which will enable people to talk via satellite . . . I have to make an observation here: this is talking about technology that is not actually available to the Australian marketplace right now. Mr Bruce Scott-Rubbish. It's out there now. I've got a rural electorate.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: If the member had any idea of what he was talking about I would argue the case with him, but I do not think you can argue with an expert from the government's own agency. In fact, when asked the question about a preference in terms of the technology, the expert conceded: No, I really don't have a preference in terms of the technology. You'll find at anyone mobile phone forum you'll have any different number of speakers who will stand up and support any different type of technology . . . In the United States, the majority of mobile phone service consumers opt for analog. When they are given the choice of different levels of analog service, including encrypted analog, most of them go for standard analog service because it is more reliable, it has better coverage and, in many instances, it is cheaper. In this country we have restricted competition, made the marketplace more restricted, driven prices up and restricted the services to people who live in remote and regional areas. In actual fact, that is totally contrary to the philosophy of this government. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr FILING

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Yes, but they interrupted me, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: -Very little, I might add, Mr Deputy Speaker. However, I will just get on with the text of this. There is a bit of history involved with this, and it goes back to 1992 when the Labor government,' to attract new players into the Australian mobile phone regime, agreed to turn off the analog network on 1 January 2000. Despite the fact that that was a very poor decision, there was one thing they did have to get right: sovereign risk. If you were going to ask people like Optus and Vodafone to come into the market with a new digital technology, there would have to be some certainty that they would have a share of the market and that, by the year 2000, the old technology would be removed. The member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay) went into a lot of glib asides about being interested'to hear what the National Party had to say about this. The National Party was saying things about this from the very minute we knew the analog system was not going to be overtaken by the digital system by the year 2000. We were out talking about it more than a year ago. We got the ear of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), and the minister has put an interim measure in place. That interim measure is that, in those areas where the digital signal is not adequate, the analog signal will be extended to provide a reasonably equivalent service. I did not hear the member for Cal are at that time, or the member for Moore (Mr Filing), expressing those doubts. We knew what it was going to mean, but we also knew that there was a matter of sovereign risk involved, that there was a whole range of technologies coining to Australia in the next four or five years and that any government in the futurebe it of our persuasion or the opposition'swould have to take into account the consequences of some ill-conceived idea that destroyed the credibility of the government's guarantee of sovereign risk. As I said, in those areas that do not have a reasonably equivalent service we have decided to allow the continuation of the analog system beyond the year 2000. The member for Cal are described areas of his electorate and said how important it was that these people have digital phones. I do not disagree with that for a minute, but you will find anywhere in Australia, as you did when we had only analog, that there are areas where you cannot get a signal. I have areas between Bundaberg and Gladstone in my electorate where we do not get a signalanalog or digital. The interesting thing is this-and none of the other speakers have mentioned this in the debate today: analog currently covers 93.8 per cent of the populated areas of Australia.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Static telephone numbers.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Yes, static telephone numbers.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: What about geographical areas?

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Where most of the people live-I thank them very much for readily taking the point. Where most of the people live, it is 93.8 per cent. Interestingly digital is now covering 94.1 per cent, to be precise. In fact, it has overtaken analog and is going ahead of it. I am not pretending for one minute to the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) or to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrews, that those two signal areas overlay completely. There will be some areas where there are gaps in the analog and there will be some areas where there are gaps in the digital. But the big point that the member for Calare is missing is this: we are now coming to yet another era of digital phone technology. Contrary to what the member for Moore said, we are on the threshold of having intermodal handsets. The technology that will be delivered is an American based digital technology called CD:.1A. CDMA will be the next technology offered to Australia. If we are going to have intermodal phones that can roam from one technology to the other, that opportunity will exist if companies are encouraged to come into this country in the same way that Optus and Vodafone were encouraged to come to Australia in 1992. You could not say that they have not made a fair effort to do the right thing and to honour their side of the agreement. For example, Optus has invested at least $5 billion in Australia. If you want to take their television interests into it, it is possibly as high as $10 billion. At this stage, Vodafone has invested $1.2 billion. They did that in the clear understanding that the analog technology was going to be switched off in the year 2000, and that mayor may not have been a good decision.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: That was a rubbish decision.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: It was a bad decision, as it turns out. However, if we do not honour that agreement, as the member for Calare himself said, the government faces the risk of quite heavy litigation. To try to interfere with its shareholding after again giving an understanding to this company and using that as a method of blackmail would destroy any guarantee of sovereign risk being honoured in this country, would be the very thing that would drive companies away like those who enough, wish to introduce CDMA, people like Hutchison Telecoms from Hong Kong, and would deny Australians a better quality technology. If you go back over the history of broadcast and telecommunications in Australia, we have not always been the first to adopt a new technology. We generally stand back a bit, have a look at the technology and then decide what will be appropriate for Australia. When we did this with black and white television, Australia per head of population embraced the medium to a greater level than anyone else in the civilised world. Then came colour television and, again, we were the frontrunner, but we waited to get the technology right. Again, with the advent of VCRs, we were a major user around the world. We are now on the verge in broadcast communications of this same argument of digital against analog. Obviously if we introduce digital properly and control it properly, we can have the best quality television in the world, no risk.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

If we want to take that to the next plane, we have to create certainty that there will be a commercial return to those organisations at the end of the investment period, and the investment will be somewhere in the order of $700 million to $900 million, which is a huge investment.

Speaker: Mr FILING

The point I am making here is this: if we want people to come to this country or if we want existing players in this country to invest in new broadcast and telecommunications technology, then it is critical that we provide certainty. If we want to move from analog to digital, from digital to CDMA and beyond CDMA to low orbiting satellites, which will be absolutely crucial for the member for Kalgoorlie

Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: You guys remind me of a fellow who rang me up when one of the last telephone exchanges in my area was going over to automatic. He passionately wanted us to retain the old wind-up phone where you had to ask for the number. That is the sort of thing you are doing. Mr Zammit-That's ridiculous!

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: No, it is not ridiculous. What you are ultimately trying to do is to take the Australian bush for a very short-term gain. I say to the member for Cal are that, for a very short-term gain, you are going to take the whole of Australia's electronic communications back to the caveman stuff. The analog spectrum is going to be surrendered for television and it is eventually going to be surrendered for telecommunications. It will be reallocated to do other things for the Australian public in both the fields of telecommunications and broadcast communications. We need to move on. One of the problems in Australia is this ready take-up in broadcast and telecommunications that I explained to you. We tend to take on these technologies much quicker than other countries. The fact that we got to 93.8 in analog and 94.1 in digital already is evidence of how quickly we have taken up the technologies. Because we have done that, it is not perfect. I know that in Sydney sometimes my digital phone drops out. It is overIQ-ded. I know there are parts in my electorate where I lose my digital signal. If you ask me, on balance, whether I would rather go back to inferior technology and leave Australia in the doldrums or whether we should take on the new technologies such as CDMA and intermodal phones that can roam from one technology to another or whether I want people not just around Bathurst and Orange but the people out west who have not seen an analog or digital phone to get a high quality low orbiting satellite phone, I think is important that we do not cave into some shallow blackmail against Vodafone to make them leave in place technology that will not only slow down their operations, slow down Optus, but also drive away new competitors in the field. The other thing you have to think about in the bush is not just having the raw technology but having the technology at a level that people can afford. We have got very low telecommunications costs in this country because, with normal telephony, Optus and other operators have offered competitive services to Telstra. We now have people offering competitive services to analog. I appeal to the member for Calare and the member for Moore to reconsider their stand. I think it is immature. I think it will not advance the cause of the bush getting high quality telecommunications. I therefore reject the amendment.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: For one of my disposition, it is very difficult to sit still and listen to somebody totally misrepresenting the facts. Let us go back to the beginning of what actually happened. In 1992, the government gave an undertaking that GSM, global systems for mobile, would be the system for Australia. The reason for this was quite easy to understand. In Europe you had 15 different systems going across Europe. The French got together and said that this was crazy and they produced a system that unified Europe, a relatively small area, and it worked well. What happened in Australia? The government was confused and bluffed by the bureaucrats and they decided to adopt this system of GSM. This is what happened. Politicians at the time were entitled to believe the information they were given by the bureaucracy, so we ended up with GSM. In the meantime, along came the Americans and developed CDMA, code division multiplier access. This is a significantly different sort of digital. It does not batch the signal, as GSM does. It is therefore compatible with analog. The member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) is quite wrong, because there is no obligation in this country to introduce CDMA. It will be opposed by it Vodafone and Optus because they do not have the technology. They just simply do not have it. They will oppose that as strongly as they will oppose maintaining analog. In the United States, you have a seamless handset which will go from the CDMA to the analog. It works extremely well. When GSM was brought in we were told-and you believed it, as I believed it at the time-that the digital process would use a much narrower spectrum, therefore we would have more services. The truth is that by batching up like that you only have to hold your digital phone near your radio to hear the interference. Because of that large signal they cannot get them close together. Analog has just gone on developing because the rest of the world can see the value of it. What is happening in the cities? In the cities you can use an analog frequency here with a low level aerial and one block away you can reuse the same frequency. You cannot do that with digital. Analog ends up having many advantages that were not seen at the time. What we are talking about is a commercial decision. This is not going to end here. Don't kid yourself. This is a big battle. People are not going to be deprived of the analog systern, and there is going to be a conflict. There is going to be a court case. Why in heaven's name would anyone, knowing there is going to be litigation, give away goodies like this? What we are talking about is bargaining chips with Vodafone and Optus. They are simply bargaining chips because they are asking us to make allowances for them when they agreed to it in the first place. Why should we do that? That is tradeable. When the court case comes about and eventually sanity does prevail and we do maintain the analog, I expect Telstra will once more be milked to pay Vodafone off. But the bill will be a lot less if we say to them, 'You agreed to those conditions. This is a commercial decision.' Let us face it: Vodafone are not going to provide service in the country, nor are Optus. The member says that he was briefed recently. I can tell you this: I have a real battle in my electorate with television: Optus decided we had to go to digital television-for very good reasons, but it was their idea. Telstra beat them to the punch and got the system up and running. So what did Optus do? Optus, loaded as it is with ex-staffers from the Labor Party, went into political mode and set about lying to everybody. When you get briefed, sir, be very careful. The only people I know who will give an accurate briefing an technical matters are in Telstra. The others lie their heads off. The truth is this: you say, 'We're going to have competition in communications.' What a lot of nonsense! The Labor Party gave away a great swag of property of the people of Australia to Optus. It gave them basically free entry. What you are doing is you are not having free entry of the technology. In the United - States they say, 'Let the technology fall where it may.' Let us have that in Australia. Let us have free technology. If you do that, somebody will introduce CDMA. It will probably be Hutchisons. It will certainly be Telstra. They will certainly do it. They know they can marry their analog servke and give you a single service. Right across the bottom of Australia you have a line of microwaves. This is technology of 30 years ago. It was a great improvement. I can remember when all the telecommunications between east and west were carried on six hard wires across the Nullarbor. Then they brought in microwave and opened it almost exponentially. That is now out of date. We now have glass fibres in. Those towers - are there. I suggest that the cost of pulling those towers down is greater than the scrap value. It would be better to leave those towers there, attach analog to them and provide an analog service across Australia-a whole new vast area of Australia would open up. But that can only be done with analog because the towers are too far apart for digital. Mr Hockey-For 10 people.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: And all the people who travel. What you have forgotten is thisMr Hockey-They're citizens.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: North Sydney is a classic case: there is not a city in this country that lives on its intrinsic worth. They all live on the sweat of the wealthy hinterland. Sydney produces nothing. It is those people out there that you despise that keep you in your comfort, - and you should realise that. It will not be realised by Vodafone. It will not be realised by Optus. And I can tell you this: when the community service obligation is given to government of any shade, Liberal or Labor, it will be cut away to nothing because governments in this country-Liberal and Labor-know that if they can win in Sydney and Melbourne the rest of the country does not matter in the shoft term. Mr Neville interjecting

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: You, sir, have been sitting there quite contentedly . You say we had an opportunity at the time. Yes, we did. We were misinfonned. We now know better. It is a city thing not to change your mind when you have more information. We have the information now: we know that CDMA is a far better system than GSM. We know that if we remove the barriers, CDMA will be brought in here, certainly by Telstra, almost certainly by Hutchisons. It will give us a seamless connection. You people talk as though analog was somehow inferior. Analog has advanced by leaps and bounds since those days. Analog now carries about the same data transmission capability. It can .be encrypted. It speaks of service that most people do not want. But the big thing is that in the United States the message is there: where people have the option they have opted for analog because of the longer service. The fact is that analog gives you line of sight. That is why it gets a longer service. When you see these figures put forward they are fictional figures because they talk about phone numbers, not geographical area. Remember this: if Telstra were to go around and put analog services on all the places they have installed digital, there would be an enormous increase in coverage area. It would increase rapidly again. The cost of that is infinitesimal.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: It's there already.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Of course it is there already. What we are talking about really is freedom of technology. Let the technology fall where it may. But you have a government guided by Public Service and vested interests that say, 'Oh no, we think GSM is the best technology.' It may have been at the time. It has been passed by. But Vodafone only has that technology. Optus only has that technology. Let the technology fall where it may. What I am saying is irrefutable. There is no doubt of that. You cannot disprove what I am saying because it is factual. On that basis, battIe is far from over. This government will turn off analog at its peril. There is going to be a court case. Let us have the court case; let us pay Vodafone out. But they will not get anything like as much as they are expecting if we leave these provisions in the act. Why would we give them this, knowing we are going to litigation? Why would we give these goodies out to them? It makes no sense at all. For this reason the member for Calare (Mr Andren) has done a service to the people of Australia. What the member for Cal are is doing is, unlike the member for North Sydney . (Mr Hockey), looking at the taxpayers of Australia. We are going to have this battIe. There is going to be compensation paid. It will be greatly reduced if we do not give away these goodies now. There is absolutely no doubt that CDMA technology is better. You cannot keep it out forever. It is only the CDMA technology that gives you the seamless connection. Themember for Hinkler (Mr Neville), I think, was talking about the satellite. The cost of the satellite is very high. The service is there now; it is true. It is very expensive. It is all right for mining companies and people in the Aboriginal industry who have their bills paid by the taxpayer. It is no good for the general public. It is a useful tool, but it will not replace the CDMA system. If you have transmission by satellite, it will almost certainly be CDMA anyway. It will be in that format because of that ability to have the seamless connection between analog anJ the CDMA. You cannot have it with a GSM system. It is simply technically not possible. Telstra have been working on it and one has to admire Telstra's ability. They say they are looking to double the length to which the GSM signal will go. It is actually going to have the number of lines available. In remote areas that does not matter. Optus, on the other hand, say, 'We are not bothering with that technology, we do not think it will work.' It is obviously in some doubt about it, but still it is going to be a very second best option. For heaven's sake, common sense says that the system is working, it gives much better coverage, and the only thing it does not really this provide is security. Most people do not care about that. I am one of those people. I do not really care who listens to my phone calls because I have got nothing to hide. This is a system working now; it covers a lot of Australia-the CDMA technology which the government is conspiring with the Labor Party to stop entering Australia. They are holding us back by planting the technology. It is meaningless to say we are going to have free enterprise and competition if you keep a rein on the technology, because it is simply within the one paper bag. Mr Neville-It's not going to rein in the technology.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Of course it is because CDMA will not be allowed in this country because the guarantee is that this country will have GSM. I can tell you now that Vodafone and Telstra are terrified of CDMA. They simply do not have the technology. For that reason, the agreement in Australia is that the digital service will be GSM. Why will we be taking the analog out anyway? The answer is simple: we are taking the analog out because GSM cannot compete. It is as simple as that. Don't you understand? We are taking this out because the companies say, 'We sold you a pup. We sold you a French system and you bought it, but we cannot make this work against the analog; therefore, you have got to remove the analog.' That is why it is being removed. GSM cannot compete with the digital. If it can, if it is a superior technology, then let the cards fall where they may. Let both play. Mr Hockey-You know that Telstra would dominate the market.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Telstra gives a good service to remote areas, unlike your friends. It does not matter what you say to your friends. I know Vodafone in your electorate and I know that they look after you very well, but I have to think about the interests of Australia. The fact is that it is simple, it is as clear as day. If the technology is superior, it will beat the analog. It cannot beat the analog, therefore, you must remove it. The people will not cop that. This government at the end of the day will be faced with such outrage that it will back down, it will be faced with litigation, it will be faced with compensation. For heaven's sake, do not give away these trump cards now. If the member for North Sydney cannot understand the logic of that, it is just as well he comes from a legal background, because he never would have survived in business. I just want to say this: we have heard a lot from this government about the community service obligation and, if the Labor Party were in government, we would hear the same from them. The reality is this-and people in the bush understand this intuitively-if the community service obligation is an off budget payment, if it has left the government, it will diminish and diminish and diminish. They will say, like the member for North Sydney, 'But there is no-one out there. There are only a handful of people.' That will be their mentality because what we have in Australia today is a political system where there is no real conflict between Liberal and Labor. You are, as the member for Moore (Mr Filing) said, Tweedledum and Tweedledumber. The real battle developing in Australia is between rural Australia, which creates the wealth, and urban Australia, which spends it. That is the battle that has to be fought in this country and this is part of that battle, because communication is vital in maintaining some sort of equity in this country. We have seen infrastructure in this country gutted in country areas. We have seen it gutted right through the country. We have seen no real enthusiasm from the present government to restore it. It was gutted by Labor and not restored by this government, and it will not be. There will be continual pressure on infrastructure in the country areas. That is why communication is absolutely vital. What we are saying is that we know we get a good service with analog. It works over a much wider area. Digital does not work. In my own town of KalgoorIie, Telstra tells me that they have got the digital coverage. I know, because I live there, that I only have to go out of town on the north side and the coverage ceases. They said, 'But we put a system in Coolgardie and now you can get coverage all the way.' They might have much more powerful receivers than I have, because I cannot get that coverage. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: I have been very interested in some of the comments in this debate and it is good to see the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) here. The member for Kalgoorlie was speaking very passionately this morning in the Main Committee about child support. He was referring to France's child-support arrangements, and I noticed he was just talking about the French system of mobile phones. He obviously must be spending too much time with the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) if he is using the French analogy. The debate today though is about this motion that was moved by the member for Calare (Mr Andren). I think it is important to go back and look at some of the contributions, particularly those by the member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay), the member for Calare and the member for Kalgoorlie. As previous speakers from the coalition side have stated, the whole reason we are in this predicament about analog phones is that the legislation that was put in place was put in place in 1992 by the Australian Labor Party. They put that in place. Not only did they do that, they compounded the problem when it came to pay TV. They legislated to have two cable TV carriers, and an enormous amount of public capital was put in place with Optus and Telstra. The reason for some of these changes to Vodafone is clear. When you look back at the Optus case, they were forced by legislationagain, that was poor policy by the Australian Labor Party-they did not have enough equity and they had to raise more capital through their British company. The whole indignity here of the Australian Labor Party is that, firstly, this is diminishing the communications systems to rural Australia and, secondly, increasing foreign ownership. Let us look at foreign ownership and let us look at foreign debt.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Let's look at telephones.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: We will get back to that, but that was the point introduced by the member for Watson. Let us look at the number of companies that were sold. Lifesavers and Allens went to Rowntree. Speedo and Tooheys Castlemaine were sold to New Zealand. King Gee and Stubbies went to the USA. Sidchrome went to the USA. A big chunk of Fairfax media went to Canada. The Ten Network went to Canada. A big chunk of Qantas went to the UK. Other big names to be sold were Brashs, Aeroplane Jelly, Amotts, BTR Nylex, National Mutual-another French company-Peters ice cream, Eagles and on it goes, particularly in the rural sector and particularly in the telecommunications sector. So do not come inhere and parade the virtues of Australian ownership when you have just about sold the whole farm. What we are trying to do is let people who are staying on the farm have a proper communications system to help get them through to the next century. So we come back to AMPS. The decision was made in 1992 by the Australian Labor Party to phase out AMPS by the year 2000. In a very courageous decision on 5 February this year we introduced legislation, and I will quote from the Australian Communications Authority in relation to this. The member for Kalgoorlie should listen to this, as should the member for Cal are, because if a review is being done now on Mount Canobolas, the member for Calare should be putting in a submission. In February 1998 the Australian Communications Authority said that a number of packages were announced for regional Australia which currently receive mobile phone coverage. If they do not receive adequate digital coverage beyond the year 2000, then the analog system will remain and it will remain until there is a proper GSM digital coverage. What could be more appropriate policy-particularly for our rural party and members of the Liberal Party in rural Australit is is-than ensuring that there are adequate communication facilities, whether you are sitting out the back of Orange, whether you are in Kalgoorlie or whether you are in a suburb of Sydney, but they have pretty good communications systems there already.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: What about Perth?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Or in Perth, I should mention that. So some good policy initiatives have been introduced by this government to ensure that regional areas are taken into account.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: No, that was not introduced by the Labor Party. That was introduced by us recently.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: You were conned. You were in ,the Labor Party and you voted with them and you have acknowledged that.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: I was not in the Labor Party. I never have been and I never will be. I obviously must have made an impression on the member for Kalgoorlie because he thinks I have been here for a long time, but I only came in at the last election. Let us take on board what was said by the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville). He talked about the actual coverage of analog. It is 93.8 per cent at the moment and digital is'94.1 per cent. I acknowledge that these are not the actual number of people and does not take into account people in remote areas, but the fact is that it is a wider coverage. What we are trying to do is enhance that coverage and make sure that the bush areas that do not have adequate coverage will continue to get coverage beyond the year 2000-whether it is through Vodafone, Optus, Telstra or new carriers that will come into the place

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Why not keep analog then?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: We have. We have said that-until they are covered by an adequate GSM system. We have actually said that. Are you blind to it? We have actually done that. If you are a farmer, one of the reasons for digital is that you can get other services. You can get data transfer, you can get the Internet, you can get a whole bunch of stuff-and a lot of it you cannot get on analog. That is why we want a better system. That is why, when we privati sed part of Telstra, a big chunk of that-$250 million-went back into building regional telecommunications infrastructure. I suspect, when the next tranche is sold, there will be another commitment to put money back. As the member for Kalgoorlie knows, when the Labor Party was in governmentwhen they privati sed Qantas, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratory and the icon, the Commonwealth Bank-it went back into recurrent expenditure.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Just watch where your old man puts the money then.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: That is a good point. I am glad he is bringing up the history of the coalition. In 1983, when the Labor Party got into power, they reduced a lot of the foreign ownership requirements. Instead of having 51 per cent Australian ownership in the North West Shelf, as you well know, it was the Labor Party that reduced it. That is why we have a lot of foreign carriers here. The member for Hinkler also made some very good points about sovereignty. As the member for Kalgoorlie knows, there is a huge amount of Australian investment and a huge amount of foreign investment in the mining industry-in your industry, Graeme. Your people are working there because of foreign investment. To use Vodafone as a bargaining chip-it is populist; it has a nice ring about it-is poor policy and you cannot just blackmail Vodafone. Can you imagine blackmailing some of your mining companies like that? You cannot do that. That is the problem with it. A policy was put in place by the previous government. Now they are trying to renege on that and trying to use it as a bargaining chip. Let us follow that argument through. Even if you achieve that, if Vodafone maintain this analog system and they do not put in any digital system

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: It only remains for me to indicate to the House the government's position with regard to the motion moved by the member for Calare (Mr Andren). In the summing up it is not usual to thank honourable members, but I think it has been an interesting debate. If we remove some of the emotion from it, I think that there are lots of issues there and members have had a good opportunity to canvass them. The government takes the view that it will not support Mr Andren's motion. The declaration that he seeks to overturn basically is designed to remove from Vodafone the licence condition requiring it to achieve majority Australian ownership by 1 July 2003. It gives effect to the decision by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 14 August last year wherein the government decided to remove, with immediate effect from the date of that announcement, the foreign ownership restrictions that are specific to Optus and Vodafone and that all proposals by foreign interests to invest in Optus and Vodafone would be subject only to the general applicable provisions of foreign investment policy. Essentially, the application of the contrary-to-thenational-interest test under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act would apply. We considered that it was no longer necessary to constrain foreign involvement in and Vodafone and that, from the point of the announcement of 14 August, foreign involvement of these two entities would be treated the same as cases involving the establishment of new entrants to the telecommunications sector. While prior approval is required, proposals would normally be approved unless judged contrary to the national interest. The government considers that it is important from the competition viewpoint that participants in the telecommunications sector not be unnecessarily constrained by foreign investment regulation. That is the basis of what we are talking about today. That is the reason why this is before the House and why we reject Mr Andren's motion. I will address some of the points in the broad. The original proposal was in the Telecommunications Act 1991. I have not had the opportunity to re-read my own speeches from that time but, to the best of my recollection, Minister Kelly was the minister who took advice and made the decision that there should be a change and a commitment to a new GSM technology and that we would move progressively to a universal application of the digitalised use of GSM technology by the year 2000. The reason for that was to provide additional competition and better utilisation of the finite resource of the spectrum. There were at the time some concerns about determining technology usage so far out, and I think those of us who voiced concerns at the time have been proved to be correct. Indeed, if the decision by the people of Australia in 1993 had been different, there may well have been an opportunity to have a look at it at that stage. The legislation in section 70 provided the opportunity for agreements to be entered into between the government and putative carriers. Minister Collins was the minister at the time-1992-who entered into a section 70 agreement. The section 70 agreement-the actual agreement, being a commercial agreement-was not available to the opposition at the time. But we now find ourselves-some years having gone along, V odafone having been awarded a licence and there being substantial investment for the roll-out to meet the objectives of the 1991 act-in the position where there is a real legal risk that action can be taken under the compensation on just terms arrangements under the acquisitions provisions of the constitution. The extent of the pay-out for these situations is arguable, but if we look at the roll-out of the exclusive digital facility provided by Vodafone it is well over $1 billion. Mr Campbell interjecting

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: I think it would be nice if you just let me finish, Graeme. That is the reason we are proceeding in the way that we are. The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) made the decision last year that we would continue with the commitment to have a. universal digitised approach to the mobile phone system, but we made an announcement at that stage that it would be subject to safeguards. That brings me to the next issue that was the subject of discussion by colleagues, that is, the use of the technology. I do not want to enter into a detailed overview of that.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: You don't know.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS
text: Perhaps I do. The first point I would make is that satellite opportunities, prospectively provided by Iridium, Globalstar, lCO and Elipso will be coming on stream--September this year will see Iridium start-and that will provide an opportunity. The arrangements with regard to the proposed auction in July this year of the spectrum-that is, the 800 megahertz and the 1.8 gigahertz areas-will leave some spectrum. Half the new spectrum will become available to new service providers which will be able to utilise whatever technology they decide. It could be code division multiple access or time division multiple access which will see the capacity for the utilisation of dual handsets which are available now. I think some members have made reference to these matters. The residual amps spectrum in the regional areas will see the emergence of possible dual operation. The other major point was made by my colleague the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts in his press release of 5 February which recognised that there is a capacity to utilise the amps spectrum in regional and remote Australia in a continuing way beyond the year 2000. It is to be subject to an immediate Australian Communications. Authority review-it was described as an urgent review to be completed by 30 June this year-to examine, in each regional area, concurrent services where they currently receive amps service; to determine whether the phase-out of the amps could leave that area without an alternative mobile coverage; and to offer a quality of service and breadth of coverage reasonably equivalent. So the opportunity is to be pursued. We made known by way of this announcement that, where there cannot be agreement between the carriers for ongoing amps coverage-and remember Vodafone do not have an analog system; they only have a digital system-we will retain for ourselves the capacity to give further directions to existing carriers to mandate that there should be a service in those areas. We will also consider mandating roaming between parts of the GSM networks which are installed under those rollout obligations if it is technically feasible and commercially appropriate as this may be a very practical way of reducing the cost to the three carriers given the expansion of GSM coverage. We recognise that there is an issue here. We are looking for a common sense approach, a practical approach, utilising the emergence of the technologies. The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) spoke eloquently about these matters. We are looking for some ways in which that can be accommodated within the proposals. I recommend that you look closely at the 5 February statement by the minister. There is an understanding of the issues, particularly in regional and remote Australia, surrounding the utility of the amps systems. As we stand here today we do not know, as the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) mentioned, the extent to which we will see price movements in the low orbit satellites and the middle orbit satellites in the very near future. That may be a solution that will solve, in part, some of these problems. I assure honourable members that the minister, the department and I are fully aware of the challenges that the decision in 1991 delivers to this country. Whilst I can understand the approach taken by the member for Cal are in his motion, the government could not, in reality, given its need to address the broad responsibilities it has to taxpayers, take a conscious decision which could cause it to enter into litigation which it would be sure to lose and which would have the consequence of an extremely large cost that it would need to bear. For those reasons, the government will not be supporting the motion for disallowance. Question put: That the motion (Mr Andren's) be agreed to. The House divided. Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: Canberra) (6.23 p.m.)Let us remember what it is that we are dealing with, and I will then conclude my remarks on this piece of legislation, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Superannuation) Bill. What we are dealing with here is a bill which is innocuous in its appearance, but which, for those people who are affected, is very significantly detrimental. This bill says that superannuation is no longer an allowable matter in awards. In future, it may be that most people can enter into arrangements that will put their superannuation arrangements which are not covered by the superannuation guarantee legislation in certified agreements or other such arrangements. Not everybody will, and if time permits, I will come to that. Most evidently, tens of thousands of Australians will be affected. The figure might be more than 100,000, if you could get behind the figures and find all the individual cases. But it is on the record, uncontested, that tens of thousands of low paid Australians will be affected-people working part time and casually in the hospitality industry and the textile, clothing and footwear industry, earning less than $450 a month. These are not fat cats that we are talking about; these are usually second income earners, mainly women, in families, battling to make arrangements that will enable them to assist in funding their and their family's retirement. If this bill is passed, it will mean that people will, from 1 July or from when this bill takes effect, lose their superannuation entitlement because they are not covered by the superannuation guarantee legislation, as they earn below the threshold. Imagine if what we were saying involved an Australian who owned a piece of property and we were going to pass a law and take it away. There would be an outcry. But all the people affected by this are people in weak bargaining positions, otherwise they would not be affected by it. They would be able to get their superannuation rights by virtue of their bargaining strength or under the superannuation guarantee legislation. Tens of thousands of Australians who currently have a legally enforceable entitlement and, each month, have money going into their superannuation account, will all lose. The government promised that no-one would be worse off. The government promised that no-one would lose their award entitlements. The government promised, 'Your superannuation will be secure.' There are tens of thousands of Australians who, under this bill, will lose, and nobody wins. It is not one of those circumstances where you can say there is a cost benefit. Maybe the benefit to others is such that the loss to these people can be justified. But the problem is that, first and foremost, the losers are the weakest, not the strongest. This is not a case of redistribution by the government in order to try to assist people in the weaker position. This is a case of the weak losing. The government often talks about the terrible circumstances imposed in industrial relations by powerful unions and portrays themsel ves as the defenders against the strength of powerful unions. I can tell you that nobody in a strong union, nobody in a strong industrial relations bargaining position, is getting caught under this. It is often the people in very good, well-organised unions but which do not have industrial strength. That is why they are on such low incomes. It is why they have had the award as their underpinning. There has been substantial research done in these two industries where you do not find highly paid workers-the hospithose tality industries, the clothing, textile and footwear industries-and they are losing. What worries us is that this is part of the emerging pattern of Australian industrial relations. As regulation is pulled out, what inevitably happens-not just in industrial relations, but that is the matter that we are dealing with at the moment-is that those in the weakest positions lose. As the framework of regulation is withdrawn, as the potential for, in this instance, the Industrial Relations Commission to intervene in the interests of fairness on behalf of those who are not in strong bargaining positions is withdrawn, as we enter into free bargaining, those with the most bargaining power win and those in the weakest positions lose. If that is the world you are trying to achieve, you should vote for this bill. But if you think that Australians have a broader sense of fairness and there ought to be some protections in place for the weak, the powerless, those who cannot otherwise enforce their rights, you should oppose this bill. As I said, who is losing? Casual workers, part-time workers and, on all the evidence, predominantly women workers, in the main earning less than $450 a month. People are excluded from the superannuation guarantee legislation for other :r;easons, not just because they fall below the $450 per month threshold. Sometimes they lose because of age or the nature of their industrial classifisuperannuation cation. People can and do lose, or do not gain, under the superannuation guarantee legislation, which has been a great leveller, a great equaliser, in superannuation. It has done a lot of good, but it cannot solve all the problems. This bill is saying, 'If you don't get caught under that act, too bad.' The other side is to say that superannuation is no longer an industrial relations matter which the Industrial Relations Commission is entitled to arbitrate. It cannot make an award about this. So in the circumstances where there is a dispute about superannuation, the Industrial Relations Commission will not be in the circumstance to resolve it. This is not a new matter; this is a matter we have been drawing to the government's attention since it first proposed to withdraw superannuation from allowable matters for awards in the first half of 1996. It is now nearly two years that we have been saying, why is it, given that the guarantee that was given in the pre-election policy called Better Pay for Better Work explicitly stated that existing award superan-lUation entitlements would be guaranteed minimum for all workplace agreements, that, under that circumstance, none of these 26,000 employees, or others in similar circumstances who entered into a workplace agreement, will be guaranteed any superannuation benefits at all? Many employees, especially those with little or no bargaining power, will suffer a manifest injustice. You cannot pass a law to say that there should not be any disputes about certain matters. Disputes arise when employers and employees cannot agree, and Australia has a traditional method of reconciling those disputes, that is, in the Industrial Relations Commission, and their findings can be and often are incorporated in awards. Where is the mischief that is caused by superannuation being an allowable award matter? Where is the crisis that is emerging? Where is the damage that is being suffered? Even if you read the arguments of the advocates, what they say is, 'This ought to be done by agreement or ought to be left to the guarantee legislation.' Some people fall through the cracks in the superannuation guarantee legislation, excellent legislation that it is. I am glad the Liberal Party finally gave up its opposition to it and allowed it to continue. It is excellent legislation and a very important part of increasing savings in Australia and improving the equity of access to superannuation. It has transformed superannuation in this country. The government has other measures which are going to undermine it, make it worse, fragment it and deny access to lower income Australians, but they are not before us in this bill. The package of them will make superannuation less fair in this country. It will make low income Australians and low income Australian families less secure in their retirement. It will take away, for no benefit and for no advantage to any other Australians, the rights of these people. It is a very strange concept. It is not something that I thought anybody came into this parliament to do, that is, to say, 'I have a clever idea. I'm going to pass a law to take away some of your rights.' But that is what we are doing here. We are doing it explicitly in breach of the commitment which the government made before the election in Better Pay for Better Work and in speeches by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), then the Leader of the Opposition. If you had to sum up what Australian working people felt about superannuation, what they would say is, 'Stop changing the system. There have been too many changes already. Let it remain as it is. It is complex, but we know what our entitlements are now. Stop changing the system.' But this government cannot stop fiddling. There will be other legislation to follow this legislation. I say: do not pass this legislation, which achieves no positive purpose. All it does is take away legitimate rights and aspirations from low income Australians, for no benefit, and it should accordingly be rejected. Debate (on motion by Mr Andrew) adjourned. Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (6.37 p.m.)-I move: That the amendment be agreed to. I would like to make a few comments about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.5) 1997 and the amendment made by the Senate. The amendment replaces the term 'bubble jet' in proposed subsection 91C(1) with a reference to 'ink-jet' in order to clarify the types of printers which will be considered as part of 7A goods. While the term 'bubble jet' has become synonymous with the term 'ink-jet' in describing a type of printer that operates by a stream of ink being shot onto paper, it has been brought to the government's attention that the term 'bubble jet' may be associated with one particular manufacturer. The amendment merely clarifies that all types of printers which operate by a stream of ink will be part of 7A goods.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: PRODUCTIVITY COMMISSION BILL
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (6.39 p.m.)-I move: That the amendments be agreed to. The Productivity Commission Bill 1996 was passed by the Senate on Monday, 30 March 1998 after the Senate had made a relatively large number of amendments. In particular, amendments have been made to the functions of the commission provisions, clause 6; the general policy guidelines for the commission, clause 8; the commissioner appointment provisions, clause 30; the meetings of the commission provisions, clause 43; and the engagement of the consultants provision, clause 49. While some of the amendments are significant, the government considers that overall the amendments do not affect the integrity of the bill. Hence, the government accepts the Senate's amendments. Parliamentary consideration of the bill has been both slow and difficult. The government is keen to complete the process so that the commission can settle down and focus on promoting policies at both the government and business levels to improve the competitiveness and dynamism of the Australian industry. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: PRODUCTIVITY COMMISSION BILL
text: We will not be opposing the amendments which have been put forward, which strike us as neither improving nor diminishing the legislation or the operations of the Productivity Commission generally. We want to place on the record that the opposition has not seen the Productivity Commission as the most appropriate vehicle for conducting industry policy. Indeed, a resolution was carried at the Labor Party National Conference in Hobart in January of this year to the effect that a Labor government would abolish the Productivity Commission. That was certainly a resolution that I was happy to support. Applying the Productivity Commission's own yardstick to these matters, it takes the view that any industries which are not world's best practice and are not seen to be efficient, effective and productive ought to be put out pasture. In recent times, the Productivity Commission has delivered reports on the future of the motor vehicle industry and the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. Those reports have been rejected by the government. They have been rejected by the government because the Labor opposition, employers, unions and state governments mounted a concerted campaign against those recommendations, which were out of step with the need for Australia to have a modern manufacturing industry. Those recommendations would have led to the demise of the motor vehicle industry and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries in this country, with the loss of many jobs and to some extent the loss of national sovereignty-our capacity to produce the things which sustain us and make us prosper. Those recommendations were of very little value. The Howard government-under sustained pressure, let me say-decided to reject those recommendations. If the best that the Productivity Commission can come up with is recommendations which get rejected, it does not seem to us that it has much of a future. That is Labor's view concerning the Productivity Commission. Having said those things, as I said, these amendments are not in and of themselves controversial and, therefore, we will not be opposing them. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: I am pleased to be here tonight to see the government agree to these amendments that have come from the Senate. These are very important amendments that have been made to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 which will see significant improvements made to the youth allowance. I am sorry to say that the most important amendments moved by Labor in the Senate were rejected by this government. Those amendments were to maintain the age of independence for unemployed young people at 18. Young people will now be treated as dependent on their parents until they reach the age of 21. This is a very retrograde step for young p-ople, who are trying to make the best of it out there in a very difficult employment market and finding it very hard to get a job. They are now being told by this government that, if their parents earn more than $23,500, their unemployment benefits will be reduced. This will see significant disruptions emerge in families. But, on the positive side, there are some improvements in this legislation as a result of the amendments that we are now considering. As I said, it is pleasing that the government has decided to accept them. We had a series of provisions in the bill when it was before the House and before the Senate that would have seen unemployed people and students face a whole range of different notification provisions. Anyone having had anything to do with the Department of Social Security would by the know how important it is to have clear requirements rather than rules saying in one instance that you could be notified in writing and in another that you could be notified orally. Some of these rules required seven days, others 14 days. Frankly, it was a mess. As a result of the amendments moved by the opposition, this has now been cleaned up. People will now have notifications sent out in writing and be given 14 days notice. That is a significant improvement. Another amendment that is also very important and which we on the Labor side are very pleased about is that young people who are unemployed and under the age of 18 will now be able to receive unemployment benefits-if they are willing and able to participate in case management. We did not want to see a situation where young people who, for whatever reason, would not or could not go back to school found themselves without any means of support. It is very significant that the government has decided to accept this amendment, to ensure that young people under the age of 18 who are unemployed and for whatever reason cannot go back to school will in fact be helped to get work. That is critical issue: they want to work. Theyneed to be helped to get work and not be left with absolutely nothing-which was, of course, the original intention of the government. The Labor opposition also moved an amendment in relation to the age of independence for students. We moved, and got a commitment from the Senate, that the independence age for students should be progressively reduced from 25 over time. The age of 25 for students is unrealistic and it is a commitment that I know students will be very pleased to see. There is also a very important change to the rules about work attachment when determining whether or not a young person is independent. The government originally said that a young person had to have worked for 18 months since leaving school, and to have earned 50 per cent of average weekly earnings in that period. That was a completely unrealistic expectation to put on young people, given the job opportunities that are out there and the wages that are paid to young people these days. What this amendment does is soften the criterion so that a person now needs to have earned the lower amount, represented by 75 per cent of the maximum Commonwealth training award. (Extension of time granted) These changes are very significant and important and, as I said, I am very pleased that the government has seen fit to make these amendments. Most unfortunately, the most significant amendment was rejected by the government. It was about the issue of the age of independence for young unemployed people. It is not the case that families with incomes between $23,500 and $42,000 are well off, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) likes to say. They are not well off and families with an income of $35,000, with young unemployed adults aged between 18 and 20 in them, will, from 1 July, be $55 a week worse off. Young unemployed people will find themselves $55 a week shorter in their unemployment benefits and having to front up to mum and dad, who do not have a high family income, to get the money out of them. Not surprisingly, parents of adults expect the those young people to be out there supporting themselves-out there in the work force, trying to make the best of it and trying to earn their own living. The reason we pay unemployment benefits is that these young people cannot find a job. As we know, this government has not moved youth unemployment rates at all. They are stuck at 26 per cent, and this measure is not going to do anything whatsoever to improve youth unemployment. All it is going to do is make families worse off, make family relationships more difficult and make life for young unemployed people that much more difficult. It is a measure which the government should reconsider. We would call upon them to come back into the parliament as soon as possible to reduce the age of independence for young unemployed people to recognise that ,these people are indepengent and that they do not live in families that can afford to see their family incomes reduced by anything from $55 to over $80 a week. That is just putting the burden of unemployment on to low and middle income families. That is what this government is all about with this measure that we are debating again tonight. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: TAX LAW IMPROVEMENT BILL
text: Braddon-Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister) (6.56 p.m.)-in reply-I would just like to make some summing up comments on the debate which has been held on this matter. I would like to express the government's appreciation for the report tabled on 12 March by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, report No. 356, entitled An advisory report on the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No.2) 1997. It is the fifth by the committee on the rewriting of the income tax law, and the fourth which specifically covers the tax law improvement project. The joint committee's ongoing involvement in the review of the work of the project has been important in ensuring the quality of the rewrite and public confidence in the rewrite process. The government is accepting all of the committee's recommendations for technical changes to the bill. The government has also made changes to the explanatory memorandum along the lines recommended by the be committee. There is a table in the supplementary explanatory memorandum setting out these changes to the bill and explanatory memorandum. The government is considering other recommendations in report No. 356 that go to wider policy matters and will provide responses on those other matters later on. I would like to underline the importance the to government attaches to the work of the tax law improvement project and our desire that this bill-the third instalment of the rewritebe passed by 30 June so that it can start to apply for the 1998-99 income year. The joint committee supports this commencement date. The main feature of the bill is the rewritten capital gains tax rules. They are much clearer than the existing law and contain positive changes that taxpayers should be able to benefit from as early as possible. The bill also contains rewrites of the provisions about intellectual property, company bad debts, horticultural plants, environmental expenditure, the averaging of primary producers' tax liabilities and evening out the effects of the above average income of some professionals. These rewrites also include some minor policy changes which will help to make the law simpler, clearer and less burdensome for the taxpayers. I would like to underline the thanks of the government to the people who have been working on this Tax Law Improvement Bill. It has been going on for quite a substantial amount of time, and a lot of work is going into this. Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
