Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.7) 1997 contains a large number of unrelated taxation matters, including in particular relating to the introduction of the new government savings rebate scheme, on which I will have something to say, together with a major proposed change to the superannuation system, known as the 'choice regime', on which I will have rather less to say, leaving the primary carriage of this to the shadow parliamentary secretary, the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson). This debate takes place against the background of the so-called tax reform debate taking place in Australia at the moment. I say 'so-called' because there is no debate really taking place, and that is for the reason that the government, specifically the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello), refuse to participate in one. As recently as Wednesday, the Treasurer specifically refused to debate me in this House on the question of what the government was going to do about the growing use of trusts for tax avoidance purposes, leaving it to honourable members rather lower down the food chain to defend the government's honour in this respect. The Treasurer refused invitation from the ABC-not for the first time-to debate with me again the same issue last week on the 7.30 Report. It is a fair question as to why the government will not come clean on this issue. Why has the promised discussion paper on the taxation of trusts been suppressed? Is it because so many coalition frontbenchers trusts? Is it because so many coalition backabolish benchers have trusts and there would be a party room revolt if the government were do something decent and effective about avoidance in this area? Is it because of other deal that we know nothing about? We have the ludicrous situation where these two leaders, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of the government, are constantly denigrating Australia's tax system generally through false claims or wild exaggerations the scale of particular problems, yet they absolutely refuse to tell us what they are planning to do. What they are engaged in is a concerted effort to falsely worry Australian businessmen and families that the Australian taxation system is broken. We know, and we have certainly argued; that that is patently untrue. The truth of the matter is that the system is in very much better shape than was when Labor came into power in the early 1980s. Then it was fair to say that the tax system really was broken, and it was broken because of the negligent stewardship of then Treasurer, the current Prime Minister. It was not broken because the necessities table reform. of life-food, clothing, shelter and utility services-were exempt from tax. Rather, it was broken because paying tax was optional for those with access to specialist taxation advice. Then Treasurer Howard refused to act for years on the taxation advice provided by Tax Commissioner O'Reilly. He was, to put it at its most charitable, asleep at the or, rather worse, and I suspect more accuratesource ly, he was deliberately protecting a small minority of the community. The problems we confronted after 1983 when we came into office were, as a consea quence of that, quite enormous. For a start, capital gains were generally quite outside tax net. As a result, quite literally, the an could get richer without any contribution being made to the general community. It did fall to Labor to address that glaring anomaly, and we did so. What was the coalition's response to that issue? It was to oppose passage of the capital gains tax tooth and nail. When the present Prime Minister was campaigning in the 1987 election as the tpen have Leader of the Opposition, he proposed to capital gains tax imd to substitute a paltry so-called speculative gains tax which to only taxed gains made on assets bought and tax sold within a year. It was only when Dr some Hewson became opposition leader that the conservative side of politics was brought to the grudging and reluctant acceptance that a capital gains tax is an essential part of an equitable, modern taxation system. The second area where the tax system in of this country was genuinely broken when we came into office was in the area of fringe benefits. The law as it then existed attempted to include the value of non-cash benefits, but it was a joke to the tax planning industry. The provision could be avoided effortlessly, and it was consistently. This meant that executives could arrange their affairs to pay little or no tax . income tax whereas their employees had to it pay tax on all of their wages. In present value, billions of dollars of income avoided tax. It did fall to Labor again to fix that disgraceful anomaly. Again, the coalition, the under the leadership of the present Prime Minister, opposed that progressive and equiFortunately, the efforts of the coalition were unsuccessful in stopping real tax reform on those occasions, but it was not for want of trying. It should be recalled for the record that, on occasions like this when we succumb to daily bouts of hypocrisy on the subject of the present tax system, the coalition also wheel subsequently opposed the raft of foreign income measures which brought foreign income earned by Australians into the tax net for the first time. They also opposed the clampdown on the use of tax havens and number of other measures which have massively increased the fairness of the current the tax system. All of those reforms were rich achieved-it is important to emphasisewithout having to resort to the punishment of ordinary families when they do their shopping or pay their bills, as will of course happen under a GST. This objective of the Prime Minister's is despite the fact that prior to the last election he promised, in language that leaves absolutely no room for wriggle, that a GST would not be the future policy of the coalition. I think it is worth reading into the record what he said in that famous or-perhaps betternotorious doorstop at Tweed Heads on 2 May 1995: JOURNALIST: So you've left the door open for a GST now, haven't you? HOWARD: No, there's no way a GST will ever be part of our policy. JOURNALIST: Never, ever? HOWARD: Never ever. It's dead. It was killed by the voters at the last election. JOURNALIST:he was a very indefatigable journalistWere you misquoted in today's Australian then? HOWARD: Well, any suggestion that I left the door open is absolute nonsense. I didn't. I never will. The last election killed the GST. It's not part of our policy and it won't be part of our policy at any time in the future. JOURNALIST: If the concept of the GST comes up in the polls . . . would you go back and revisit that area, or look at it again? HOWARD: No ... No, because we are against it ... It is absolutely out of the question. A wry smile from the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) opposite. The truth of the matter is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, in committing themselves to this particular 'reform' of the tax system, are acting absolutely against what they said their stated policy was in an absolutely unprecedented way. A truly amazing thing about the current situation is that while the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are trying to build up a false case against the current system, arguing its decrepitude and unworkabiIity, they do steadfastly refuse to detail what they intend to propose to the Australian people. They are running around saying, 'The system is broke. It's terrible.' But they refuse to spell out even in broad terms what they are planning to do. They still refuse to admit what is supremely self-evident-that the main objective, the central objective, of their agenda is the introduction of a comprehensive GST. We have had a tax task force secretly meeting since last August. We have established that it has already spent over $1.2 million of public money, yet it keeps no record of its meetings. It meets without having formal agendas. All of the work that it produces, most importantly, is kept secret by the government. We know that the identification of the ,various options has already been completed. If the Treasurer is interested in a genuine, well-informed public tax debate all he has to do is release that information that has been generated by the task force, paid for with taxpayers' money, so that the community can evaluate the real options that are available. It is not necessarily a matter of putting down at this stage the government's own preferred approach to this, desirable as that would be. The most important thing is simply for the range of options that has already been generated, cos ted and quantified by the task force to be made public. Then the full range of those options can be known by the community. The worthiness of the government's package can be judged in its proper context, if and when it is released. Why is the government afraid of th-s process? Why don't we have an open, inclusive process, as we did in 1985, with the publication of a substantial draft white paper canvassing various options? The reason is, I suggest, that the government knows that its agenda simply will not stack up under detailed scrutiny. They know that the unfairness inherent in their basic objectives cannot be hidden. It certainly cannot be hidden if the facts are on the table for an extended period. So they refuse to put that information into the public arena. They want it out at the last possible moment. It is a clear strategy to avoid a real debate. It is not to engage in one. The government really does stand condemned for its cynicism. Looking at the particular provisions of this bill, which, as I say, are introduced against that background but do not tell us much what the ultimate tax package is going to be, there are a number of major proposals contained in the bill. I will quickly go through them, spending most time on the first, because it is the most substantial-the savings rebate. This was announced in the 1997-98 budget as a really, I have to say, pathetic substitute for Labor's national superannuation cocontribution regime, which was abandoned at the same time in that budget. The savings rebate is really a savings option in the context of that last budget. It certainly does not constitute a net gain to the vast majority of working Australians. Rather, it is an enormous future cost. Moreover, the abandonment of cocontribution was a deliberate repudiation of the solemn commitment that was given by this government prior to the last election that it would in fact honour the co-contribution proposed by Labor. Unless anyone is in doubt about that, let me quote from a speech by the then shadow Treasurer, Mr Costello, the member for Higgins, to the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia on 2 November 1995. He said: We will deliver the full tax dollars earmarked by the Budget back into superannuation or like vehicles on the schedule set down. We reserve the right to vary the mechanism to provide the most effective and equitable delivery of these dollars. Further details will be made known during the election period. But they will be paid in full. Minor variations, possibly, yes. Basic concept, basic dollars, clearly there committed. It was a classic example of a non-core promise, as we have come to understand all too unhappily in so many other contextspromises strongly delivered then abandoned when it is convenient to do so. Other people call them by their proper name, that is, broken promises-nothing more and nothing less than that. The crucial thing is that this particular deception of the Australian people is coming at a tremendous cost. The co-contribution was a visionary plan which would have massively increased the retirement income of future generations of Australians. It would have delivered security in retirement and would also have delivered Australia a huge increase in national savings in the future. On the first aspect of it, increasing security in retirement, the superannuation guarantee scheme, which will deliver superannuation contributions of nine per cent of people's income when it is fully implemented, is itself a tremendous base for adequate retirement income for average Australians. Even that was voted against by the coalition, just as they voted against any other decent reform in recent years. However, what needed to happen was the supplementation of that nine per cent base with another six per cent, three plus three, in order to provide completely adequate retirement income. That is exactly what the co-contribution regime was designed to do, and that is why its abandonment is such a tragedy for the Australian community. The effect of this has been estimated by the Commonwealth's retirement incomes modelling task force, or RIM task force, which estimated that a worker who was 35 years old in 1994-95 earning average weekly ordinary time earnings and who retires at age 65 would have had a superannuation benefit under our scheme of around $280,000 in real terms. However, without the benefit of the cocontribution regime, with its abandonment, that worker's final benefit will not be savings $280,000 but only $170,000 in the same dollars. This decision has cost that particular worker and millions of others around 40 per cent of his or her final retirement benefit and significantly reduced the standard of living capable of enjoyment by such workers in retirement. The fact that all of this has not been really widely understood in the community is absolutely no excuse for this appalling decision. The second area of lost opportunity in the government's decision here was the effect of that decision on the future level of national savings, which has just been devastating. With the Asian crisis about to beset us, indicating a very serious current account deficit problem in the future, it is even more vital that the level of national savings be maintained and that the whole burden of doing so not fall on public savings through the budget. The estimate by the RIM task force was that the co-contribution would have increased aggregate national savings by $400 billion over and above what it otherwise would have been by the year 2020. By this time it would have been increasing the level of national savings around two per cent of GDP per annum. We would have benefited both those in retirement and we would have benefited the nation by significantly increasing the pool of domestic savings, increasing the funds available of course for domestic investment and job creation. Instead of all that-and it has all been abandoned-we have now this savings tax offset known as the savings rebate. It will provide a rebate of 15 per cent of the tax that would otherwise be payable on up to $3,000 worth of non-salary and wage income earned after 1 July 1999. Non-deductible superannuation contributions do also qualify for this rebate, with a 7Y2 per cent rate applying for this 1998-99 year. The greatest irony, indeed tragedy, about the savings rebate is that it has little or nothing to do with improving savings. It really has nothing to do with increasing national savings nor with rewarding Australians in any very direct way for increasing their savings. It is, in fact, a subsidy to be paid to people who are deriving unearned income. If you work as an employee and receive salary or wages then you pay normal tax. But if you get considerable unearned income or business income, then you will get the benefit of this particular rebate, enabling you to pay $450 less tax a year. Ordinary employees, as a result, not only lose the higher level of retirement income that our co-contribution scheme would have delivered; they will also generally not qualify for the full $450. That is because the average interest earned by something over five million taxpayers, I understand, is less than $150 a year. If this were the only source of nonsalary and wage income, as it is for most people--earnings of interest and so on of that order of magnitude-then what you are talking about is only a savings rebate of around $22.50 or less than SOc a week, and only half of that for good measure in this current year of 1998-99. To pretend that the savings rebate is a major benefit to most people is quite simply a joke in bad taste. It is a device which lowers the tax for all types of unearned income-interest, dividends, trust and partnership distributions, rent and so on-and for superannuation pensions and eligible termination payments. It rewards people who are living off their savings rather than rewarding people for engaging in saving, other thanand there is an exception-in the case of direct superannuation contributions. The critical thing to understand about all this is that it can actually reward people who are engaged in dis-saving. On the assumption that people are earning, say, six per cent on the long-term bond rate on their savings at the moment, that means that so long as you have $50,000 invested somewhere you will be generating the $3,000 of unearned income which will enable you to receive the full rebate. That means, for example, if you started a year with $75,000 invested and ran down that capital so that at the end of the year you only had $50,000-in other words, if you dis-saved to the tune of $25,000-you could still collect the full $450 rebate. This is absolutely absurd and the second reading amendment that I will be moving at the conclusion of my remarks points up that particular absurdity. We have previously established in Senate estimates that the savings rebate will not result in an increase in national savings, according to the government's own retirement incomes modelling task force. That is an issue that we will be further pursuing and fleshing out in the Senate when this legislation gets there. The cost of the savings rebate to bupget is large. It is rising to over $2 billion in the year 2000-01; presumably it will grow still further in future years. One would have thought that the government would have been very proud of such an initiative. In fact the reverse was true. It will be remembered that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was so embarrassed that he would qualify for the full rebate that he announced in fact to this parliament on the day after the budget last year that he would not be claiming it. However, the problem for him became that the savings rebate will be calculated automatically. There is no provision for him not to claim the benefit. Indeed, advice from the bureaucracy indicated that to create a system that would allow the Prime Minister or anyone else to opt out would have cost some millions of dollars in administrative costs. Even though he knows it is unfair-knows it so well that he got up in public and said that he would not accept it-the Prime Minister will in fact benefit from this provision. That is why we consider not only this whole thing to be a nonsense but also that, if it was to applied at all, it should certainly have been done on the basis of a decent means test. Again, my second reading amendment goes to this point. Despite the measure being considered unfair by Labor, as it was and still is-that is, only rewarding those with savings related income-the savings rebate was in fact the centrepiece of last year's budget. We take the view that opposition to it in this place, or more significantly in the Senate, is inconsistent with Labor's general position that governments are entitled to their major budget measures, however wrong-headed those measures might be. Accordingly I do indicate now that the opposition does not propose to oppose this measure. We think it is very bad policy. We think it is a disgrace, certainly, compared with the company-contribution regime that it replaced. However, it is the government's measure for better or worse and we will not oppose it. I cannot let the debate pass on this issue without pointing out just one other thing-I have already mentioned it but I will emphasise it-that is, the savings rebate does also apply to distributions from trusts. Far from cracking down on trusts, the government is proposing to actually reward the use of trusts for income splitting by providing a further maximum additional benefit of $450 per trust beneficiary. So in the case of a trust with multiple beneficiaries-a family consisting of a husband, wife and, let us say, seven children-the family could obtain an additional benefit of nine times $450, or $4,050 a year. How that could possibly be in the national interest is beyond our ken. The second measure-and I will be much briefer about all these other elements in the bill-goes to distributions from private companies. It is long standing practice for private companies to not distribute their profits to shareholders to avoid the tax that may be payable thereby on the dividends, but rather for a loan to be made to the shareholders. That loan is very often on non-commercial terms-with no interest payable and it being repayable on demand-which means that the shareholder effectively gets the income be without having to pay tax on it. The income tax law has for many years had a provision attempting to deal with this issue, but it has proven ineffective in meeting its objectives. Last year's budget contained an announcement to tighten the law to ensure that non-commercial loans by private companies to their shareholders were subject to punitive tax to stamp out that practice, and that is achieved in the bill by strengthening the existing provisions-sections 108 and 109. These proposals have been particularly controversial with the small business community, which has lobbied strongly against them. The government has relented on some aspects, specifically those concerning benefits paid to shareholders in their capacity as employees, which contained a myriad of unintended consequences sometimes involving double or even triple taxation. Incredibly, the backdown on employee benefits was announced not by the Treasurer but by the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, who was left to clean up the Treasurer's mess in this respect. The Treasurer always runs for cover when it comes to anything remotely embarrassing in the conduct of his portfolio. While supporting the proposals in principle in the soon to be amended bill, the opposition is concerned that there may be some further anomalies which do treat small businesses unnecessarily unfairly. We believe that these provisions should be properly examined by a Senate committee and that is the course that we have supported. Perhaps it is embarrassment over this issue which has caused quite outrageous behaviour, I have to say, by the government in regard to proper Senate scrutiny of this legislation. I understand the government is proposing that a Senate inquiry into this legislation should report by this Thursday-tomorrow-and it secretly scheduled hearings into the bill on Monday, before this House had even considered the government's amendments. Some of the complex raft of amendments, which have not even been dealt with in this House yet, were released last Friday evening, so people only had a few hours-no more than that-to lodge submissions to the committee. That is a bad joke in terms of the government's respect for parliamentary process, and it should come back to haunt them. The third measure goes to dividend imputation anti-avoidance. The 1997-98 budget contained a number of initiatives to counter abuse of the dividend imputation system. This bill proposes to implement two of these initiatives: namely, firstly, general antiavoidance provisions specific to imputation and, secondly, anti-streaming rules-that is, rules to counter the practice of companies paying dividends, and giving other benefits, to shareholders in such a way as to give shareholders who benefit most from iniputation credits a greater imputation benefit than those who would not benefit to the same degree. The general anti-avoidance rules will apply to schemes to obtain a tax advantage in relation to imputation credits-that is, trading in those credits or streaming. The tax commissioner has the choice of whether to limit the company's imputation credits or to deny shareholders the benefit of the credits, depending on the type of scheme and the circumstances of either party. These general anti-avoidance rules will supplement the specific provisions for anti-streaming and the announced, but not yet introduced, provisions aimed at countering trading in imputation credits. The industry is complaining that this sents a double jeopardy problem for taxpayers-namely, even if they comply with the specific requirements under the anti-streaming provisions or the upcoming anti-trading in imputation credits provisions, they may still be caught by general anti-avoidance provisions. In addition, some are concerned by the wide drafting of the anti-avoidance provisions, and the relaxation of the normal test from tax avoidance being the dominant purpose for the transaction to being other than incidental to the transaction. We are concerned that some of these criticisms may be valid, especially in the context of the potential impact on collective instruments, such as superannuation and managed investment funds, which are continually trading in shares, presumably for nontaxation reasons. We in the opposition certainly recognise the dilemma that, without general anti-avoidance provisions, wealthy taxpayers can be expected to devise ways to get around the specific provisions. God knows we fought long enough and hard enough to give real teeth and substance to part 4A in this respect. Accordingly, while strongly supporting the proposals in principle, the opposition is concerned that there may be some further anomalies which affect taxpayers unfairly, so what we want is for these provisions to be properly examined by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee. There are a number of other specific matters in respeCt of which the opposition takes the view that they are, on their face, reasonable and do not require any further serious investigation by a Senate committee. I am referring to provisions about employers' remittance systems and about capital gains tax and an assets register in relation to that. Then there are much smaller matters like election expenses for the Constitutional Convention, gifts to the National Nurses Memorial Trust, provisions about charitable trusts and also some minor changes to the sales tax regime. I indicate as to all of those measures that the opposition does not oppose them. The remaining part of the bill-and it is a very substantial part of the bill-goes to the question of choice of superannuation funds. repreI will leave detailed discussion of those matters, as I foreshadowed, to the member for Wills, whose bailiwick this is and .whose knowledge of this subject is immense. What I do simply want to foreshadow, as he will spell out in more detail, is that Labor does propose a number of amendments to this part of the legislation. They will include delaying the start date for choice until 1 July 2000 for both new and existing employees; ensuring that default funds contain specific investment choice and insurance cover features to protect those employees who do not make an active choice from winding up in an inappropriate fund; outlawing commission based sales of products which receive superannuation guarantee contributions; removing clause 32V, which overrides industrial awards; redefining the definition of 'industry based fund' to include the requirement that such funds operate on a not-for-profit basis; and inserting third-line forcing provisions which will prevent employers from forcing employees into a fund from which employers will receive a benefit. In addition to those amendments, and hopefully substituting for them and making them unnecessary, the member for Wills will be seeking the support of this House for a completely alternative approach to the whole question of choice of fund. We believe that there is a substantial case to be made for a quite different model, which would be a twostage one in which, as the first stage, all super funds with more than 50 fund members would be required to offer investment choice options to all fund members and, as a second stage, after an extensive education and consumer protection campaign, there would be implemented a genuine employee choice super model whereby employees could nominate to have super contributions paid into a fund other than that set out in an industrial award with the agreement of their employers. We believe that here our model would lead to a much better choice arrangement which is driven by those whom this government should be most concerned about but whom it is manifestly not concerned about-that is, the Australian workers. If the government were concerned about workers here as elsewhere, then it would not be proceeding with this costly complicated choice of fund model that will in fact result in lower retirement incomes. I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not opposing the second reading of bill, the House notes that the Government in legislation has: (1) broken its finn promise made before the last election to deliver the full amount of the' superannuation co-contribution; and (2) instead proposed a much less valuable and much less equitable savings rebate and notes that the policy; (a) only specifically actually rewards saving in the form of superannuation contributions; (b) enables the full amount of the rebate to be received notwithstanding the taxpayer has actually engaged in dis-saving; (c) will result in the level of national savings being significantly lower than if the superannuation co-contribution arrangements were implemented; (d) is not means tested and is therefore inequitable in its impact; and (e) is so unfair that the Prime Minister announced to this House that he would' not claim his entitlement".

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being approximately 7.30 p.m., I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Industrial Relations  p.m.)-Tonight I want to express my abhorrence at this government's divisive and confrontational actions in vilifying Australia's working men and women, their families and their unions. Australians elect governments to solve problems, give leadership, unite us and build our nation. What we have is a government that sets out to deliberately create problems and to divide Australians. It is setting Australian against Australian, pitting worker against worker and painting unionists and unions as lazy, overpaid, underworked and un-Australian, so encouraging the vilification of their families, even in their own communities. Why? Because the objective of the government is to destroy the trade union the movement, to bust unions, to Americanise our this workplaces and to make it easier to reduce working conditions, pay and entitlements. Mr Speaker, you and I know that we have had conservative governments in the past, but the Howard government is the most divisive, confrontationist, incompetent and dishonest in living memory. This government cultivates the politics of envy by listing the workers' gross incomes and deleting any reference to working conditions, hours worked, risks entailed or disruption to family life. They say all this whilst they ignore the incompetence of senior managements. They ignore the obscene and totally unjustified amounts paid to mining executives, and company executives generally. Business executives are being rewarded for abolishing jobs, so increasing unemployment. These executives preach parsimony to workers whilst shovelling cash, pensions and share options into their treasure chests. Let me cite Rio Tinto as an example. The most recent news on its Internet site concerning Rio Tinto's Hunter Valley No.1 mine says that it is now one of the least productive mines in the Hunter Valley and last year made profit of $1 per tonne. It ignores the revenue squandered by management of this global multinational in demurrage payments which cost $2 to $3 per tonne. They knowingly sell coal for delivery at a rate that cannot be achieved, resulting in late delivery penalties or demurrage payments. .It refers to the average length of service of a Rio Tinto employee at Hunter Valley No.1 mine as being 12112 years. On Rio Tinto's Internet site, they discuss 'The best person for the job based on their skills and performance, not just their length of service. An end to the seniority system'. That may be a subject for discussion, but clearly this does not apply to the directors. The average length of service of the Australian directors, Messrs Clifford, Davis and O'Leary, is 37 years. Of all the directors on the board, the - verage length of service is 24 years. So much for seniority; so much for new thinking, currency in ideas and new ideas in personnel and management. Let us tum to salaries. The Internet site shows the average salary for an employee. For example, a truck driver at the Hunter Valley No.1 mine earns between $73,000 to $83,000 per annum for a 42Yz hour week and up to $97,000 with overtime and other benefits-like many others in society. Compare this with the exorbitant and obscene salaries of top executives and directors of Rio Tinto: Lee Clifford, mining director of Rio Tinto, was entitled to a lump sum pension at the end of 1996 of $2,759,000, an increase of $1,343,000 over 1995. He received a total salary in 1996 of $1,243,000 before tax, an increase of $284,000 from the previous year-an increase of almost 30 per cent. Leon Davis, chief executive, entitled to a lump sum pension of $6,600,000 at the end of 1996, an increase of $1,148,000 over 1995. His total salary was $1,815,000 before tax, an increase of $803,000 on the previous year. Michael O'Leary, director, was entitled to a lump sum pension of $4,025,000 at the end of 1996. His total salary in 1996 was $853,000 before tax, an increase of $293,000 from 1995. Little wonder that workers and their families rebel at the arrogant and intimidating activities of managements of companies like a Rio Tinto. In all my parliamentary experience covering transport and industrial relations, I have never seen a firm that got best performance for shareholders, employees and customers by confronting, intimidating and vilifying their employees. But this is the kind of behaviour that is aided and abetted by this H.R. Nicholls Society led government supporting the actions of foreign multinationals like Rio Tinto whose only commitment is to themselves and their foreign shareholders. Any benefit to Australia is incidental. This government refuses financial assistance to workers who have been robbed of their termination entitlements. (Time expired) Taxation of Compensation Moneys

Title: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr MUTCH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Certainly. The Federal Court of Australia last week made a landmark ruling in a case involving my local constituent and justice fighter Maree Whitaker. Mrs Whitaker is blind as a result of an operation some years ago that went wrong and where she developed the condition 'sympathetic ophthalmia' . With this condition an operation on one eye can detrimentally affect the other good eye. The surgeon involved was found to be liable in contract and in negligence, and Mrs Whittaker was awarded a substantial amount of damages in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. The surgeon's appeal to the Court of Appeal was dismissed. A further appeal by special leave to the High Court was also dismissed. At question in the case decided by the Federal Court last week was whether Mrs Whitaker was liable to pay tax on the prejudgment interest, that is, the amount paid to compensate her for the loss of compensation moneys between the time of the operation and the Supreme Court judgment and the postjudgment interest, the loss of the use of compensation moneys between the date of the Supreme Court judgment and the date of termination by. the High Court. This was an extremely important test case for people who have received compensation moneys for personal injuries sustained through the negli- state. gence of others and upon which many incapacitated people must rely for their income for the rest of their life. The matter is long running. In 1996, I wrote to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to ensure that legal costs for Mrs Whitaker's appeal were funded by the Australian Taxation Office. It is an indication of the importance of the case that the Australian Taxation Office agreed to pay these costs, regardless of the outcome. Before the Federal Court, solicitors Warren MCKean Dixon of Miranda argued that prejudgment interest compensates a victim for deprivation of the use of a compensation sum pending final resolution of the case, not because an investment opportunity has been forgone. This argument prevailed with respect to pre-judgment interest. However, postjudgment interest, due to the interpretation of section 95 of the Supreme Court act as compared to section 94, is taxed. It seems to me that, from the point of view of a personal injuries compensation victim, the legal distinction is semantic. The trial judge is unable to calculate into a damages award the possibility of appeal so as to ultimately compensate the victim for the exigencies of the legal process. Therefore, I ask that the Treasurer, in view of the review of the taxation system now in progress, look at the position of compensation victims and consider, in the case of such victims, treating so-called interest payments-both preand post-judgment-as forming part of the sompensation payment. I ask that it be considered to be compensation for added pain and suffering for delay in resolution and for keeping the victim from use of the money. The money may not have been invested at all, but might have been needed immediately for the assistance and comfort of the injured party. I hope this matter will be considered by the government's tax consultative task force in the interests of those people whose lives have, in many cases, been made very difficult because of the injuries they have sustained and who have to rely upon their own devices and the compensation moneys to look after themselves so as not to be a burden upon the Greek Community Cyprus

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Watson) (7.41 p.m.}-Last week I was pleased to attend the Greek National Day celebrations in Sydney and the Greek embassy's function for Greek National Day on 25 March this year. The Greek National Day is celebrated very extensively in Sydney with a number of large functions, some supported by various Greek organisations and a very large celebration supported by the Greek Orthodox Church. As usual, the meeting in Sydney last Sunday fortnight was very well attended by politicians as well as by leading figures in the Greek community. This month the Greek Festival of Sydney is running, and the highlight of that will be a function at the Greek Club inLakemba in my electorate. I think the Greek community in Sydney is what helps to make Sydney a very Mediterranean city. In my electorate there is a particularly large Greek community. The outward looking approach of the Greek community melds exceptionally well, I think, with the Australian approach. We have there an excellent example of the way multiculturalism in this country works. As is usually the case at these gatherings, one of the focuses was the situation in Cyprus. If there is one matter that draws those who are of Greek origin and those who have a supportive nature together it is the continuing division of Cyprus. Many of us thought that the beginning of the talks about the accession of Cyprus to the European Union meant that the Turkish government would see some sense, that there would be closer ties built between the Turkish Cypriots and the Greek Cypriots and that there would be a withdrawal of the Turkish troops from Northern Cyprus. One good thing about the accession of Cyprus to the European Union would have been that we would have seen the borders between the rest of Europe and Cyprus become more transparent, which should also have made the green line that runs through the northern part of Cyprus disappear. It is unfortunate that the Turkish government seems to have taken a very strong line against Cyprus's accession to the European Union, and it was most unfortunate that the Turkish Cypriot representatives did not participate in the accession talk. It is very interesting that Robin Cook, the British Foreign Minister who has the pre-idency of the EU at present, noted and welcomed the offers by the Cyprus government to include Turkish Cypriot representatives in the team negotiating the terms of Cyprus's accession to the European Union. Cook said: The European Union regrets that the Turkish Cypriot community have so far responded negatively to this offer. It reiterates the importance that attachesthat is, the unionto associating the Turkish Cypriots with the accession process, in accordance with the conclusions of the Luxembourg European Council. The Presidency and the Commission will pursue the necessary contacts. I think that that is what should happen. The Denktash regime in the north should not be trying to use this as an excuse to partition the island. The Turkish Cypriot junta in the north should join in the accession process so that Cyprus can once again become a united country and Turkish Cypriots and Greek Cypriots can live as one in an undivided homeland. As part of Europe, that would promote a lot more economic benefits for all Cypriots and will certainly allow Cypriots from both parts of the island to visit each other and get on with their lives, which is what most of the ordinary Cypriots want, unHke what many of the Turkish Cypriot politicians want. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Before I call on the next member, on behalf of the parliament I thank the honourable member for Watson for the job he does representing this parliament on the Committee for Cyprus of the Interparliamentary Union, which is a very important function on behalf of all Australians. Child Care Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay) (7.46 p.m.)-I wish to make some comments tonight in light of the comments on child care on 30 March by the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). She continues to spread Labor misinformation which even the Australian Centre-Based Child Care associati'on, which represents 1,100 child-care centres, says is completely unfounded. In a press release of 22 February, the President of the Australian Confederation of Childcare said: We want to completely refute recent comments about Child Care which appear to be politically motivated, which suggest there have been substantial fee increases. This politically motivated campaign only serves to do long term damage to the Child Care Industry as a whole. This campaign is trying to blame the current Federal Government for reductions in attendance at Child Care Centres. Nothing could be further from the truth. it The current Federal Minister, Warwick Smith, has in a short space of time, shown more understanding and leadership in Child Care than any previous Minister in recent times. This Government has, for the first time, put in place a planning system for Child Care, it has removed inequitable funding practices such as operational subsidies, it has introduced a hotline for information about Child Care and it has recently announced a retention of the current system of allocation of Child Care assistance to families which will avoid complex and intrusive procedures for families. Without doubt children and families are the big winners under' The Howard Government's Child Care Policies. The Penrith City Council continues to rail against the reduction in operational subsidies. The operational subsidies effectively prevented some 51,000 families in outside school hours care from receiving any sort of childcare assistance. We have put the equity back into that. We have taken the $20 benefit from 70,000 families which was denied to 200,000 Australian families using private centres-and that $20 a week benefit basically went to fund community based centres-and we have spread that money over the entire child-care system. And it is not just long day care centres which the Penrith council is concerned about, considering that it runs 17 of them. We have spread it out over family day care centres, occasional care, outside school hours care services, vacation care services, playgroups, multifunctional children's services, multifunctional Aboriginal children's services, mobile children's services and toy libraries. we have really coveted this entire area. Yes, Penrith City Council is upset. Its .17 child-care centres have lost substantial amounts of federal money, which has gone to fund other child-care places, and they have to make up that deficit. But in addition to what the Commonwealth government was funding them, something like $2 million of the ratepayers of Lindsay's money was being spent by council on child care. This is to compete for places in an area which is oversupp-ied with child-care places. It is to compete against private centres in Lindsay, of which there are a number which have not put up their fees and are in fact cheaper than those run by council. These centres are still available, and here we are with Penrith City Council using federal money and local government money to compete against private centres which are providing an adequate service, given tha- all centres must comply with the state regulatIOns in order to qualify for the child-care assistance and the child-care rebate. These sorts of fees work together in a way that sees an equitable distribution of mo-ey between low income families, and they provide an extra 83,000 places over the next four years. By the end of next year, 83,000 inore child-care places will be available in the community, including in my area, to the people of Australia than were available under tpe previous government. An extra $4.9 billion has been allocated over four years. So I comph::tely refute any suggestion, any politically motivated innuendo, from t-e opposition that people of my electorate are III any way disadvantaged in terms of child care. Whatever it takes, this government is going to do it. We are providing more child-care places and more assistance. (Time expired) Concord Hospital

Speaker: Mr ZAMMIT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I take this opportunity in tonight'S adjournment debate to pay tribute to the role played by community volunteers in my electorate-those who belong to organisations and also those who act individually. Because of .the time constraints, I will refer to only one organisation and one individual. Ever since my election to the New South Wales state parliament in 1984 I have been aware of the highly dedicated and motivated Concord Hospital Service Auxiliary who are now into their 30th year, having commenced their work in 1969 when Concord Hospital was then known as the Veterans Hospital 113 AG.H. Repatriation and was widely respected as one of the finest teaching hospitals in Australia. In June 1993 the hospital was integrated into the state system and is now known as Concord Repatriation General Hospital. The volunteers did not miss a beat. They became incorporated and now number 120 men and women who continue to go from strength to strength. To raise funds, they operate a gift shop and candy cart, and run market days and raffles. In more recent times they have expanded their operations to include functions such as Christmas and July dinners, this year being their third dinner, all of which my wife, Rita, and I have attended. They have also organised race days at Rand. wick and Rosehill Gardens and dinner dances. They also organise one major fete day in the hospital grounds and/or at a local park. A wine auction dinner dance was held last Friday, which my wife and I also attended. It proved to be highly enjoyable and raised a very substantial sum of money under the highly experienced hammer wielded by the guest of honour, Len Evans. Additionally, the volunteers work in many departments and wards in the hospital, tidying and refreshing flowers, as well as undertaking many other tasks, including laminating, dynomaking, stamping various envelopes, rolling bandages, repairing equipment, filing and other clerical work, and assisting patients when required. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the livewire president of the volunteers, Ruth Ellis, who has proven to be a very great asset to the hospital and to our community in general. I will now list some of their very impressive financial donations to the hospital just in the past 2Y2 years. For the ophthalmology department, a Yag laser for the early detection of glaucoma, $17,000. For the radiology department, a mammography machine, $70,000. For the sports medicine department, a Bobath couch, $2,500. For the blood donors department, four lazy-boy chairs for the taking of blood, $3,500. In the chapel, the restoration of the original altar of the hospital, $500. For the burns unit, three TVs and videos for the comfort of long-stay patients, $4,000. For the medical oncology day-care unit, mattress covers to provide relief for very ill patients, $4,000 in various wards. For the ENT department, a Kay's rhino-laryngeal stroboscope, $16,500. For the new transit room, two bezique standard back armchairs, $600; two bezique high back armchairs, $660; two pastor standard back armchairs, $220; one upright refrigerator, $850; and one TV, NEC brand, $740; a total of $3,070. In addition, for the orthopaedics department, audiovisual equipment to educate patients and staff, $600. For the ANZAC Health and Medical Research Foundation, $50,000. For the Kokoda Track Walkway Ltd, $4,102. Various departments require assistance with water coolers, ice making machines, curtains and tablecloths. For the cardiac department, two monitoring machines worth $7,000. I say: well done, Ruth Ellis and the Concord Hospital volunteers. While on the topic of volunteers, I also pay tribute to a most delightful and energetic 90year-old lady who, when asked about her age, said simply that she had reached a significant age- Mrs Dorothy Pemberton from Concord West in my electorate who, together with another 13 volunteers, many from the Concord Uniting Church, has been giving assistance at Homebush Boys High School over a very long period of time. Mrs Pemberton has been helping students to improve their reading and literacy skills and, as a former teacher. she has an excellent rapport with the students, who speak highly of her patience, knowledge, teaching skills and positive attitude. She has been attending Homebush Boys High School since 1991. She is a really great lady. On my behalf, and on behalf of my constituents, I wish Dorothy Pemberton a happy retirement and continued good health. Great Western Highway

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Macquarie) (7.56 p.m.)Last night I made a few comments about the needs of the Great Western Highway, until the clock rather cruelly brought my run to an end, although perhaps to the relief of some others present. I made some comments about the importance of the Great Western Highway for a number of reasons-as a link between the central west and the ports and markets of Sydney, because of the needs of a growing tourism market in the mountains, and the need for access for emergency vehicles. The same comments apply also to the Bells Line of Road, an important alternative route across the Blue Mountains. I finished by talking about safety issues relating to the Great Western Highway compared to roads throughout the rest of the state. I made the comment that, throughout the state of New South Wales, on average, thr(:!e per cent of accidents lead to casualties, whereas on the Great Western Highway nine per cent of accidents lead to casualties. Across the state generally, one per cent of accidents lead to fatalities, but on the Great Western Highway three per cent of accidents lead to fatalities. So the Great Western Highway is a road of significant importance but one that needs considerable attention. It needs funding. In the last two years, the federal government has increased funding for roads to the state government of New South Wales. In 1995-96, the last year of the Labor government, $311 million was allocated for road funding to the New South Wales government. In the first year of this government, 1996-97, we increased it to $321 million, an increase of 3.1 per cent. In this year's budget, 199798, we increased it to $337 million, an increase of 5.2 per cent. Therefore, there really is "no excuse on the part of the state government not to increase funding for the Great Western Highway. Having said that, there is still a strong case for increased federal funding for the Great Western Highway. Sadly, in 1992, the former Labor government excluded the Great Western Highway from its national highway funding program, therefore leaving it solely dependent upon the resources of the state government. It is very pleasing to note, however, that this government has restored the roads of national importance program-in addition, I might say, to the black spots program. The RONI program does give some strong hope of increased funding for the Great Western Highway. It is for this reason that I urge the federal government to seriously consider upgrading the Great Western Highway to a road of national importance. It is, on all accounts, a road of national importance, for the reasons that I said. It is a very vital link between western New South Wales, central New South Wales and the markets and ports of Sydney. It is, in essence, a road of national importance and does need to be. funded appropriately. I look forward, therefore, to increased federal government attention to the Great Western Highway - nd the improvements that will bring. It is important that we do improve the traffic flow, that we do improve the development and employment opportunities for people in the mountains and central and western New South Wales. It is important that we assist the burgeoning tourist industry in the Blue Mountains. It is important, while doing all of this, that we consider the needs_ of local residents and it is important, most of all, that we improve the highway in order to reduce casualties and to save lives.

Speaker: Ms WORTH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Adelaide-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services) (8.00 p.m.)-I acknowledge the commitment of the member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay) to a just solution to the Cyprus problem and again place on the parliamentary record my own commitment to exactly the same solution. I am, in fact, the patron of the Justice for Cyprus Coordinating Committee in South Australia. I took a special interest in this subject because of the constituents I represent in my electorate. In fact, I travelled with the member for Watson and others to Cyprus and Greece roughly 18 months ago. To speak to one's constituents and feel committed to what they are committed to is one thing, but to visit Cyprus and see the division there, to see our peacekeeping force in action, to see the green line, to see the flag pole where Solomos Solomou was shot down, to look through binoculars over Famagusta where people in my electorate lived and to know that the only way they can see the city that they lived in is through binoculars because of the division there is to bring home the lack of human rights that people there are still experiencing and, of course, to acknowledge how fortunate we are in our own country to not have those divisions. In South Australia, the Cyprus Community of South Australia Inc. has just celebrated its 50th anniversary. I was pleased to help celebrate with them at a debutante ball and assist in cutting their very splendid cake. They are very good citizens of our country, many of them coming here as refugees, many of them from one particular village which is still in that northern occupied part of Cyprus. I am sure that all of my colleagues here would welcome any progress on solving the Cyprus problem. I have noted that the European Union yesterday welcomed the Republic of Cyprus to the accession process and also expressed regret over the continued Turkish occupation of part of Cyprus. On behalf of the EU, Council President Robin Cook said: I am delighted that today we are meeting to open accession negotiations. The Union has shown it can respond decisively and effectively to the transformation of Europe's political landscape and use the opportunities this offers to end the divisions of the past. These efforts are being matched by Cyprus which has made great strides on the path to accession. The EU regrets that it has not been possible to achieve a political solution to the continuing division of Cyprus in time for the accession negotiations on which we embark today. The Union believes that Cyprus' accession to the EU should benefit all communities, including the Turkish Cypriot community, and help to bring about civil peace and reconciliation on the island. In that context, our objective remains a bi-communal, bi-zonal federation on the basis of a comprehensive political settlelllent in accordance with UN Security Council Resolutions. A political settlement would allow the provisions of the Accession Treaty to be implemented throughout the island. Mr Cook also noted that the EU welcomes the offer by the Cyprus government to include Turkish Cypriot representatives in the team for negotiating the terms of the Cyprus accession to the EU. He said: The European Union regrets that the Turkish Cypriot community has so far responded negatively to this offer. I would have to reiterl,lte my own disappointment and I know that of those in my own electorate who are so interested in this just solution. In fact, in Adelaide the community have made sure that they have made contact with Turkish Cypriots who are also living in Australia. They are recognising what they share in common and how important that reconciliation, which has been spoken of in the EU yesterday, is to them. I would hope the member for Watson, and I am' sure all people in this place-I know you also have a special interest in this issue,

text: would join me in hoping for a just solution in the not too distant future. (2) What decisions were announced at the meeting with regard to the establishment of an Asian currency stability fund, and what involvement in the fund will the Australian Government have. (3) Is he able to provide detail on progress by the IMF to stabilise the Thai and other currencies in the region. (4) Will the currency turmoil in Asia have any impact on Australian exports. (5) What role is being played by Australia in dealing with currency stability in Thailand and Asia. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Decisions made at or in the context of the September 1997 IMF and World Bank annual meetings included a 45 per cent increase in IMF quotas, an allocation of Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) and an approximate doubling of the authorised capital of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) Quotas are the financial subscriptions made by member countries to the IMF. The agreement reached in September was formally adopted by the Board of Governors of the IMF in February 1998 and is currently awaiting ratification by members. The quota increase will expand the resources available to the IMF to fulfil its responsibilities including the provision of emergency assistance to members. Australia will benefit to the extent that IMF programs are able to be more effective in supporting the economic recovery of global and regional trading partners. SDRs are financial assets created by the IMF and allocated to members to supplement their international reserves. The agreement reached for an SDR allocation of SDR21.4 billion will double the NA volume of SDRs on issue. Australia will receive SDR213.5 million, valued at about $A426.9 million, from the IMF as a result of this decision. Our international reserves will increase accordingly. Agreement was also reached for a doubling of the capital of MIGA. MIGA provides political risk insurance and' advisory services in relation to foreign investment in developing countries. Australia is in the process of finalising its membership of MIGA. Australia will benefit from the capital increase through the strengthening of MIGA's capacities to provide insurance and advisory services to Australian businesses investing in developing countries. (2) The annual meetings did not make any decisions on the establishment of an Asian currency stability fund, but a meeting of officials to discuss made a proposal for the establishment of an Asian monetary fund was held in Hong Kong at the time of the annual meetings. This meeting did not reach agreement. A further meeting of officials in Manila on 1819 November 1997 agreed on a new framework for enhanced Asian regional cooperation. This included a mechanism for regional surveillance to complement global surveillance by the IMF, enhanced economic and technical cooperation particularly in strengthening domestic financial systems and regulatory capacities, measures to strengthen the IMF's capacity to respond to financial crises, and a cooperative financing arrangement that would supplement IMF resources. This "Manila Framework" was endorsed by APEC Economic Leaders at their meeting in Vancouver on 25 November 1997 and by the ASEAN plus Six Finance Ministers meeting in Kuala Lumpur on 2 December 1997. Australia was represented at these meetings by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, respectively. (3) The governments of Thailand, Indonesia and the Republic of Korea have each agreed on reform programs with the IMF. Summaries of the programs are included in the latest edition of the Treasury Roundup. They include both macroeconomic and structural measures designed to restore market confidence. Thailand and the Republic of Korea have both made good progress in implementing their programs and in reducing market turbulence. In Indonesia, less progress has been made and an IMF team is currently reviewing the program. (4) The outlook for growth in many of Australia's trading partners in the East Asian region has weakened considerably in the face of financial market turbulence over the past six months and that is likely to have a negative impact on both the quantity and price of Australian exports to the region. Most likely to be affected by the downturn are exports of manufactures and services (such as tourism and various business services), demand for which tends to be influenced by changes in incomes in countries of destination. Indicators of a decline in tourism credits have already emerged, with arrivals from Asia falling by 23.5 per cent through the year to December 1997. Non-rural exports may also be affected by a downturn in world industrial production. However, the impact is more likely to be felt through lower prices than through lower export volumes. This is because export volumes of some non-rural commodities are more likely to be affected by domestic production than income levels in export markets. Asia accounts for a large proportion of our rural exports and the world price of some rural commodities have fallen as a result of the slowdown in Asia. However, as with some non-rural commodities, volumes of a number of important rural exports, such as cereals, are largely determined by the quantity produced rather than movements in the income levels of export markets. In addition, for some rural commodities, such as beef, veal and sugar, supply difficulties elsewhere in the world may work to the advantage of Australian suppliers, despite a downturn in demand from East Asia. The impact on growth in the Asian economies affected by instability will be reduced by the positive effects of depreciation of their currencies on their exports. This in turn provides export opportunities for countries such as Australia, whose exports feed into the production of Asian exports. (5) Australia has been active in regional consultations at Ministerial and official level on the crisis, and through our representatives on the Executive Boards of the IMF, World Bank and Asian Development Bank. Australia is participating in support for the IMP-supported programs for Thailand, Indonesia and Korea. Japan and Australia are the only countries in all three support arrangements. In each case, Australia's support is for up to $USI billion. Australia's support for Thailand is being provided through currency swaps between the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Bank of Thailand. The size and timing of the swaps are in parallel with the disbursements being made to Thailand by the IMP. A first swap of $US400 million was made on 12 September 1997, a second swap of $US200 million was made on 17 December 1997 and a third of $80 million on 13 March 1998. The support arrangements for Korea and Indonesia are based on the Manila Framework and constitute a second line of defence which can be called upon in the event that unanticipated adverse external circumstances create the need for additional resources to those provided by the IMF and other international financial institutions. As at the end of February 1998, no funds have been transferred under these support arrangements. On 25 December 1997, the bilateral supporters announced a willingness to activate up to $US8 billion (around a third) of the support funds for Korea in response to continuing market pressures and in conjunction with the announcement by the Korean Government of a revised adjustment program. With the subsequent improvement in market conditions, these funds have not so far been required. Operation Mandrake (Question No. 2515) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 18 November 1997: (1) Does Operation Mandrake monitor 1300 known paedophiles and approximately 400 additions each year. (2) Is he able to say how many Australian Federal Police (AFP) officers are assigned to Operation Mandrake; if not, why not. (3) Is it a fact that there is not one single full time officer assigned to Operation Mandrake. (4) Is it a fact that Operation Mandrake is managed by two part-time officers and one part-time staff member. (5) Are the resources allocated by the Commonwealth to the AFP for the fight against paedophilia sufficient, if so, why. Mr Williams-The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourarrangements able member's question: (1) The AFP maintains an intelligence project codenamed 'Mandrake' relating to paedophilia. The AFP investigates Australians involved in paedophile activities overseas and monitors in particular the overseas travel of those persons who are the subject of alerts. Statefferritory police have the primary role in the investigation of paedophilia activities within Australia and the AFP provides information and international support on request. As at 15 January 1998 the database contains 1854 names of which 330 are considered as potential offenders under the Crimes. (Child Sex Tourism) Act. The rest are persons who, for a variety of reasons, have come to notice in relation to paedophilia. Some are convicted paedophiles, but the majority are suspects, to varying degrees. On creation of the database in 1994, there were approximately 122 entries. In the last three years, entries have averaged 450 per annum. It could, however, be misleading to draw inferences from these figures alone as to the scale of criminal paedophile activity. An assessment of the nature and scale of any criminal activity involves judgements drawn from a number of sources, of which statistics is only one. (2) The AFP maintains a flexible workforce with a system of operational assessment which allows resources to be allocated according to priority. The AFP currently has nine people throughout Australia engaged in investigation and intelligence collection relating to paedophilia. (3) No. (4) No. See (2) above. (5) I am satisfied that the AFP resources currently being allocated to the investigation of suspected paedophile activities meets Commonwealth responsibilities. The Commonwealth Government, through the AFP, has responsibility for eriforcement of the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Act 1994. This Act makes it an offence for Australians and permanent residents of Australia, to engage in child sex tourism overseas. The Act has extra-territorial powers and persons may be prosecuted for acts committed outside Australia. The AFP, through its overseas liaison network and membership of Interpol, monitors overseas travel of persons suspected to be involved in paedophilia and also investigates the illegal use of the communications network (Internet) to transmit child pornography. This is carried out in close cooperation with State and Territory Police Services which carry the primary responsibility for investigating paedophile activity in Australia. The Commonwealth Government remains concerned about Australians who engage in paedophile activity overseas and is working closely with other countries to discourage such activity. This includes encouraging countries to strengthen their laws and to give priority to the protection of children. Australia has provided direct assistance to both Thailand and the Philippines in training of police officials to investigate sexual offences against children. Australia also recently entered into a Memorandum of Understanding with the Philippines to co-operate in the exchange of information relating to child sex activity. Foundation for Survivors of Torture: Commonwealth Funding (Question No. 2671) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: Has the Commonwealth funded the Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture; if so, (a) under what category was the funding provided, (b) what tendering process was followed, (c) how many organisations applied for the funding, (d) did the Foundation receive additional funding for the purchase of major capital items such as vehicles; if so, under which funding round, (e) for what period has the funding been allocated under the service agreement between him and the Foundation, (f) what were the Foundation's client outcomes i1996-97, (g) were the outcomes considered in the tendering process and (h) does the Foundation receive recurrent funding; if so, for how many positions. Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Yes. (a) The funding provided by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to the Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture (VFST) is under the Community Settlement Services Scheme (worker based) category. (b) The VFST received funding through the . standard grants process in accordance with the guidelines for the Community Settlement Services Scheme for worker positions and projects which fitted the priority categories of the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy as identified by the Government in its Budget Statement of May 1997. (c) Six hundred and seventy organisations applied for funding in 1997-98. (d) No. (e) Funding was allocated for 1997-98 for twelve months commencing 1 October 1997. (f) In 1996-97, the VFST provided services to 744 refugee and humanitarian entrants who have experienced some form of torture and trauma, mainly from Bosnia, Iraq and Somalia. These services included an early intervention program (assessment and counselling) for 511 clients placed in On Arrival Accommodation (OAA). One hundred clients were assessed as requiring short term counselling and 102 clients required medium to long term counselling. The VFST also works in collaboration with mainstream and specialist agencies to provide specialist health services and other generalist settlement services. (g) Yes. (h) The VFST was funded for 12 months from 1 October 1997 until 30 September 1998. Funding is sufficient for approximately ten positions.
